3-16-2: CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS PROHIBITED:
   (A)   The following Adult-Use Cannabis Business Establishments are
prohibited within the Village. No person shall locate, operate, own, or allow
to be operated, or aide, abet, or assist in the operation any of the following
cannabis related business establishments within the Village:
Adult-Use Cannabis Craft Grower
Adult-Use Cannabis Cultivation Center
Adult-Use Cannabis Dispensing Organization or Dispensary
Adult-Use Cannabis Infuser Organization or Infuser
Adult-Use Cannabis Processing Organization or Processor
Adult-Use Cannabis Transporting Organization or Transporter
   (B)   No retail or service business, private club, or other similar
organization shall permit the on-site use of cannabis at their location or on
their premises in the Village. (Ord. 2019-11, 9-3-2019)
3-16-3: PUBLIC NUISANCE DECLARED:
Operation of any prohibited Cannabis Business Establishment within the Village
in violation of the provisions of this Chapter is hereby declared a public
nuisance and shall be abated pursuant to all available remedies. (Ord. 2019-11,
9-3-2019)
3-16-4: PENALTY:
Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this Chapter shall be
punished by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day a
violation is committed or permitted to continue under this Chapter shall
constitute a separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder. (Ord.
2019-11, 9-3-2019)
3-16-5: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this Chapter, or the application of any provision of this
Chapter, is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall
not affect other provisions of this Chapter, or their application, that can be
given effect without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its
application. Each unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such
provision, is severable, unless otherwise provided by this Chapter. (Ord. 2019-
11, 9-3-2019)
CHAPTER 17
LICENSED VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-17-1: Licensed Video Gaming Exemption
3-17-2: Definitions
3-17-3: Video Gaming Terminal Permit Sticker
3-17-4: Regulations Governing Establishment And Terminal Operators
3-17-5: Inspection Of Premises
3-17-6: Revocation/Suspension Of License And Permit Sticker
3-17-7: Seizure Of Unlawful Video Gaming Terminals
3-17-8: Penalties
3-17-1: LICENSED VIDEO GAMING EXEMPTION:
The prohibitions under any provision of the Village Code that may reference or
govern gambling or gaming shall not apply to any video gaming terminal that has
a valid video gaming terminal permit sticker and is in full compliance with the
other provisions of this Chapter 17 of Title 3 of the Village Code. (Ord. 2023-
04, 4-3-2023)
3-17-2: DEFINITIONS:
 
                       As used in this Chapter of the Village Code, means the
ACT:                   Video Gaming Act found at 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., as from
                       time to time amended.
                       Any business licensed by the State to have or operate a
                       Video Gaming Terminal in the Village of Roanoke,
ESTABLISHMENT:         including any licensed fraternal establishment, licensed
                       truck stop establishment, and licensed large truck stop
                       establishment, as these terms are defined under the Act.
                       An individual, partnership, corporation or limited
                       liability company that is licensed under the Act and
TERMINAL OPERATOR:     that owns, services, and maintains video gaming
                       terminals located within the corporate limits of the
                       Village.
                       This definition shall have the same meaning ascribed to
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: such term by the Act, as amended from time to time.
                       (Ord. 2023-04, 4-3-2023)
 
3-17-3: VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL PERMIT STICKER:
In order for a video gaming terminal to be operated by an establishment or by a
terminal operator, the establishment and terminal operator are required to
obtain an annual video gaming terminal permit sticker from the Village for each
video gaming terminal located on its premises by submitting a written
application, on a form provided by the Village to the President or the party
designated by him/her. Each video gaming terminal permit sticker issued by the
Village shall expire April 30, next, after date of issue, with an annual fee of
one-hundred dollars ($100.00) per video gaming terminal payable in full at the
time the application is filed with the Village. The cost of this fee shall be
shared equally between the terminal operator and the establishment where the
video gaming terminals are operated. (Ord. 2023-04, 4-3-2023)
3-17-4: REGULATIONS GOVERNING ESTABLISHMENT AND TERMINAL OPERATORS:
The following regulations apply to all establishment and terminal operators
operating a video gaming terminal on its premises with a valid video gaming
terminal permit sticker for each of its video gaming terminals:
   (A)   No more than the State allowed maximum number of video gaming
terminals may be located on establishment premises.
   (B)   A valid Village video gaming terminal permit sticker shall be clearly
displayed at all times on each video gaming terminal.
   (C)   Other than having up to the State allowed maximum number of video
gaming terminals with valid video gaming terminal permit stickers, the
establishment and terminal operator are prohibited from having, anywhere on its
premises, an electronic video gaming machine that may be available to play or
simulate the play of poker, line up, blackjack, faro, roulette, craps, slots,
or any other card or dice game or other game of chance, or that is otherwise
akin to a gambling or gaming device, even if solely for amusement purposes.
   (D)   No establishment or terminal operator may cause or permit any person
under the age of twenty-one (21) years to use, play or operate a video gaming
terminal.
   (E)   No person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age may be within
ten feet (10') of the gaming device. The area must, at all times, be within the
view of at least one (1) employee who is at least twenty-one (21) years of age.
   (F)   No video gaming terminal may be played except during the legal hours
of operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic beverages at the
establishment pursuant to this ordinance.
   (G)   The establishment and the terminal operator must fully comply with the
Act and all rules, regulations and restrictions imposed by the Illinois Gaming
Board.
   (H)   The establishment and the terminal operator must fully comply with all
other ordinances of the Village as well as federal and Illinois law and
regulations. (Ord. 2023-04, 4-3-2023)
3-17-5: INSPECTION OF PREMISES:
Every establishment where a video gaming terminal is kept shall be subject to
inspection by the Village President, designated law enforcement official, or
his/her authorized agents, at any time, to ensure compliance with the Village
Code. This includes all establishments applying for a video gaming terminal
permit sticker. It shall be unlawful for any person to hinder, resist, oppose
or attempt to hinder, resist or oppose the Village President, law enforcement
official, or his/her respective agents in the course of any inspection. (Ord.
2023-04, 4-3-2023)
3-17-6: REVOCATION/SUSPENSION OF PERMIT STICKER:
The Village may revoke or suspend any video gaming terminal permit sticker
issued by the Village if it determines that the establishment or the terminal
operator has violated any of the provisions of this chapter. No license shall
be so revoked or suspended, except after a public hearing before the Village
Board, with a three (3) day written notice to the establishment or terminal
operator (as applicable) affording the establishment or terminal operator an
opportunity to appear and defend. Notwithstanding the foregoing, any
establishment that has its liquor license revoked or suspended by the Village
or by the Illinois State Liquor Commission, or has its video gaming license
revoked or suspended by the Illinois Gaming Board, shall automatically, without
a hearing before the Village Board, have all Village video gaming terminal
permit stickers revoked or suspended for the same time frame as its liquor and/
or Illinois Gaming Board gaming license is suspended, whichever the case may
be. (Ord. 2023-04, 4-3-2023)
3-17-7: SEIZURE OF UNLAWFUL VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS:
Every video gaming terminal that does not have a valid video gaming terminal
permit sticker or is otherwise unlawful shall be considered a gambling device
subject to seizure and shall be turned over to the Illinois Gaming Board, in
accordance with Board regulations and applicable law, unless otherwise ordered
by a court of competent jurisdiction. (Ord. 2023-04, 4-3-2023)
3-17-8: PENALTIES:
Whoever violates any provision of this Chapter 17 of Title 3 of the Village
Code shall be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first
offense in any twelve (12) month period, and a fine of seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for a second offense and each subsequent offense in a twelve
(12) month period. This penalty may be enforced by issuance of a "Notice of
Violation" for the fine amount, or by issuance of a "Notice to Appear." Each
day any violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. This monetary
penalty shall be in addition to any and all other remedies which may be
available to the Village under this Chapter 17 any other provision of the
Village Code or federal or Illinois law. (Ord. 2023-04, 4-3-2023)
TITLE 4
BUILDING REGULATIONS
Demolition Of Structures And Buildings   1
Moving Of Structures And Buildings   2
CHAPTER 1
DEMOLITION OF STRUCTURES AND BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-1-1: Demolition Permit
4-1-2: Permit Application
4-1-3: Evidence Of Disconnection Of Utilities
4-1-4: Adequate Drainage For Demolition Sites
4-1-5: Fees For Demolition Permits
4-1-6: Required Bonding And Insurance
4-1-7: Required Safety Drawings And Specifications
4-1-8: Required Use Of Aprons And Canopies
4-1-9: Demolition Of Structures Having Common Or Party Walls
4-1-10: Predemolition Inspections Of Premises
4-1-11: Issuance Of Demolition Permit
4-1-12: Supervision And Inspection Of Demolition Site
4-1-13: Maintaining Property In Safe Condition
4-1-14: Closure Of Adjacent Streets Or Sidewalks
4-1-15: General Regulations Pertaining To Demolition Or Wrecking Activities
4-1-16: Demolition And Wrecking Prohibited At Night
4-1-17: Violation Penalty
4-1-18: Cost Schedule
4-1-1: DEMOLITION PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to demolish or wreck any
building or structure, or any structural part thereof, within the village,
without first obtaining a demolition permit from the director of inspections
for the village, or for any person or organization to otherwise violate any
provision of this chapter. The zoning officer for the village (see title 10 of
this code) is hereby designated as the "director of inspections" for the
village as used throughout this title. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-2: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Application for a permit to demolish or wreck any building or structure within
the village shall be made in writing by the owner or his agent, upon such
official village forms as may be furnished by the director of inspections. The
applicant shall file the appropriate forms with the director of inspections,
with copies to be filed with all utility companies serving the premises as well
as the owners or their agents of adjoining or neighboring properties. Such
application shall state the location and description of the building or
structure, the date when demolition is to commence, and the approximate length
of the time during which such demolition shall continue. If no new building is
to be erected on the site thereof, the statement of work to be done shall
include a description of the condition in which it is intended to leave the
site thereof. A permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall expire forty five
(45) days after the day of issuance, which may be extended an additional
fifteen (15) days upon a showing of good cause. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-3: EVIDENCE OF DISCONNECTION OF UTILITIES:
A permit to demolish, wreck or remove any building or structure or part thereof
shall not be issued by the village and shall not be valid until written
evidence has been submitted to the director of inspections, verifying that all
utility service connections and appurtenant equipment have been removed,
disconnected, sealed or plugged in a safe and appropriate manner. (Ord. 2003-
11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-4: ADEQUATE DRAINAGE FOR DEMOLITION SITES:
To prevent unsanitary and structurally unsound conditions, all structures or
buildings being demolished, wrecked or removed which have basements must have
all basement wall and floor surfaces cracked, broken and separated so as to
provide adequate drainage through and within the site. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-5: FEES FOR DEMOLITION PERMITS:
An applicant shall not be issued a demolition permit to demolish, wreck or
remove buildings, structures, or any part thereof unless and until a permit fee
has been paid to the director of inspections in accordance with the schedule
set forth in section
 4-1-18 of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-6: REQUIRED BONDING AND INSURANCE:
Before any permit required by this chapter is issued granting authority to
wreck a building or structure, the person engaged in the work or wrecking the
same shall:
   (A)   File with the director of inspections a bond with sureties to be
approved by the director of inspections, to extend to and cover all such
demolition or wrecking operations carried on through permits obtained
thereunder by such person during any year beginning May 1 and ending April 30,
to indemnify, keep and save harmless the village against any loss, cost,
damage, expense, judgment or liability of any kind whatsoever which the village
may suffer, or which may accrue against, be charged to or be recovered from the
village, or any of its officials, from or by reason or on account of accidents
to persons or property during any such wrecking or demolition operations; and
from or by reason or on account of anything done under or by virtue of any
permit engaged for any such wrecking or demolition operations; and no permit
shall be issued for any wrecking work, except as hereinbefore otherwise
provided during such year until such bond is filed. Such bond shall be in the
sum of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and shall be conditioned upon
the performance of the work covered by the permit. There shall be an additional
bond filed in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon
the restoring and leveling of the premises upon which such wrecking or
demolition operations have been completed.
   (B)   File with the director of inspections a certificate or other verified
proof that the applicant carries liability insurance, in the amounts of at
least one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person and three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000.00) per occurrence.
   (C)   File with the director of inspections a certificate indicating that
the applicant carries workers' compensation insurance covering all persons
working on the demolition job with the applicant, for the applicant, or on
behalf of the applicant.
In lieu of the bonds required in subsection (A) of this section, the applicant
may file with the director of inspections a bond for each permit sought, said
bond to be conditioned as the bonds in subsection (A) of this section. Said
bond shall be twice the full amount of the bid on the wrecking job, ten percent
(10%) in cash or its equivalent. This exception shall apply not more than once
per calendar year to any owner.
None of the bonds or insurances herein shall be required of the owner of
accessory buildings as described herein, when said owner is doing the
demolition of said accessory building himself; provided, said owner files with
the director of inspections a certificate or other verified proof that he
carries homeowners' liability insurance on said home in amounts not less than
fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) per person and one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000.00) per occurrence.
The director of inspections shall require before issuance of a permit such
additional bonds and insurance as may be necessary due to the ultrahazardous
nature of a particular wrecking or demolition operation. When determining
whether additional bonds and insurance will be necessary, the director of
inspections shall consider the following relevant factors:
   (A)   The existence of a common or party wall on the premises to be
demolished;
   (B)   The amount of traffic normally on the adjoining streets, alleys and
highways;
   (C)   The experience of the applicant and his employees in wrecking or
demolition operations;
   (D)   The length of time during which demolition or wrecking shall occur;
and
   (E)   Any other factors relevant to the hazard of that particular operation.
An overview of the bonding and insurance requirements is set forth in section
4-1-18 of this chapter. Should any conflict exist between this section and
section
4-1-18 of this chapter, the provisions of this section shall govern. (Ord.
2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-7: REQUIRED SAFETY DRAWINGS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
Where the building or structure intended to be wrecked or demolished is over
four (4) stories or forty five feet (45') above the adjoining sidewalk grade,
the property owner, demolition contractor, or his agent shall submit
specifications and a drawing indicating fences, barricades, aprons, canopies
and other safeguards which are to be used in connection with the demolition or
wrecking operation. These specifications and drawings shall be approved by the
director of inspections before a permit is issued to wreck or demolish such
building or structure, and the safeguards provided within such drawings and
specifications shall be erected in strict compliance therewith. (Ord. 2003-11,
9-2-2003)
4-1-8: REQUIRED USE OF APRONS AND CANOPIES:
Whenever required by this chapter or the director of inspections, the
demolition contractor or wrecker shall construct one apron for each four (4)
stories above adjoining sidewalk grade or multistoried buildings; the lowest
apron shall be in the third story. Each and every canopy and every apron shall
be designed according to provisions to safely support a uniformly distributed
load of two hundred fifty (250) pounds per square foot. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-
2003)
4-1-9: DEMOLITION OF STRUCTURES HAVING COMMON OR PARTY WALLS:
Before a permit is issued for the wrecking or demolition of a structure that
has one or more party walls in common with one or more buildings, the property
owner, demolition contractor, or wrecker shall deliver to the director of
inspections a certificate by a licensed architect or licensed structural
engineer to the effect that the adjoining premises do not require anchorage, or
if such certificate indicates that anchorage is necessary, the certificate
shall be accompanied by a drawing signed and sealed by such architect or
engineer and approved by the director of inspections indicating adequate
anchorage of floor and roof joists at not greater than ten foot (10') intervals
for each and every floor and roof resting on such party wall, and the adjoining
premises shall be anchored in strict compliance with such drawings. The written
consent of the owner of the adjoining premises permitting the anchorage shown
on such drawing shall also accompany the certificate. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-10: PREDEMOLITION INSPECTIONS OF PREMISES:
Before any demolition permit shall be issued, the director of inspections shall
inspect, or cause to be inspected, the premises where said demolition is to
occur, for the purpose of determining whether the planned measures for the
demolition are adequate so as not to endanger any utility systems,
installations or adjoining public or private properties. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-
2003)
4-1-11: ISSUANCE OF DEMOLITION PERMIT:
If the director of inspections finds that all the requirements of this chapter
are being complied with by the permit applicant, he shall approve the
application and issue a permit for such demolition or wrecking. Approval by the
director of inspections shall not relieve any party from complying with any
provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-12: SUPERVISION AND INSPECTION OF DEMOLITION SITE:
Upon the issuance of the demolition permit required by this chapter, such
building or structure may be demolished, wrecked or torn down; provided all the
work done thereunder shall be subject to the supervision of and inspection by
the director of inspections to determine the progress of work or to determine
if safety hazards exist. No person shall prevent or inhibit the director of
inspections from gaining access to the demolition site or fail to follow the
reasonable directives of the director of inspections regarding potential safety
hazards. The director of inspections shall also inspect, or cause to be
inspected, the premises upon the completion of work. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-13: MAINTAINING PROPERTY IN SAFE CONDITION:
As a condition of the issuance of any demolition permit required by this
chapter, the applicant or the property owner shall provide a written guarantee
to the village that upon completion of demolition or wrecking activities, the
premises will be left in a proper and safe condition, and that said applicant
or property owner shall stand liable under their bond for any work done
pursuant to subsection (C) of this section.
   (A)   For the purposes of this section, "proper and safe condition" means
that all debris is cleared away, that any excavation remaining is either filled
in and tamped down level with the final grade for the premises or surrounded by
a chainlink or masonry fence at least six feet (6') in height, if such property
is not to be put to immediate use. If the property is to be used for any
purpose within two (2) months after such demolition or wrecking and the
property is not brought to final grade, then adequate barricades, lighted at
night, shall be installed around the perimeter of such excavation during this
time period.
   (B)   Nothing in subsection (A) of this section shall be construed to permit
the maintenance of a public nuisance in permitting the excavations to be fenced
rather than filled. Village officials and the director of inspections retain
the power to require filling of excavations which become a threat to the public
health or safety. Upon receipt of written notice from village officials or the
director of inspections that an excavation must be filled because it presents a
threat to public health or safety, the applicant or property owner shall
immediately fill the excavation. Both the applicant and the property owner
shall be in violation of this provision until the excavation is properly filled
and made safe.
   (C)   If the premises are not cleared or put into a safe condition or work
commenced to do so within ten (10) days of the completion of the demolition or
wrecking, or within three (3) days after receiving notice under subsection (B)
of this section, the director of inspections shall authorize the work to be
done and expenses involved shall be chargeable to the posted bond.
The director of inspections shall inspect or cause to be inspected such
premises at least once daily during the period when such demolition or wrecking
continues. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-14: CLOSURE OF ADJACENT STREETS OR SIDEWALKS:
The director of inspections may grant permission to the demolition contractor
or property owner to occupy a roadway or sidewalk beyond the limits of the
premises undergoing demolition to include any adjacent roadway or sidewalk. The
demolition contractor or property owner shall obtain consent from the owner or
lessee of the adjacent property for closure of any sidewalks, unless the
director of inspections otherwise determines that closure of the sidewalk is
necessary for safety reasons. The director of inspections may approve the
closure of any roadway after consulting with village officials and the chief of
the Roanoke fire protection district. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-15: GENERAL REGULATIONS PERTAINING TO DEMOLITION OR WRECKING ACTIVITIES:
All operations of such demolition or wrecking shall be performed in a
workmanlike manner and with the least amount of noise possible. Care shall be
taken to protect neighboring structures with adequate shoring and whatever else
is necessary to protect such structures. Large signs stating "Wrecking and
Demolition Work in Progress -- No Trespassing" shall be erected on each side of
the building undergoing demolition that faces on a public street, alley or
sidewalk. Adequate protection shall be provided to prevent injury to any
village or public utility appurtenances on or near the premises subject to the
demolition process. It shall be the duty of all persons working at or
responsible for such demolition or wrecking to see that children are warned
away from such premises and are not permitted to play in or about the premises
subject to the demolition process or to frequent the structures undergoing
demolition. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-16: DEMOLITION AND WRECKING PROHIBITED AT NIGHT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct the demolition of any building
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.;
provided, however, that nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit
any work necessary at any time to prevent imminent injury to persons or
property, or any night work permitted or required by the director of
inspections to avoid potentially dangerous conditions for daytime traffic in
the vicinity of said building. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-17: VIOLATION PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and each day
that a violation continues shall be construed as a separate offense and
punished accordingly. The penalty herein provided shall be in addition to any
removal or destruction order that may be entered, or injunction issued. (Ord.
2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-1-18: COST SCHEDULE:
Permit fees, bonds, insurance and penalties:
   PERMIT FEES
      Amount      Type Of Structure
         $25.00   Nonresidential structures
         25.00   Residential structures
         -0-   Accessory building, 1 story in height and less than 200 square
feet in floor area
   BONDS
      Amount      Condition
         $100,000.00   Performance of demolition
         5,000.00   Restoration and leveling of property after demolition
   -OR-
Twice the full amount of the demolition job, 10 percent in cash or its
equivalent. This exception may be used by a property owner only once per
calendar year.
   -OR-
For the owner of an accessory building who is doing the demolition himself, a
certificate or other verified proof of the following homeowners' liability
insurance:
         $ 50,000.00   Per person
         100,000.00   Per occurrence
   LIABILITY INSURANCE
      Amount       Type
         $100,000.00   Per person
         300,000.00   Per occurrence
   WORKERS' COMPENSATION INSURANCE
Certificate indicating the permit applicant carries workers' compensation
insurance for all persons working on the demolition job with the applicant, for
the applicant, or on behalf of the applicant.
   VIOLATION PENALTY
$100.00 to $750.00 per each day of a violation of any provision of this
chapter.
(Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
CHAPTER 2
MOVING OF STRUCTURES AND BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-2-1: Moving Permit
4-2-2: Permit Application
4-2-3: Permit Fee
4-2-4: Bond Requirement
4-2-5: Performance Deposit Required
4-2-6: Issuance Of Permit
4-2-7: Supervision
4-2-8: Warning Lights And Signs Required
4-2-9: Cutting Of Wires
4-2-10: Fire Alarm Wires
4-2-11: General Moving Regulations
4-2-12: Violation Penalty
4-2-13: Cost Schedule
4-2-1: MOVING PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to move, or cause or permit to be moved,
any building or structure, on, through or over any street, alley, sidewalk or
other public place within the village without having first obtained a moving
permit. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-2: PERMIT APPLICATION:
Application for a permit to move any building or structure shall be made in
writing by the owner of the building or structure, the owner's agent, or
contractor, upon such forms as may be provided, to the director of inspections,
with copies to the village clerk, superintendent of streets, water and sewer
departments, any utility company serving the premises, and the owners or agents
of adjoining or neighboring premises.
Such application shall state the current location and description of the
building or structure, the date when moving is to commence, the proposed route
and the number of days that such building or structure shall occupy any portion
of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. Also, the application
shall include the owner's name and address and the name and address of the
party undertaking the moving. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-3: PERMIT FEE:
No permit to move any building or structure shall be issued unless and until a
fee shall have been paid to the director of inspections in the sum of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for each day or fraction thereof that it is intended that the
building or structure shall occupy any portion of any street, alley, sidewalk
or other public place. An additional sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each day
or fraction thereof over and above the time stated in such application, during
or on which any such building or structure shall occupy said public place shall
be paid to the director of inspections. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-4: BOND REQUIREMENT:
Before any permit to move any building or structure shall be issued, the person
engaged in the work of moving the same shall file with the director of
inspections a certificate bond, in an amount and conditioned as set forth in
section
4-2-13 of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-5: PERFORMANCE DEPOSIT REQUIRED:
Before any permit to move any building or structure shall be issued, the person
engaged in the work of moving the building or structure shall deposit with the
director of inspections a sum of money as set forth in section
4-2-13 of this chapter, conditioned upon the safe condition of the premises
after removal of such building or structure as provided in section
4-2-11 of this chapter. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-6: ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
If the director of inspections and the superintendent of streets, water and
sewer departments are satisfied that all provisions will be complied with, and
that all possible precautions will be taken by the applicant to prevent injury
to persons, vehicles or property, public or private, they shall approve the
application, and the director of inspections shall issue a permit for such
moving. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-7: SUPERVISION:
Upon issuance of the moving permit, such building or structure may be moved
upon the public ways; provided all work done thereunder shall be subject to the
supervision of the director of inspections. The director of inspections shall
inspect or cause to be inspected such operations at least once every two (2)
hours during the period when the moving is in progress. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-
2003)
4-2-8: WARNING LIGHTS AND SIGNS REQUIRED:
Whenever any street, alley or sidewalk is obstructed by any building or
structure being moved thereon, written warnings to that effect shall be placed
thereon by the persons engaged in the moving, adequate to warn vehicles and
persons entering that portion of the public way so obstructed.
Such persons engaged in the moving shall keep warning lanterns or lights upon
the building or structure after dusk and before dawn so as to warn any person
or vehicle against collision with the building or structure. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-
2-2003)
4-2-9: CUTTING OF WIRES:
Whenever it shall be necessary to interfere with any wires or cables of a
public utility in the moving of any building or structure, the terms of any
special or franchise ordinance governing the wires or cables shall apply and
the bond therein specified shall be given. If no such terms apply, then the
director of inspections shall estimate the expense of cutting and repairing the
wires and the bond to be given to cover such expense. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-10: FIRE ALARM WIRES:
Whenever any such moving building or structure approaches any fire alarm wire
or pole which shall be endangered by the moving of such building or structure,
the mover shall notify the chief of the Roanoke fire protection district at
least six (6) hours before reaching such wire or pole so that they may be
removed or protected by the village or fire protection district authorities.
(Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-11: GENERAL MOVING REGULATIONS:
   (A)   All moving operations shall be performed in a workmanlike manner and
with the least amount of noise possible. In addition to other safety
requirements specified in this chapter, it shall be the duty of all persons
working at or responsible for such moving operations to see that all persons
and vehicles are warned and kept away from such building or structure, and at
such distance as to prevent injury.
   (B)   The person granted the moving permit, or his agent, shall give notice
to the chief of the Roanoke fire protection district, village clerk, Woodford
County sheriff's department, superintendents of streets, water and sewer
departments, and any public utilities involved, at least two (2) hours in
advance of the commencement of any moving operations. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-12: VIOLATION PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in an amount
not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation is
committed or permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense and
shall be punishable as such. (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
4-2-13: COST SCHEDULE:
   PERMITS
      Amount      Term
      $50.00   For each full or partial day
   BONDS
      Amount      Type
      The same as set forth Certificate bond in section
4-1-18 of this title
   DEPOSIT
      Amount      Type
      The same as set forth in section
4-1-18 of this title   Performance - conditioned upon safe condition of the
property after removal of the building
   VIOLATION PENALTY
      Up to $750.00 for each day of the violation
   (Ord. 2003-11, 9-2-2003)
TITLE 5
FIRE REGULATIONS
General Fire Regulations   1
Fireworks and Explosives   2
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL FIRE REGULATIONS
SECTION:
5-1-1: Combustible Materials
5-1-2: Constructing Unsafe Structure
5-1-3: False Fire Alarm
5-1-4: Fire Lanes Designated
5-1-5: State Fire Marshal Regulations Adopted
5-1-1: COMBUSTIBLE MATERIALS:
No person shall burn, or cause to be burned, any hay, straw or other
combustible material within any street, alley or other public place in the
Village without the permission of the President of the Board of Trustees, or
within twenty feet (20') of any house, barn, shed, fence or wooden buildings.
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully kindle or leave any fire, or to
deposit or use any dangerous, combustible or inflammable material or liquid or
substance in any such manner as to cause damage or injury to any building or
other property, or in such a manner as to endanger any buildings or other
property within the Village.
5-1-2: CONSTRUCTING UNSAFE STRUCTURE:
lt shall be unlawful for any person to construct or use in any dwelling, shed
or other building in the Village, any stove pipe, chimney, fireplace, flue,
oven, boiler or other apparatus or fixture used for or in connection with fire,
when the same shall be in an unsafe condition.
5-1-3: FALSE FIRE ALARM:
lt shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly make false alarm of fire or
false cry for assistance, within the corporate limits of the Village. (R.O.
1908, Ord. 13)
5-1-4: FIRE LANES DESIGNATED:
The Board of Trustees of the Village and/or the committee designated by said
Village Board and the Chief of the Fire Department will meet and prescribe
certain areas to be designated as fire lane areas within the Village. Said fire
lane areas will be noted and mapped and said mapping will then be published in
the Roanoke Review, a local newspaper.
Appropriate signs will be posted along the designated streets informing the
public that these are emergency fire lane areas.
If at any time the fire lane areas are blocked in some way or fashion, the Fire
Chief, acting through the proper authorities of the Village, is empowered to
provide for the moving of any vehicles or other objects blocking such fire lane
areas at the expense of the owner of said blocking vehicles or objects. The
blocking objects will be moved and stored at the owner's expense at some place
designated by the proper Village authorities of the Village.
Anyone found to be violating this Section of the Village Code of the Village
will be guilty of a misdemeanor and cited as such. (Ord. 1979-9, 10-15-79)
5-1-5: STATE FIRE MARSHAL REGULATIONS ADOPTED:
The President and Board of Trustees of the Village ordain that the regulations
of the State Fire Marshal pertaining to the storage of volatile materials and
all other items that may be pertinent to the Village and the residents of the
Village are adopted in their entirety as they currently exist and as they are
amended from time to time.
The Village Attorney is empowered and directed to stay abreast of such
regulations so that it can be determined if anyone is in violation of those
regulations from time to time, so that they can be appropriately notified to
comply with the State laws that are hereby adopted and made part of the Village
Code. (Ord. 1990-4, 5-7-90)
CHAPTER 2
FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES
SECTION:
5-2-1: Sale of Fireworks and Explosives
5-2-2: Set Off Fireworks, Explosives
5-2-1: SALE OF FIREWORKS AND EXPLOSIVES:
The sale of commercially constructed fireworks and explosives of any nature
shall be forbidden within the boundaries of the Village, except as authorized
by the Village Board.
5-2-2: SET OFF FIREWORKS, EXPLOSIVES:
The firing of commercial or self-constructed fireworks, or the ignition of
explosives of any nature shall be forbidden within the Village limits, except
as authorized by the Village Board. (Ord. 152, 12-3-34)
TITLE 6
POLICE REGULATIONS
Misdemeanors   1
Animals; Fowl (Rep. by Ord. 1985-6, 10-7-1985)   2

CHAPTER 1
MISDEMEANORS
SECTION:
6-1-1: Advertisements
6-1-2: Aiding Escape
6-1-3: Annoying Persons On Streets
6-1-4: Assault Or Battery
6-1-5: Reserved

6-1-7: Disturbing Assemblages, Amusements
6-1-8: Disturbing The Peace
6-1-9: Drunkenness
6-1-10: Exhibit Animals
6-1-11: Fighting, Quarreling
6-1-12: Firearms
6-1-13: Furnishing Liquor To Prisoners
6-1-14: Gambling
6-1-15: Getting Upon Vehicles
6-1-16: Hindering Officers
6-1-17: House Of Ill Fame
6-1-18: Injuring Property
6-1-19: Killing, Injuring Certain Animals
6-1-20: Lewdness
6-1-21: Loitering
6-1-22: Noise Disturbance
6-1-23: Personating An Officer
6-1-24: Playing Ball In Streets
6-1-25: Spring Or Air Gun, Discharging
6-1-26: Throwing Missiles
6-1-27: Unlawful Assemblages
6-1-28: Vagrancy
6-1-29: Penalties
6-1-30: Trespassing
6-1-31: Curfew
6-1-32: Use Of Skateboards
6-1-33: Possession Of Tobacco Products By Minors
6-1-34: Dumping On Village Property
6-1-1: ADVERTISEMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to stick, nail, paint, brand or stamp, or
in any other manner put upon any house, fence, wall, pavement or other public
or private place in the Village, any written, printed, painted or other
advertisement, bill, notice, sign or poster without having first obtained the
consent of the owner or occupant or officer having the control of any such
house, fence, wall, pavement or other public or private place. (R.O. 1908, Ord.
11)
6-1-2: AIDING ESCAPE:
It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to aid, abet or encourage the
rescue or escape or attempt to escape from the calaboose, or from any officer
or person aiding him, of any person, or to attempt to supply or supply any such
person with any weapon or with any implement or means of escape or to aid, abet
or encourage any other person to perform any of the acts hereinbefore
mentioned. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-3: ANNOYING PERSONS ON STREETS:
No person shall pursue any amusement or exercise calculated to injure or annoy
any person passing along the street or sidewalk. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-4: ASSAULT OR BATTERY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit an assault and battery upon
another, or assault, strike or fight or challenge to fight another, or to be
guilty of any language, act or conduct calculated to provoke a breach of the
peace. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-5: RESERVED:
(Ord. 2016-10, 8-15-2016)
6-1-6: DISORDERLY CONDUCT:
It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb the peace or be guilty of any
violent, tumultuous, offensive or disorderly conduct or offensive carriage.
(R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-7: DISTURBING ASSEMBLAGES, AMUSEMENTS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct himself in a disorderly
or riotous manner at any place or exhibition, amusement or entertainment, and
if any person belonging to or connected with any such show or exhibition shall
conduct himself in a riotous or disorderly manner, or cause any disturbance or
breach of the peace at the place of exhibition, the license of such show or
exhibition may be revoked or forfeited in the discretion of the President of
the Board of Trustees or any proper Village officer.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully or heedlessly disturb
any lawful assembly of persons. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-8: DISTURBING THE PEACE:
Any two (2) or more persons who shall assemble for the purpose of disturbing
the peace, or of committing an unlawful act, and who shall not disperse when
commanded or requested by any peace officer, shall each severally be subject to
a penalty as provided for by section
1-4-1 of this code. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-9: DRUNKENNESS:
It shall be unlawful for any intoxicated person to be found in any street or in
any public place, or to be found disturbing the peace of the public, or of his
own or any other family, in any place. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-10: EXHIBIT ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person within the village limits to indecently
exhibit any stallion, bull, jackass or other animal in any public place, or to
let any such animal, except in an enclosed and covered place out of view, or to
let any such animal within ordinary hearing distance of any occupied dwelling
house, or to keep, stand or let any animal in such a place or in such a manner
as to disturb the peace and quiet of any neighborhood or family. (R.O. 1908,
Ord. 39)
6-1-11: FIGHTING, QUARRELING:
Any two (2) or more persons who shall, by agreement, fight in any public or
private place, or who shall meet to do any unlawful act upon common cause of
quarrel, and make any advance toward it, shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-12: FIREARMS:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to fire or discharge any
firearm except in case of necessity, or in the performance of lawful duty.
(R.O. 1908, Ord. 13)
6-1-13: FURNISHING LIQUOR TO PRISONERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to procure for, furnish or convey to any
person confined in the village calaboose intoxicating or spirituous liquors.
(R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-14: GAMBLING:
   (A)   Gaming House: It shall be unlawful for any person to, in the village,
by himself, servant or other agent, keep, maintain or support any gaming house
or place used for the practice of gaming, or to knowingly suffer or permit any
premises used, owned or occupied by him or under his control to be used for any
such purpose.
It shall be further unlawful for any person to knowingly suffer or permit any
species of gambling for money or other thing of value, or any check or other
thing intended to represent the same, in any house or premises occupied by him,
or owned by him or under his control, or to keep or have in his possession any
gaming implements for the purpose of gaming therewith.
   (B)   Raffle, Lottery: It shall be unlawful for any person, in any manner,
to gamble or raffle for money or other thing of value, or anything intended to
represent or representing money, or to conduct any lottery, or to dispose of,
for gain, any ticket, chance or share in any lottery, except that only state or
federal government lottery shall be exempt from these provisions. (R.O. 1908,
Ord. 11; amd. 1974 Code)
   (C)   Liquor Establishment: No retailer of liquors shall by himself, his
agent, servant or clerk suffer or permit any species of gaming in any part of
his premises, or in any place adjacent thereto under his control.
   (D)   Card Tables: No person shall be permitted to keep, have, exercise or
maintain any card table, dice, bagatelle or pigeonhole table, faro bank, or any
kind of gambling device at which or on which any game of chance is played for
any valuable thing, within the village, or the representative of any valuable
thing. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 7)
6-1-15: GETTING UPON VEHICLES:
No person shall get into or upon any wagon, carriage, sleigh or other vehicle
without the consent of the owner, nor shall otherwise in any way purposely
annoy or molest any person; and no person shall get upon or hold on to any car
or engine or tender while the same is in motion on any railroad in the village,
unless such person be in the employ of such railroad or a passenger thereon, or
has been invited to get thereon by some employee of such road. (R.O. 1908, Ord.
11)
6-1-16: HINDERING OFFICERS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to wilfully delay, hinder or obstruct any
officer of the village, or any person aiding such officer, in the discharge of
any official duty, or to aid, abet or encourage any other person to perform any
of the acts above mentioned, or to neglect or refuse to obey any of the acts
above mentioned or to neglect or refuse to obey any lawful order or directions
of said officer. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-17: HOUSE OF ILL FAME:
   (A)   Maintaining House: It shall be unlawful for any person to be guilty of
keeping, maintaining or contributing directly or indirectly to the support of
any house of ill fame or house of assignation, or place used for the practice
of fornication or adultery within the village.
   (B)   Allow Use of Premises: It shall be unlawful for any person to
knowingly suffer or permit any premises occupied by him, or under his control,
within the Village, to be used as a house of ill-fame, or as a house of
assignation, or as a place for the practice of fornication or adultery.
   (C)   Inmates: It shall be unlawful for any person to be an occupant or
inmate of any house of ill-fame, or house of assignation, or any place used for
the practice of fornication or adultery within the Village.
   (D)   Visitors: It shall be unlawful for any person to be found in any house
of ill-fame or assignation or in any place used for the practice of fornication
or adultery within the Village.
   (E)   Witness, Juror: No person shall be subject to any penalty whatever for
or on account of any admission, evidence or testimony which he may make or give
as a witness in any court concerning his being an occupant or inmate or of
being found in any house of ill-fame, or house of assignation, or gaming house,
or place used for the practice of fornication or adultery.
In all cases arising under any subsection hereof, no person shall be a
competent juror unless he shall be a citizen of this State and a resident of
Woodford County.
   (F)   Reputation: In any case arising under any of the subsections hereof,
the fact that any house is a house of ill-fame or house of assignation, or that
any place is used for the practice of fornication or adultery, shall be
sufficiently proven by evidence that such is the general reputation of the
same. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 10)
   (G)   Right of Entry: The proper law enforcing officer is hereby authorized
to enter any house of ill-fame or house of assignation, or any place used for
the practice of fornication or adultery within the Village and to enter all
parts of the same at any time in the day or night by breaking inside doors, and
to arrest all the occupants or inmates thereof, and every person who shall be
found therein with or without process and detain them until they can be brought
before some competent court for trial. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 10; amd. Ord. 79-3, 5-
7-79, eff. 5-8-79 at 6:00 A.M.)
6-1-18: INJURING PROPERTY:
   (A)   Injure Electric Light Property: It shall be unlawful for any person to
wilfully or intentionally injure, remove, deface or in any way damage any
electric lamp, wire, pole or any article or thing belonging thereto, or any
other street lamps.
      The parents or guardian of any minor offender against the provisions of
this subsection shall be held liable for all damages sustained by reason of
such offending and costs of prosecution.
      All fines collected under the provisions of this subsection, after paying
for the property damaged or destroyed in violation of the same, shall be turned
into the Village Treasury. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 16)
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person in the Village to be guilty of
defacing any building or buildings, fence, sign, tree, box, lamppost or other
property belonging to the Municipal corporation or any private corporation or
person, by cutting, breaking, daubing with paint or other substance, or by
hitching horses or other animals to, or to in any other manner deface, tear
down, injure or destroy the same.
6-1-19: KILLING, INJURING CERTAIN ANIMALS:
   (A)   Birds: It shall be unlawful for any person within the Village to
shoot, injure or capture any bird, or to intentionally destroy or injure the
nest eggs of any bird. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
   (B)   Squirrels: No squirrel or squirrels shall be killed within the Village
at any season of the year. (Ord. 50, 8-3-08)
6-1-20: LEWDNESS:
   (A)   Indecent Language: It shall be unlawful for any person to use any
indecent, profane, vulgar or obscene language in any public place.
   (B)   Indecent Exposure: It shall be unlawful for any person to publicly,
purposely, make an indecent exposure of his or her person, or appear in any
indecent or lewd dress, or in a state of nudity, or to be guilty of any other
lewd or indecent act or behavior.
   (C)   Indecent Books, Statues: It shall be unlawful for any person to
exhibit, sell or offer to sell, any indecent, obscene or lewd book, picture,
statue or other like thing, or to exhibit or perform any indecent, lewd or
obscene play, exhibition or other representation.
   (D)   Obscene Markings: It shall be unlawful for any person, in any place
open to the public view, to write, mark, draw, cut or make any obscene, lewd or
indecent word, sentence, design or figure. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 10)
6-1-21: LOITERING:
All persons who shall loiter about any street corner or in the vicinity of any
church, place of amusement, hotel or other public place or about or in the
entrance leading to any public hall or building or any business house, thereby
obstructing any sidewalk or street or interfering with the public convenience
and who shall refuse or neglect to disperse when requested by any Village
officer, or the owner or occupant of the building or buildings adjacent, or
their agents, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11;
amd. 1974 Code)
6-1-22: NOISE DISTURBANCE:
   (A)   Definitions:
 
              Additional evidence of a different person or character to the
              same point. A complaint is said to be corroborated when it is
CORROBORATED: shown to correspond with the representation of another witness or
              to comport with some fact otherwise known or established related
              to the violation.
              Any sound made or caused to be made by a person or by an animal,
NOISE:        vehicle, mechanical device, or contrivance under a person's
              control.
 
   (B)   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to emit or cause to be
emitted any noise in any manner that is unreasonably loud, unnecessary, and
disturbing or annoying.
   (C)   Interpretation: For the purposes of this section, noises occurring
between the hours of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. are
more unreasonable, disturbing, and unnecessary than noises occurring between
seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. However, during
community events held in the Village, including swim meets and sporting events
held by community youth programs and festivities and firework shows held as
part of the 4th of July celebration, the nighttime hour shall be extended later
until the conclusion of that community event for sounds and noises created by
the particular community event. Additionally, repetitious sounds are more
unreasonable, disturbing, and unnecessary than intermittent sounds.
   (D)   First Complaint: Upon receipt of a complaint or observation of a
violation of this section, the person shall be notified of the violation and
served with a written copy of this section, and a record of such service shall
be maintained by village officials or the village's law enforcement agency.
This service may be obtained by personal service or by certified or registered
mail. If the person cannot be served or refuses service after a reasonable
attempt to do so, service can be obtained by regular mail or by posting the
violation notice and copy of this section on the front door of the person's
residence or building located on the property on which the violation has
occurred.
   (E)   Subsequent Violation: If, at any time within twelve (12) months of the
service described above, another such violation occurs and is complained of and
corroborated, the person may be issued a citation charging a violation of this
section. However, if a law enforcement officer witnesses or observes the
subsequent violation, such violation need not be complained of or corroborated
by another person. Additional notice shall not be required at any time during
the twelve (12) month period following the initial notice in order for a
subsequent violation or violations of this section to occur.
   (F)   Penalty: A person violating this section shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each such offense. A person violating this section within twelve (12) months of
the first violation shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense. The
chairperson of the village's ordinance committee shall be permitted to issue
administrative citations for violations of this section under section
1-4-13 of this code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each date
upon which a violation occurs. (Ord. 2005-06, 8-1-2005; amd. Ord. 2019-08, 8-
19-2019)
6-1-23: PERSONATING AN OFFICER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely represent himself to be an
officer of the village or to, without authority, exercise or attempt to
exercise any of the powers and duties of any village officer. (R.O. 1908, Ord.
11; amd. Ord. 79-3, 5-7-1979, eff. 5-8-1979)
6-1-24: PLAYING BALL IN STREETS:
No person shall throw or strike any baseball or missile of any kind in or about
the streets or alleys of the village, or shall play baseball or shinny or other
similar games, or shoot with bow and arrows, or rubber shooter, in or near any
street, alley or avenue of the village, or shall throw any snowball or other
missile, to the annoyance of any person in the village. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-25: SPRING OR AIR GUN, DISCHARGING:
It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to discharge any spring or
air gun of any kind. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 34)
It shall also be unlawful for any person on Sunday to disturb the peace or vex
or annoy any person or family or any religious assemblage. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 14)
6-1-26: THROWING MISSILES:
No person shall purposely or heedlessly cast or throw any stone or other
missile from or into any public place or at any person. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-27: UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLAGES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly suffer or permit any
assemblage for the purpose of disturbance of the peace or of committing any
unlawful act or breach of the peace or any riotous, offensive, tumultuous or
disorderly conduct, in or upon any premises owned or occupied by him or under
his control. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-28: VAGRANCY:
Any person able to work and maintain himself in any legitimate calling or
business, not having any visible means of support, who idly without employment,
loiters or strolls about idly, begging or frequenting gambling houses,
disorderly or bawdy houses or places where intoxicating liquors are sold, or
who shall otherwise lead an idle or dissolute course of life, or any person who
shall have in his possession any instrument used for counterfeiting or the
commission of a burglary, or for picking locks or pockets or other implement or
device used by cheats and swindlers without being able to give a good and
satisfactory account of his possession of the same or who shall trespass upon
private property in the nighttime or habitually sleeps in sheds or stables,
outhouses, barns, unoccupied dwelling houses or in the open air, without being
able to give a satisfactory account of himself and all habitual night walkers
or persons strolling or walking about the streets at late or unusual hours of
the night without being able to give a satisfactory account of themselves,
shall be deemed vagrants. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 11)
6-1-29: PENALTIES:
Any violation of this chapter, as amended from time to time, shall be a
misdemeanor and shall be punishable by fine or public service as set forth in
title 1, chapter 4 of this code as amended from time to time, by imprisonment
not to exceed six (6) months as authorized by the Illinois municipal code, or
by any combination of fine, public service, and imprisonment. (Ord. 2002-04, 3-
4-2002)
6-1-30: TRESPASSING:
   (A)   Village Lagoon:
      1.   There will be no trespassing at the village lagoon or any property
immediately confined by the fence around the village lagoon.
      2.   Appropriate signs stating "No Trespassing" will be placed in
locations around the lagoon in such a manner as to be immediately visible to
all the public.
      3.   Any disrepair or holes in the fence surrounding the lagoon and
barring access will be immediately repaired upon passage of this subsection
(A).
      4.   The fine for violating this trespassing ordinance will be fifty
dollars ($50.00) per offense. (Ord. 1991-7, 7-1-1991)
6-1-31: CURFEW:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any minor person under seventeen (17) years
of age to be present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or
highway at the following times unless accompanied or supervised by a parent,
legal guardian, or other responsible companion at least eighteen (18) years of
age approved by a parent or legal guardian, or unless engaged in a business or
occupation which the laws of the state of Illinois authorize a person of less
than seventeen (17) years of age to perform:
      1.   Between one minute past twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. Saturday;
      2.   Between one minute past twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. Sunday; and
      3.   Between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on Sunday to Thursday,
inclusive, and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. on the following day.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any parent, legal guardian, or other person
to knowingly permit any person in his custody or control to violate subsection
(A) of this section.
   (C)   A person convicted of a violation of any provisions of this section
shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00). If an administrative citation is issued under the
administrative enforcement provisions set forth in section
1-4-13 of this code for a violation of this section, the administrative
enforcement citation shall impose a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
violation of this section to be paid to the village of Roanoke. (Ord. 2003-10,
9-2-2003, eff. 10-3-2003)
6-1-32: USE OF SKATEBOARDS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or otherwise use a
skateboard on any public sidewalk or street located in the "restricted area",
as defined in subsection (B) of this section, in the village of Roanoke.
   (B)   For the purposes of this section, the "restricted area" is defined as
the area lying between the following streets in the village, including the duly
designated streets: (east of) Jefferson Street, (south of) Ann Street, (west
of) State Street, and (north of) Front Street/Route 116.
   (C)   A person convicted of a violation of this section shall be fined not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00). If an administrative citation is issued under the administrative
enforcement provisions set forth in section
1-4-13 of this code for a violation of this section, the administrative
enforcement citation shall impose a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
violation of this section to be paid to the village of Roanoke. Multiple
violations of this section under the administrative provisions of section
1-4-13 of this code shall carry a fine as designated in section
1-4-13 of this code. (Ord. 2003-14, 10-20-2003)
6-1-33: POSSESSION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS BY MINORS:
   (A)   Definitions: The following definitions shall apply in the
interpretation and enforcement of this section:
   POSSESSION: To have upon one's person or have in close proximity to one's
person or in one's control.
   TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco (which means tobacco
in any form which is suitable for dipping and/or chewing) or tobacco in any
other form.
   (B)   Delivery And Possession Of Tobacco Products:
      1.   Delivery Of Tobacco Products To Minors: It shall be unlawful for any
person, whether acting individually or acting through an owner, officer,
employee or agent, to sell, give, distribute, furnish, or deliver any tobacco
products in any form to any person under the age of eighteen (18) years.
      2.   Possession Of Tobacco Products By A Minor: No person under eighteen
(18) years of age shall have in his or her possession any tobacco product in
any of its forms. It shall not be a violation of this section for any such
person to have tobacco products in his or her possession while in the presence
of his or her parents or legal guardian, or in the performance of a religious
ceremony or while participating in any theatrical performance where possession
of a tobacco product is necessary.
   (C)   Penalties:
      1.   Delivery To A Minor: A person convicted of a violation of subsection
(B)1 of this section shall have committed a petty offense and shall be fined
not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). If an administrative citation is issued under the
administrative enforcement provisions set forth in section
1-4-13 of this code for a violation of this section, the administrative
enforcement citation shall impose a fine of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for a
first offense, four hundred dollars ($400.00) for the second offense in a
twelve (12) month period, and six hundred dollars ($600.00) for the third or
any subsequent offense in a twelve (12) month period.
      2.   Possession By A Minor: A person convicted of a violation of
subsection (B)2 of this section shall have committed a petty offense and shall
be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than five hundred
dollars ($500.00). If an administrative citation is issued under the
administrative enforcement provisions set forth in section
1-4-13 of this code for a violation of this section, the administrative
enforcement citation shall impose a fine of seventy five dollars ($75.00) for
the violation of this section to be paid to the village of Roanoke. Multiple
violations of this section under the administrative provisions of section
1-4-13 of this code shall carry a fine as designated in section
1-4-13 of this code.
      3.   Enhanced Penalty For Violations On School Grounds And Parks: If a
person is convicted of a violation of subsection (B)2 of this section while the
person is on the grounds or facilities comprising a park or school (including
school buses), or is within two hundred fifty feet (250') of such school or
park grounds, the person shall have committed a petty offense and shall be
fined not less than one hundred twenty five dollars ($125.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). If an administrative citation is issued
under the administrative enforcement provisions set forth in section
1-4-13 of this code for a violation of this section, the administrative
enforcement citation shall impose a fine of one hundred twenty five dollars
($125.00) for the violation of this section to be paid to the village of
Roanoke. Multiple violations of this section under the administrative
provisions of section
1-4-13 of this code shall carry a fine as designated in section
1-4-13 of this code. (Ord. 2006-08, 11-6-2006)
6-1-34: DUMPING ON VILLAGE PROPERTY:
   (A)   Dumping Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage,
refuse, ashes, or any unwanted item or unwanted material on any village
property or in any village receptacle at any time unless such person or entity
has express prior consent from the village to dump or place garbage, refuse,
ashes, or any unwanted item or unwanted materials on village property or in a
village receptacle.
   (B)   Recycling Receptacles: It shall be unlawful to dump or place any non-
recyclable items or materials, including garbage or refuse, in or adjacent to a
village recycling receptacle located on village property or the village right-
of-way or on the village property, village street, or village right-of-way
adjacent to or near the village recycling receptable. The village may use a
security camera or other electronic system to monitor the area around the
village recycling receptacle that records video or photographic evidence of
violations of this provision of section
6-1-34 of the village code. A “village recycling receptable” as used in this
section
6-1-34 of the village code includes a recycling receptacle owned or leased by
the village or placed on village property at the village’s request through a
contract for recycling or other village authorization.
   (C)   Signage: The Village shall post signage on or near village property or
village receptacles in a location that provides reasonable notice and warning
to violators and potential violators that dumping is prohibited on the property
or in the receptacle and that a minimum fine of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) will be imposed for any violations of this “no dumping" provision.
Further, if a video or electronic surveillance system is being used under
subpart (B) of this section
6-1-34 of the village code, the signage must also provide reasonable notice and
warning to violators that a video or other electronic surveillance system is
being used to monitor the area around the village recycling receptacle.
However, the violator's lack of knowledge or viewing of such signage shall not
be a defense to committing a violation of this section.
   (D)   Penalty: A person or entity violating this section shall be fined not
less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each such offense. A person
violating this section within twelve (12) months of the first violation shall
be fined not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a second offense and
not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each subsequent offense
in the twelve (12) month period. The chairperson of the village's ordinance
committee or any law enforcement officer shall be permitted to issue
administrative citations for violations of this section under section
1-4-13 of this code with a fine in the amount as set forth in this subpart (D)
of this section
6-1-34 of the village code as the minimum fine for the violation. A separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each date upon which a violation occurs.
In addition to any fine imposed for a violation of this section of the Village
Code, a person convicted of a violation of this section shall be required to
reimburse the Village for the reasonable cost of removal and disposal of the
garbage, refuse, ashes, unwanted item, or unwanted material dumped or placed on
village property or in a village receptacle in violation of this section. (Ord.
2020-05, 4-20-2020; amd. Ord. 2020-07, 6-1-2020; Ord. 2024-05, 7-15-2024)
CHAPTER 2
ANIMALS; FOWL
(Rep. by Ord. 1985-6, 10-7-1985)
CHAPTER 3
DOGS, CATS AND ANIMALS
SECTION:
6-3-1: Definition
6-3-2: Vaccination Against Rabies
6-3-3: Running At Large
6-3-4: Impounding And Destroying
6-3-5: Animals Creating A Disturbance
6-3-6: Dangerous, Mischievous Animals
6-3-7: Deliberate Violation For Purpose Of Impoundment
6-3-8: Vicious Dogs
6-3-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this chapter, the word "dog" shall be construed to include
animals of every kind and description of the canine species whatsoever from and
over three (3) months of age, and shall also include the female as well as the
male. For the purpose of this chapter, the word "cat" shall be construed to
include animals of every kind and description of the feline species whatsoever
from and over three (3) months of age and shall also include the female as well
as the male. The word "animal" used in this chapter shall include any other two
(2) or four (4) legged animal. (Ord. 1985-6, 10-7-1985)
6-3-2: VACCINATION AGAINST RABIES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep, maintain or harbor a
dog, cat or other animal requiring rabies vaccination within the village
without first having said dog, cat or other animal vaccinated by a licensed
veterinarian against rabies, and it shall be the duty of every such person
owning, having charge of or control of any dog, cat or other animal requiring
rabies vaccination to have said dog, cat or other animal vaccinated against
rabies annually thereafter.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of every licensed veterinarian vaccinating a dog,
cat or other animal requiring rabies vaccination against rabies to issue a
certificate showing the date of such vaccination, a description of the dog, cat
or other animal requiring rabies vaccination, and the name and address of the
owner thereof. Such certificates shall be in triplicate and be numbered in the
order issued. One copy of such certificate shall be retained by the
veterinarian, and two (2) copies shall be delivered to the owner. One copy of
said certificate shall be filed by the owner of the dog, cat or other animal
requiring rabies vaccination at the time said dog, cat or other animal is
registered and the other copy shall be retained by the owner of the dog, cat or
other animal. (Ord. 1985-6, 10-7-1985)
6-3-3: RUNNING AT LARGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person keeping, maintaining or harboring a dog,
cat or any other animal to allow said dog, cat or other animal to run at large
at any time beyond the limits of the land of its owner, and upon the streets,
sidewalks or other public or private property. For the purpose of this section,
a dog, cat or other animal shall be considered not to be at large whenever said
dog, cat or other animal is under the control of a person by means of a leash,
chain, cord or rope of not more than ten feet (10') in length and of sufficient
strength to control said dog, cat or other animal. (Ord. 1985-6, 10-7-1985)
6-3-4: IMPOUNDING AND DESTROYING 1 :
Any dog, cat or other animal found in the village in violation of any provision
of this chapter shall be impounded by the animal control officer or anyone else
authorized by the president and board of trustees to perform such duties, and
placed or kept in a suitable place. The animal control officer or any police
officer or anyone else properly delegated by the village, may, following the
impounding of such dog, cat or other animal, notify the owner of the dog, cat
or other animal, or if the owner of the dog, cat or other animal is unknown,
said individual shall post written notices in at least three (3) public places
in the village describing the dog, cat or other animal and the place and time
of taking of said dog, cat or other animal. Unless the dog, cat or other animal
is redeemed and all charges paid, and the dog, cat or other animal is
registered and vaccinated as herein required, said dog, cat or other animal may
be sold or destroyed in the most humane manner possible after the expiration of
seven (7) days from the time said dog, cat or other animal is impounded or the
posting of notices aforesaid; provided, however, that any dog, cat or other
animal which appears to be suffering from rabies or affected with hydrophobia,
mange or other infectious, contagious or dangerous disease shall not be
released, but may be destroyed forthwith. Additionally, any animal impounded
under the terms of this provision, shall not be released until all fines and
other sums have been paid to the person designated to receive such sums by the
president and board of trustees of the village.
If a person claims an animal, be it a dog, cat or other animal, which has been
confined pursuant to the terms of this section, said person, shall be
responsible for all expenses for boarding as well as any vaccination or medical
treatment that is necessary for that animal, dog or cat. This applies to all
animals picked up pursuant to the terms of this section. The fine for the
violation of any provision of this chapter shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00)
for the first offense and twenty five dollars ($25.00) for the second offense
and every offense thereafter. (Ord. 1985-6, 10-7-1985)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  6-3-8 of this chapter.
6-3-5: ANIMALS CREATING A DISTURBANCE:
   (A)   Definitions:
   ANIMAL: Any and all types of animals, both domesticated and wild, male and
female, singular and plural.
   CORROBORATED: Additional evidence of a different person or character to the
same point. A complaint is said to be corroborated when it is shown to
correspond with the representation of another witness or to comport with some
fact otherwise known or established related to the violation.
   OWNER OR KEEPER: Any person having a right of property in an animal, or who
has it in his care or control, or who knowingly permits such animal to remain
on property owned or controlled by him. If such animal is licensed, the person
last issued such license shall be presumed to be the owner of the animal and,
for the purposes of this section, if such person is a minor then the parent or
guardian with whom the child resides shall be considered to be the "owner or
keeper".
   (B)   Prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to be the owner or
keeper of any animal or animals which emit noises in such a manner that is
unreasonably loud, unnecessary, and disturbing or annoying.
   (C)   Interpretation: For the purposes of this section, noises occurring
between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
are more unreasonable, disturbing, and unnecessary than noises occurring
between seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. Additionally,
repetitious sounds are more unreasonable, disturbing, and unnecessary than
intermittent sounds.
   (D)   First Complaint: Upon receipt of a complaint or observation of a
violation of this section, the owner or keeper of the animal or animals shall
be notified of the violation and served with a written copy of this section,
and a record of such service shall be maintained by village officials or the
village's law enforcement agency. This service may be obtained by personal
service or by certified or registered mail. If the person cannot be served or
refuses service after a reasonable attempt to do so, service can be obtained by
regular mail or by posting the violation notice and copy of this section on the
front door of the person's residence or building located on the property on
which the violation has occurred.
   (E)   Subsequent Violation: If, at any time within twelve (12) months of the
service described above, another such violation occurs and is complained of and
corroborated, the person may be issued a citation charging a violation of this
section. However, if a law enforcement officer witnesses or observes the
subsequent violation, such violation need not be complained of or corroborated
by another person. Additional notice shall not be required at any time during
the twelve (12) month period following the initial notice in order for a
subsequent violation or violations of this section to occur.
   (F)   Penalty: A person violating this section shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each such offense. A person violating this section within twelve (12) months of
the first violation shall be fined not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such offense. The
chairperson of the village's ordinance committee shall be permitted to issue
administrative citations for violations of this section under section
1-4-13 of this code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each date
upon which a violation occurs. (Ord. 2005-06, 8-1-2005)
6-3-6: DANGEROUS, MISCHIEVOUS ANIMALS:
Whoever knowingly suffers or permits any dangerous, unruly, or mischievous
animal owned or kept by him to go at large in the village to the danger,
annoyance, or damage of any person within the village shall be subject to a
penalty of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first offense, and not less than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
subsequent offense. (Ord. 2005-06, 8-1-2005)
6-3-7: DELIBERATE VIOLATION FOR PURPOSE OF IMPOUNDMENT:
Whoever wilfully drives or entices any animal from beyond the inhabited part of
the village into the inhabited part of the village, or aids or abets the same,
or lets any animal out of any enclosure in which it may be confined, or aids or
abets in the letting out or escape thereof, in order to take up or impound the
same shall be subject to a penalty of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) in each case. (Ord.
2005-06, 8-1-2005)
6-3-8: VICIOUS DOGS:
   (A)   Definition Of Vicious Dog: For the purposes of this chapter, "vicious
dog" is defined as:
      1.   Any individual dog that, without provocation, bites or attacks a
human being or domestic animal either on public or private property; or
      2.   Any individual dog that has a known propensity, tendency or
disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury, or to otherwise
endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals; or
      3.   Any individual dog that is owned or harbored primarily or in part
for the purpose of dogfighting or is trained for dogfighting; or
