      4.   Any individual dog that has, upon two (2) separate occasions, when
either unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended by its owner or a member of its
owner's family, in a vicious or terrorizing manner, approached any person in an
apparent attitude of attack upon streets, sidewalks, any public grounds or
places, or private property not owned or controlled by the owner.
      5.   No dog shall be deemed "vicious" if it bites, attacks, or menaces a
trespasser on the property of its owner, anyone assaulting its owner, anyone
who has tormented or abused the dog or its offspring, or is a professionally
trained dog used for law enforcement or guard duties.
   (B)   Definition Of Owner: For the purposes of this chapter, "owner" is
defined as any person having a right of property in an animal, or who keeps or
harbors an animal, or who has it in his care, or acts as its custodian.
   (C)   Possession Illegal: It shall be unlawful for any person to keep,
harbor, or in any way possess within the corporate limits of the village a
vicious dog, unless the dog is spayed or neutered, and unless the dog is
licensed and confined as provided by this chapter.
   (D)   Identification Of Vicious Dogs: Any law enforcement officer or animal
control officer employed by or under contract with the village or Woodford
County who suspects that a dog may be vicious within the meaning of this
section may conduct an investigation to determine whether or not the dog has
committed any act or displays any characteristics which qualify it as a vicious
dog. If upon the completion of such investigation the officer concludes that
the dog is a vicious dog, such officer shall issue a written notice of
determination which includes at least the following:
      1.   A description of the dog;
      2.   Information available concerning the ownership of the dog;
      3.   A statement or conclusion that the dog is a vicious dog within the
meaning of this section;
      4.   A description of the acts or characteristics which led the officer
to conclude that the dog is a vicious dog;
      5.   Notice to the owner that the vicious dog must be licensed and
confined in accordance with the requirements of this chapter;
      6.   Notice that the owner may appeal the determination of the officer to
the village president within seven (7) working days after the determination is
served upon the owner.
This notice of determination shall be served on the owner by certified mail
from the village clerk or the "code official" (as designated in section
7-4-13 of this code) to the last known address of the owner or by personal
service from the officer or any person authorized by law to make personal
service. If the owner cannot be served or refuses service after a reasonable
attempt to do so, service can be obtained by regular mail or by posting the
notice of determination on the front door of the owner's residence.
   (E)   Appeal Of A Determination That A Dog Is A Vicious Dog:
      1.   The owner may appeal the determination that the owner's dog is a
vicious dog. An appeal must be in writing and directed to the village
president, and it must be filed by the owner with the village clerk at the
village hall within seven (7) days after receipt of the notice of determination
which identifies the dog as a vicious dog. Should the owner fail to appeal the
determination within seven (7) days, the determination of the investigating
officer that the dog is a vicious dog shall become final. Upon receipt of an
appeal, the village president, or such person as the village president may
designate to act on the village president's behalf, shall convene a hearing for
the purpose of determining whether the dog in question is a vicious dog.
      2.   The hearing shall be held within no less than five (5) nor more than
ten (10) business days after the village president or his designee provides
written notice of the time, date and location of the hearing upon the owner at
the owner's last known address. The hearing shall be conducted informally and
shall remain open to the public. At the hearing, the owner shall have the
opportunity to present evidence to explain why the dog should not be declared a
vicious dog. The owner shall have the right to be represented by legal counsel
at the owner's expense. The officer who made the initial determination that the
dog is vicious, and any other persons having knowledge of the facts and
circumstances, may be heard by the village president or his designee. All
witnesses at the hearing shall be subject to cross examination by the owner,
village representatives, or either party's attorney. If an appeal has been
properly requested, the village president or his designee shall hold this
hearing and decide all issues related to the appeal regardless of whether the
owner appears at the hearing. Evidence regarding the determination of whether a
dog is a vicious dog may include any acts or incidents involving the dog after
the events that lead to the issuance of the notice of determination up to the
time of the hearing.
      3.   Within five (5) business days after the conclusion of the hearing,
the village president or his designee shall determine whether or not the dog is
a vicious dog within the meaning of this section. The village president or his
designee shall notify the owner in writing of its determination. The decision
of the village president or his designee shall be final.
      4.   If any officer of the village, including a law enforcement officer
or an animal control officer, determines that the public safety requires the
immediate impoundment of a dog as authorized by this section, the officer shall
within a reasonable time notify the owner of the facts and circumstances
relating to the impoundment. Upon receipt of such notification, the owner may
appeal the determination of the officer to the village president or his
designee in accordance with the procedures established hereinabove for the
identification of vicious dogs.
   (F)   Licensing Of Vicious Dogs:
      1.   No person shall possess any vicious dog within village limits
without having first obtained a license for the vicious dog from the village.
However, an owner may continue to possess a vicious dog without a license: a)
during the forty eight (48) hour period after the final determination has been
made that the dog is a vicious dog, and b) during the license application
process described in this subsection (F).
      2.   An application for a license to possess a vicious dog shall be filed
with the village clerk on a form prescribed and provided by the village and
shall be accompanied by all of the following:
         (a)   Verification of the identity of the owner and current address by
providing a photocopy of the owner's driver's license or state identification
card.
         (b)   Proof of ownership of the vicious dog.
         (c)   A copy of the current immunization and health record of the
vicious dog, including certification that the dog has received a rabies vaccine
and that the dog has been spayed or neutered, prepared by a veterinarian
licensed to practice in the state of Illinois.
         (d)   A certificate of insurance evidencing coverage in an amount not
less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), insuring said owner against any
claim, loss, damage or injury to persons, domestic animals, or property
resulting from the acts, whether intentional or unintentional, of the vicious
dog.
         (e)   Two (2) photographs of the vicious dog to be licensed taken not
less than one month before the date of the application. One photograph shall
provide a front view of the vicious dog and shall clearly show the face and
ears of the vicious dog. One photograph shall show a side view of the vicious
dog.
         (f)   A license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00).
         (g)   A license granted under this subsection (F) for a vicious dog
shall be nontransferable. Any change of owner shall require a new license for
the vicious dog.
      3.   Upon receipt of an application, village officials shall cause an
inspection of the premises on which the vicious dog shall be kept to determine
that all provisions of this section relating to confinement and posting of
signs have been complied with by the applicant. Upon completion of the
inspection, the village clerk shall be notified of the results of the
inspection.
      4.   Based upon the results of the inspection, the village clerk shall
notify the applicant of the approval or denial of the license. In the event
that the license is denied, the notification shall be provided in writing and
the reasons for such denial shall be stated. Upon denial, the owner of the
vicious dog shall remove the vicious dog from the corporate limits of the
village within forty eight (48) hours. Upon approval, the clerk shall issue a
license to the applicant.
   (G)   Reporting Requirements Of License: Any person holding a license
pursuant to this section shall report to the village's law enforcement agency
the incidence of any of the following events as provided herein:
      1.   The sale, barter, exchange, gift or death of any vicious dog shall
be reported to the village clerk within forty eight (48) hours.
      2.   The escape from confinement of any vicious dog shall be reported to
the village's law enforcement agency upon discovery of the escape.
      3.   The biting or nipping of any person or animal by a vicious dog shall
be reported to the village's law enforcement agency upon occurrence.
      4.   The birth of any offspring of a vicious dog shall be reported to the
village clerk within forty eight (48) hours of the birth of the offspring. The
license shall be immediately revoked until proof is provided that the vicious
dog has been spayed or neutered.
      5.   The permanent removal of any vicious dog from the corporate limits
of the village shall be reported within forty eight (48) hours of such removal
by surrender of the license of the owner to the clerk of the village.
Except as otherwise provided in this section, the failure to report of any
incident required to be reported under this subsection shall be a violation of
this section.
   (H)   Revocation Of License: A license granted pursuant to this section
shall be automatically revoked upon the second violation by the licensee of any
provision of this section. In the event of a revocation of the license, the
license fee shall be retained by the village and the vicious dog must be
removed from the village within forty eight (48) hours.
   (I)   Confinement Of Vicious Dogs: No person shall possess any vicious dog
unless the vicious dog is confined in accordance with this section. No vicious
dog may be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure that
would allow the vicious dog to exit the structure on its own volition. No
vicious dog shall be kept in a house or structure when the windows are open or
when screen windows or screen doors are the only obstacle preventing the
vicious dog from exiting the structure. The owner of a vicious dog shall keep
the dog securely confined at all times in a locked pen, locked fenced yard, or
other locked enclosure while on the premises of the owner. The owner shall
display in a conspicuous manner, a sign on his or her premises warning that
there is a vicious dog on the premises. This sign shall be visible and legible
from the road. When the vicious dog is off such premises, the owner shall keep
the dog:
      1.   On a leash or tether not more than five feet (5') long having a
minimum tensile strength of at least three hundred (300) pounds; or
      2.   In a locked pen, or other locked enclosure (i.e., car or truck).
   (J)   Impoundment Of Dogs: A dog shall be impounded for any grounds
enumerated in this subsection by any law enforcement officer or animal control
officer employed by or under contract with the village or Woodford County;
provided, however, that if any law enforcement officer or animal control
officer reasonably believes that such dog poses an immediate threat of severe
injury to any person or domestic animal, such officials are authorized to kill
such dog. Grounds for impoundment include:
      1.   The dog has previously been determined to be a "vicious dog"; and
         (a)   The vicious dog is not confined as provided by subsection (I) of
this section or is running at large; or
         (b)   The owner of a vicious dog has not obtained or applied for a
license within forty eight (48) hours of any determination under this section
that the dog is a vicious dog.
      2.   Whether or not the dog was previously determined to be a vicious
dog:
         (a)   Without provocation, the dog has attacked, bitten or killed a
domestic animal; or
         (b)   The dog was used or possessed for the purposes of dogfighting;
or
         (c)   Without provocation, the dog has attacked, bitten, or killed a
person.
Upon impoundment of a dog, the owner of the dog shall be served notice of
impoundment in the same manner as provided in subsection (D) of this section.
The notice will state whether the dog is subject to redemption or destruction.
The notice will state that all dogs subject to redemption and not redeemed
within fourteen (14) days are subject to destruction. If the dog is not subject
to redemption, the notice shall state that appeal or review of the proposed
destruction must be sought in the circuit court of Woodford County within
fourteen (14) days of receipt of the notice. If the dog is subject to
redemption, but the dog has not been previously determined to be a vicious dog,
notice shall also be given pursuant to subsection (D) of this section that the
dog has been determined to be a vicious dog. If the owner of a dog subject to
redemption appeals the determination that the dog is a vicious dog pursuant to
subsection (E) of this section, and the village president or his designee
determines that the dog is not a vicious dog, the dog shall be released to its
owner without cost, except that the cost of keeping the dog during impoundment
can be assessed to the owner of any dog, vicious or not, found running at
large. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to allow an owner to
appeal a determination that a dog is a vicious dog, if the dog was determined
to be vicious after a previous appeal, or if the owner previously failed to
file a timely appeal of a determination that the dog was a vicious dog.
   (K)   Redemption Of An Impounded Dog:
      1.   Unless a dog is ineligible for redemption under this subsection, an
owner of a vicious dog holding a license pursuant to this section may redeem an
impounded vicious dog subject to the following conditions:
         (a)   Proof of a valid license issued by the village under subsection
(F) of this section; and
         (b)   Payment of all costs of keeping the vicious dog during the
period of impoundment.
      2.   If the owner of a dog otherwise subject to redemption fails to
redeem the impounded dog within fourteen (14) days of receiving notice of
impoundment, the dog shall be subject to destruction, provided no dog otherwise
subject to redemption shall be destroyed pending appeal, pursuant to subsection
(E) of this section, of a determination that the dog is a vicious dog. Nothing
in this subsection shall be construed to allow an owner to appeal a
determination that a dog is a vicious dog, if the dog was determined to be
vicious after a previous appeal, or if the owner previously failed to file a
timely appeal of a determination that the dog was a vicious dog.
      3.   An impounded dog shall not be subject to redemption, but shall be
subject to humane destruction, if:
         (a)   Whether or not the dog had previously been determined to be a
vicious dog, the dog causes severe injury, disfigurement or death in an
unprovoked attack on a person; or
         (b)   Subsequent to having been determined, pursuant to this section,
to be a vicious dog, the vicious dog has, without provocation, attacked or
bitten a person on one or more occasions; or
         (c)   Subsequent to having been determined, pursuant to this section,
to be a vicious dog, the vicious dog has, without provocation, killed a
domestic animal on one or more occasions; or
         (d)   Whether or not the dog had previously been determined to be a
vicious dog, the dog was used, with the knowledge or consent of its owner, for
dogfighting.
   (L)   Destruction Of Dogs: A dog that has been impounded, and: 1) has not
been redeemed by its owner, or 2) is not subject to redemption, shall be
destroyed in a humane fashion, no sooner than fourteen (14) days after its
owner has received actual notice of impoundment, provided:
      1.   If the dog is otherwise subject to redemption, and the owner is
appealing, pursuant to subsection (E) of this section a determination that the
dog is a vicious dog, the dog shall not be destroyed pending the appeal and
pending the licensing of the dog, if the dog is determined, after appeal, to be
a vicious dog requiring licensing; or
      2.   An appeal or request for review filed by the owner in the circuit
court of Woodford County shall immediately stay destruction of a dog not
subject to redemption pending a final court order; or
      3.   The village board, for compelling reasons and in its sole
discretion, can require that the vicious dog be placed with any not for profit
or charitable "no kill" shelter or dog rescue organization, provided said
organization agrees that the vicious dog shall not be sold, bartered, made
available for adoption, released or bred.
   (M)   Costs Of Impoundment And Destruction: Except as otherwise provided in
subsection (J) of this section, the owner shall be liable for all costs of
keeping the dog during any period of impoundment (including any period during
which destruction was stayed pending judicial review), all costs for humane
destruction of the dog, and all costs for the disposal or burial of the dog.
Costs of keeping the dog during a period of impoundment include shelter, food,
veterinary expenses, and other expenses necessitated by the seizure of the dog
for the protection of the public.
   (N)   Penalties: Upon conviction of a violation of any provision of this
section, the court shall assess a fine of not less than two hundred dollars
($200.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). This penalty is
in addition to any other expenses that an owner may be required to pay under
this section for the impounding or destruction of a dog.
   (O)   Other Statutes And Ordinances: Nothing in this section shall limit the
authority of the village or law enforcement officials or animal control
officers to control, license, impound, or destroy dogs as otherwise provided by
any other ordinance or statute.
   (P)   Severability: If any subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this
section is, for any reason, held to be unconstitutional or invalid by a
decision of any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect
the validity of the remaining portions of this section. (Ord. 2006-09, 11-6-
2006)
CHAPTER 4
LITTERING
SECTION:
6-4-1: Scattering Litter
6-4-2: Attaching Advertising Matter to Fences or Posts
6-4-3: Deposit of Litter Within Village
6-4-4: Deposit of Litter on Private Property
6-4-1: SCATTERING LITTER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to scatter or throw upon the public
thoroughfares, any handbills, posters, advertisements or papers. Nothing herein
shall be construed to authorize any person to obstruct the public thoroughfares
or create any nuisance therein. These provisions shall not interfere or prevent
the posting of notices required by law to be posted.
6-4-2: ATTACHING ADVERTISING MATTER TO FENCES OR POSTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to post, paint, tack or otherwise attach
any notice or other advertising matter to any fence, wall or building or other
property until first obtaining the consent of the owner of such property. It
shall be unlawful for any person to post, paint, tack or otherwise attach any
notices or advertising matter to any telegraph, telephone, electric or such
other pole.
6-4-3: DEPOSIT OF LITTER WITHIN VILLAGE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep or deposit dirt, trash or other
litter into any street or onto any sidewalk within the Village. It shall be
unlawful for any person to scatter papers or other material detrimental to the
order of the Village in the public parks, streets or on any sidewalk.
6-4-4: DEPOSIT OF LITTER ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any litter on any private lot or
premises whether such lot is owned by said person or another. All trash or
litter shall be placed in approved receptacles. (Ord. 74-11, 12-16-74)
TITLE 7
HEALTH AND SANITATION
Health And Sanitation   1
Use Of Public Sewers   2
Industrial Wastes   3
Private Property Maintenance   4
Plants And Weeds   5
Air Pollution   6
Dangerous Or Unsafe Buildings   7
CHAPTER 1
HEALTH AND SANITATION
SECTION:
7-1-1: Disposal Of Dead Animals
7-1-2: Slaughterhouses
7-1-3: Render Lard
7-1-4: Sale Of Diseased Animals
7-1-5: Care Of Fresh Meat
7-1-6: Weeds, Rubbish Accumulation
7-1-1: DISPOSAL OF DEAD ANIMALS:
   (A)   Leaving Dead Animal On Property: It shall be unlawful for any person
to deposit, throw, discharge, place or leave the dead body of any animal or an
nauseous, foul, offensive or putrid liquid or other substance likely to become
offensive or injurious to the health or comfort of any person residing within
the village. (R.O. 1940, Ord. 8)
   (B)   Burial Of Dead Animals: It shall be unlawful for any person to bury or
cause to be buried any carcass of any animal anyplace within the village
limits, and any person so doing shall be deemed guilty of maintaining a
nuisance, shall be subject to penalty as provided for by section
1-4-1 of this code, and he shall immediately, upon such conviction, remove said
carcass from the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 98, 3-4-1918)
   (C)   Offensive Substances, Carcass: No person shall, in removing any dead
animal, excrement or other nauseous, offensive or putrid liquid or substance,
purposely or unnecessarily cause the same to be offensive or annoying to any
other person. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 8)
7-1-2: SLAUGHTERHOUSES:
Whenever within the village or within one-half (1/2) mile of the limits of the
same, any slaughterhouse or other building or enclosure used for the purpose of
slaughtering animals shall be or become foul or noisome so as to taint the air
within the village, the owner, keeper and user thereof shall be severally fined
as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. Should such slaughterhouse, building or enclosure so
continue foul and noisome for ten (10) days after the first conviction of
either owner, keeper or user, or upon the second conviction of either, then, in
either case, it shall be the duty of the proper law enforcing officer or the
street commissioner to notify such owner, keeper or user to forthwith remove
such slaughterhouse, building or enclosure and if said owner, keeper or user
shall not remove the same within three (3) days after such notification, then
the proper law enforcing officer or the street commissioner shall cause the
same to be removed and the costs of said removal may be recovered from such
owner, keeper or user or either of them by any appropriate action. (R.O. 1908,
Ord. 8; amd. Ord. 79-3, 5-7-1979, eff. 5-8-1979)
7-1-3: RENDER LARD:
No person shall, within the village, steam, boil or render any tainted lard,
tallow or fat or other animal substance so as to taint the air and render it
unwholesome or offensive. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 8)
7-1-4: SALE OF DISEASED ANIMALS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale any sick or
diseased animal, poultry or fish or the flesh of any sick, diseased or
otherwise unwholesome dead animal, poultry or fish or any unsound or
unwholesome provisions or articles to be used for food or any adulterated or
pernicious milk, drink or liquors. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 8)
7-1-5: CARE OF FRESH MEAT:
Any person hauling meat or in any way carrying the same from one point to
another within the village shall keep the same entirely covered with a
material, the texture of which shall be sufficiently close to prevent any and
all flies and other insects from reaching or resting upon the same and keep and
prevent any and all dust and dirt from coming in contact with such meat while
being so carried or hauled. It is further ordained that such said material
covering meat as herein provided shall at all times be kept clean and free from
any rend or tears and subject to the inspection of the board of health at any
reasonable hour. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 44)
7-1-6: WEEDS, RUBBISH ACCUMULATION:
It shall be unlawful for the owner, agent, lessee, tenant or occupant of any
lot or tract of land within the corporate boundaries of the village to allow or
permit any noxious plants, weeds, rubbish or other accumulation of noxious
vegetation to grow, accumulate or decay thereon. (Ord. 189, 10-5-1942)
Any person, whether as owner, agent, lessee, tenant or occupant as aforesaid
who violates this section shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance; and notice
shall be given to such person by the proper law enforcing officer to remove or
abate the same and, unless such nuisance be removed or abated within forty
eight (48) hours after such notice, the person guilty of maintaining such a
nuisance as aforesaid shall be subject to penalty as provided for by section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 189, 10-5-1942; amd. Ord. 79-3, 5-7-1979, eff. 5-8-
1979)
CHAPTER 2
USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS
SECTION:
7-2-1: Use Of Public Sewers Required
7-2-2: No Competing Sewer System
7-2-3: Building And Maintaining Sewers
7-2-4: Protection From Damage
7-2-5: Storm Water Drains
7-2-6: Violation
7-2-1: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit or permit to be deposited
in an unsanitary manner upon public or private property within the village, or
in any area under the jurisdiction of the village, any human or animal
excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.
It shall be unlawful to discharge into any natural outlet within the village,
or in any area under the jurisdiction of said village, any sanitary sewage,
commercial or industrial wastes or other polluted solids and liquids except
where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with subsequent
provisions of this chapter.
Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain
any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or
used for the disposal of sewage.
The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy,
employment, recreation or other purpose, situated within the village and
abutting on any street, alley or right of way in which there is now located or
may in the future be located a public sanitary sewer of the village, is hereby
required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to
connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance
with the provisions of this chapter, within forty five (45) days after the date
of official notice to do so, at which time billing will begin whether
connection is made or not, and provided that said public sewer is within one
hundred feet (100') of the property line. (Ord. 1967-6, 6-13-1967)
7-2-2: NO COMPETING SEWER SYSTEM:
In order to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the inhabitants of
the village, no other system of sanitary sewers may be constructed or operated
within the boundaries of the village. A "sanitary sewer system" is hereby
defined as a system serving two (2) or more individual users. (Ord. 1967-6, 6-
13-1967)
7-2-3: BUILDING AND MAINTAINING SEWERS:
   (A)   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or
opening into, use, alter or disturb any public sewer or appurtenances thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the village. There shall be two
(2) classes of building sewer permits:
      1.   For residential and commercial services, and
      2.   For service to establishments producing industrial waste.
In either case, the owner or his agent shall make application on a special form
furnished by the village. Permit applications shall be supplemented by any
plans, specifications or other information considered pertinent in the judgment
of the superintendent of the sewer system. A permit and inspection fee of
twenty dollars ($20.00) for a residential or commercial building sewer permit
shall be paid to the village treasurer at the time the application is filed.
   (B)   All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of
the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner or the personnel
installing the building sewer for said owner shall indemnify the village from
any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by said
installation. The owner installing said sewer system shall extend his sewer
line with the approval of the superintendent of the sewer system and at the
owner's own cost out to the village trunk sewer line. Under no occasion or
situation will the village be obligated to extend or maintain the sewer line
from the trunk to the property owner's property boundary at the cost of the
village. The village shall be responsible for maintaining a flow in the trunk
line between manholes; the property owner shall be responsible for maintaining
a flow between their property boundary and the trunk line.
   (C)   A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every
building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an
interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the
rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway, the building
sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the
whole considered as one building sewer. Other exceptions will be allowed only
by special permission granted by the superintendent of the sewer system.
   (D)   Old building sewers or portions thereof, may be used in connection
with the new buildings only when they are found on examination and test by the
superintendent of the sewer system to meet all requirements of this chapter.
   (E)   The building sewer and fittings shall be constructed of PVC SDR 26.
All sewers shall be laid on suitable improved bed or cradle as approved by the
superintendent of the sewer system.
   (F)   All joints and connections shall be made gastight and watertight. All
plumbing shall be done in accordance with and shall meet the requirements as
set forth by the current editions of the Illinois plumbing code and the
standard specifications for water and sewer main construction in Illinois
manuals.
   (G)   The size and slope of the building sewers shall be subject to the
approval of the superintendent of the sewer system, but in no event shall the
diameter be less than four inches (4"). The slope of such four inch (4") pipe
shall not be less than one-eighth inch (1/8") per foot. A slope of one-fourth
inch (1/4") per foot shall be used wherever practical.
   (H)   Whenever possible the building sewer shall be brought to the building
at an elevation below the basement floor. The depth shall be sufficient to
afford protection from frost. All excavations required for the installation of
a building sewer shall be open trench work unless otherwise approved by the
superintendent of the sewer system. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed
in accordance with ASTM specifications (designation 312) except that no
backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected by the
superintendent of the sewer system or his representative.
   (I)   In all the buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit
gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such drains shall
be lifted by approved artificial means and discharged to the building sewer. No
water operated sewage ejector shall be used.
   (J)   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall be
made at the "Y" branch designated for that property, if such branch is
available at a suitable location. Any connection not made at the designated "Y"
branch in the main sewer shall be made only as directed by the superintendent
of the sewer system.
   (K)   The applicant for the building sewer shall notify the superintendent
of the sewer system when the building sewer is ready for inspection and
connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the
supervision of the superintendent of the sewer system or his representative.
   (L)   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter, parkways, and other public property
disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory
to the village. All costs and expenses incident to the installation and
connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner.
   (M)   No one shall in any way excavate village property for any reason
without the specific written consent of the president of the village board, the
chairperson of the village's water and sewer committee, or the superintendent
of the sewer system. (Ord. 2004-13, 6-21-2004)
7-2-4: PROTECTION FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break,
damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or
equipment which is a part of the public sanitary sewerage system of the
village. Any person violating this provision shall be charged with the
commission of a misdemeanor and placed under arrest. (Ord. 1967-6, 6-13-1967)
7-2-5: STORM WATER DRAINS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect, or cause to be connected any
sanitary sewer or other tile or drain carrying, or to carry, any sewage or
matter other than unpolluted water to the storm water sewers of the village,
and it shall be unlawful to make or cause to be made any sanitary sewer
connection with lateral storm water sewers which may be connected with said
storm water sewers. (Ord. 178, 1-6-1941)
7-2-6: VIOLATION:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
charged with the commission of a misdemeanor, shall be subject to penalty as
provided for by section
1-4-1 of this code, and shall become liable to the village for any expense,
loss, or damage sustained by the village by reason of such violation. (Ord.
1967-6, 6-13-1967)
CHAPTER 3
INDUSTRIAL WASTES
SECTION:
7-3-1: Prohibited Discharge
7-3-2: Obstructing Flow Of Sewage Works
7-3-3: Preliminary Treatment Of Wastes
7-3-4: Control Manhole
7-3-5: Interceptors
7-3-1: PROHIBITED DISCHARGE:
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface
water, ground water, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, cooling water or
unpolluted industrial process waters into the sanitary sewer system. (Ord. 70-
5, 7-6-1970)
7-3-2: OBSTRUCTING FLOW OF SEWAGE WORKS:
No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged to any public sewer, any
harmful waters or wastes, whether liquid, solid or gas, capable of causing
obstruction to the flow of the sewage works, or other interference with the
proper operation of the sewage works. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
7-3-3: PRELIMINARY TREATMENT OF WASTES:
The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having harmful or
objectionable characteristics shall be subject to the review and approval of
the village board, who may prescribe limits on the strength and character of
these waters and wastes. Where necessary, in the opinion of the village board,
the owner shall provide at his expense, such preliminary treatment as may be
necessary to treat these wastes prior to discharge to the public sewer. Plans,
specifications and any other pertinent information relating to proposed
preliminary treatment facilities shall be submitted for the approval of the
village board and of the state board of health, and no construction of such
facilities shall be commenced until said approval is obtained in writing. Where
preliminary treatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastes, they
shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the
owner at his expense. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
7-3-4: CONTROL MANHOLE:
When required by the village board, the owner of any property served by a
building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install and maintain at his
expense a suitable control manhole in the building sewer to facilitate
observation sampling and measurement of the wastes. All measurements, tests and
analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes shall be determined in
accordance with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Sewage", and
shall be determined at the control manhole or upon suitable samples taken at
said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been required,
the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in
the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. (Ord.
70-5, 7-6-1970)
7-3-5: INTERCEPTORS:
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the
said inspector, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes
containing grease in excessive amount, or any flammable wastes, sand and other
harmful ingredients except that such interceptors shall not be required for
private living quarters or dwelling units. Where installed, they shall be
maintained by the owner, at his expense, in continuously efficient operation at
all times. (Ord. 70-5, 7-6-1970)
CHAPTER 4
PRIVATE PROPERTY MAINTENANCE
SECTION:
7-4-1: Definitions
7-4-2: Uncovered Garbage
7-4-3: Windblown Refuse
7-4-4: Deposits On Street
7-4-5: Consent Of Owner
7-4-6: Disposal
7-4-7: Garbage Collection By Village; Fee
7-4-8: Containers
7-4-9: Duty To Collect
7-4-10: Separation
7-4-11: Prima Facie Evidence
7-4-12: Notice Of Violations; Removal; Liens
7-4-13: BOCA Property Maintenance Code
7-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the words enumerated herein shall have the following
meanings:
   ASHES: Residue from fires used for cooking and for heating buildings.
   GARBAGE: Waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and
consumption of food; waste from the handling, storage and sale of produce.
   REFUSE: Combustible trash, including, but not limited to, paper cartons,
boxes, barrels, wood, excelsior, tree branches, yard trimmings, wood furniture,
bedding; noncombustible trash, including, but not limited to, metals, tin cans,
metal furniture, dirt, small quantities of rock and pieces of concrete, glass,
crockery, other mineral wastes; street rubbish, including, but not limited to,
street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catch basin dirt and contents of litter
receptacles. (Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-2: UNCOVERED GARBAGE:
It shall be unlawful to place or permit to remain anywhere in the village, any
garbage or other material subject to decay, other than leaves or grass,
excepting in a tightly covered container. (Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-3: WINDBLOWN REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful to cause or permit to accumulate any dust, ashes or trash
of such nature that it can be blown away by the wind, anywhere in the village.
(Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-4: DEPOSITS ON STREET:
It shall be unlawful to deposit or permit to fall from any vehicle, any
garbage, refuse or ashes on any public street or alley in the village; provided
that this section shall not be construed to prohibit placing garbage, refuse or
ashes in a container complying with the provisions of this chapter, preparatory
to having such material collected and disposed of in the manner provided
herein. (Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-5: CONSENT OF OWNER:
It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage, refuse or ashes on any
premises in the village without the consent of the owner of such premises.
(Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-6: DISPOSAL:
It shall be unlawful to dispose of any garbage, refuse or ashes anywhere in the
village except in a legally permitted incinerator or disposal device, properly
constructed and operated, or in a lawfully established garbage or landfill
site. (Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-7: GARBAGE COLLECTION BY VILLAGE; FEE:
   (A)   Weekly Collection: The collection of garbage, refuse and ashes shall
be available from the village for all premises at least once a week, provided
that the material is properly stored and set out for collection in a container
complying with the provisions of this chapter. Garbage pick up will be at the
curb or street line unless otherwise designated from time to time by the proper
village authorities.
   (B)   Fees: Effective June 1, 2007, there are hereby established the
following monthly fees for garbage collection services provided by the village:
 
Single-family residences          $ 5.00
Business and commercial pick ups  10.00
 
Business pick ups shall also include any dumpster pick up service at any site
in the village. Apartment units will be assessed a single-family residence fee
for each apartment unit.
   (C)   Collection Of Fee: The village collector shall have the duty to assess
and collect the garbage collection fee in conjunction with the collection of
charges for village water and sewer service. The garbage collection fee shall
be payable to the village monthly no later than the close of business on the
fifteenth day of the month immediately following the end of the monthly period
for which garbage collection service has been provided.
   (D)   Liability For Payment: The owner of the premises and the occupant
thereof shall be jointly and severally liable to pay the fee for the garbage
collection service for said premises. This service is provided to the premises
by the village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises and the
occupant are jointly and severally liable to the village for the payment of
this fee. The garbage collection fee shall run with the property and remain a
liability of the individuals aforementioned.
   (E)   Late Payments: If the fee for garbage collection service is not paid
within fifteen (15) days after the rendition of the bill for such service, then
a penalty of twenty percent (20%) of the amount of the bill shall be added
thereto. (Ord. 2007-05, 5-21-2007)
   (F)   Discontinue Service: If the fee for garbage collection service is not
paid within thirty (30) days after the rendition of the bill for such fee,
creating a delinquency, then a second notice will be sent and will serve as a
notice of delinquency to the owner of the premises as well as the tenant of the
property seven (7) days prior to the date scheduled for termination of
services, informing them of the delinquent amount. Said notice shall state that
garbage collection service will be discontinued seven (7) days from the date of
such notice. If the matter is not resolved to the satisfaction of the village
collector, or the delinquent bill remains unpaid, then the service to the
property will be discontinued on the termination date stated in the final
notice, being seven (7) days from the date of the delinquency notice. Upon
termination of garbage collection services, the owner or occupant of the
premises shall become responsible for removing garbage from such premises.
Garbage collection service shall not be reinstated until all past due bills,
penalties, and other charges are paid in full.
Should the charges for garbage collection service not be paid due to a check
returned by the bank for nonpayment for any reason, the village shall follow
the process set forth in subsection
 8-5-11(B) of this code for addressing the returned check and the resulting
nonpayment of the garbage collection service fee, which shall include the
village's authority to terminate garbage collection services as set forth in
subsection
8-5-11(B) of this code. (Ord. 2008-05, 9-15-2008)
7-4-8: CONTAINERS:
It shall be the duty of every owner or his agent or occupant of any house,
building, flat or apartment in the village where persons reside, board or
lodge, or where animal or vegetable food is prepared or served, or where
"garbage", as hereinbefore defined, is created, to provide for such house,
building, flat or apartment, and at all times to maintain in good order and
repair, containers of reasonable size and number so that all garbage and refuse
will not only fit in such containers, but, additionally, that the containers
can be sealed with lids after the garbage and refuse has been placed therein.
Plastic or polyethylene bags will be permissible for the convenience of the
residents located in residential areas only. However, the condition of said
bags shall be the prime responsibility of the resident and the village will not
be responsible for the collection of strewn garbage or litter from torn bags.
(Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-9: DUTY TO COLLECT:
The duties of collection and disposal of garbage, ashes and rubbish, together
with the regulations in regard thereto, be and are hereby assigned to the
street and alley committee in conjunction with the board of health of the
village of Roanoke. (Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-10: SEPARATION:
Refuse which is flammable shall not be mixed or mingled with refuse that is
nonflammable. (Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-11: PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE:
The fact that garbage, refuse or ashes remain on any occupant's premises in the
village in violation of this chapter shall be prima facie evidence that the
occupant of such premises is responsible for the violation of this chapter.
(Ord. 75-4, 5-5-1975)
7-4-12: NOTICE OF VIOLATIONS; REMOVAL; LIENS:
   (A)   When the owner or person in control of a parcel of private property is
in violation of any of the preceding sections of this chapter, the owner or
person in control shall be notified in writing of the violation, specifying the
type of violation, what is to be done to remedy the violation, and granting a
period not to exceed fourteen (14) days within which said condition is to be
remedied. Notification shall be made by certified or registered mail from the
village clerk or the "code official" as designated in section
7-4-13 of this chapter, or by personal service from a proper law enforcement
officer, the "code official" as designated in section
7-4-13 of this chapter, or other person authorized by law to make personal
service.
   (B)   If the condition is not remedied by said owner or person in control of
the private property within fourteen (14) days of the aforementioned
notification, the village may provide for the removal of the garbage and debris
from the private property.
   (C)   The village may recover the reasonable cost of the removal of such
garbage and debris from the owner or person in control of the property. After
the removal of the garbage and debris, village authorities shall present the
owner or person in control of the property with a bill for the reasonable
charges for the removal of such garbage and debris. Unless otherwise designated
by the village, the owner or person in control shall have ten (10) calendar
days to pay such costs. Notice of the bill shall be served upon the owner or
person in control of the property by personal service or by certified or
registered mail.
   (D)   If the costs are not paid within ten (10) days or other time period
designated by the village, the cost and related expenses shall become a lien
against the property. The village or the person performing the service by
authority of the village, in his or its own name, may file a notice of lien in
the office of the recorder of deeds of Woodford County against the property and
the owner or the person in control of the property for such costs and related
expenses. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth
the description of the real estate, the amount of the cost and expense
incurred, and the date or dates when such costs and expense were incurred by
the village.
The lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except
taxes, provided that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is
incurred, the village shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense
incurred by the village in the office of the recorder of deeds for Woodford
County. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner or persons interested
in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be
released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed. The
lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose.
   (E)   Any action taken by the village pursuant to this section shall not
impede or supersede the village's authority to take any other action permitted
under this code, including the issuance of ordinance violation notices that
impose a fine for the violation. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-4-13: BOCA PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE:
   (A)   The nationally recognized BOCA ("Building Officials and Code
Administrators") national property maintenance code/1996, together with all
future supplements and amendments which may from time to time be approved and
published by the governing body or board, is hereby adopted by reference as a
village ordinance governing buildings and structures on any property and
property maintenance within the village.
   (B)   The following insertions and amendments are hereby made to the BOCA
national property maintenance code/1996, and these insertions and amendments
together with the text of the BOCA national property maintenance code/1996
shall constitute the form of the BOCA national property maintenance code/1996
as it shall apply in the village.
      1.   Section PM-101.1: Insert "The Village of Roanoke, Illinois," as the
name of the jurisdiction.
      2.   Section PM-105.1: At the end of the section, add "For the purposes
of the BOCA National Property Maintenance Code/1996, the code official shall be
hereby designated as the chairperson of the Village's Ordinances Committee."
      3.   Section PM-106.2: Amend the provision in the first sentence of the
section to read as "be subject to a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than
$750.00" and delete the provision which reads "or imprisonment for a term not
to exceed [number] days, or both, at the discretion of the court".
      4.   Section PM-107.2: At the end of the section, add "This section shall
apply except when notice, or the form of the notice, is specifically set forth
elsewhere in this code or the Village Code."
      5.   Section PM-107.3: At the end of this section, add "Additionally,
service of notice may be proper when completed in accordance with other
provisions of the Village Code or the Illinois Municipal Code."
      6.   Section PM-108.1: The text of the entire section is deleted and
replaced with "It shall be unlawful to maintain or permit the existence of any
unsafe structure, unsafe equipment, or structure unfit for human occupancy, as
these terms are defined below, within the Village, and it shall be unlawful for
the owner, occupant, or person in custody of any unsafe structure, unsafe
equipment, or structure unfit for human occupancy to permit the same to remain
in such condition, or to occupy or allow occupancy of the same while it remains
in such condition. Further, the code official may condemn the property or
equipment pursuant to the provisions set forth below in this Section."
      7.   Section PM-108.1.1: At the end of this section, add "or that lacks
doors or windows making the structure available to or frequented by malefactors
or disorderly persons who are not lawful occupants of the structure".
      8.   Section PM-108.1.2: Add the phrase "fence," after the phrase
"includes any".
      9.   Section PM-110.1: The text of the entire section is deleted and
replaced with "See Chapter 7 of Title 7 in the Village Code."
      10.   Sections PM-110.2, PM-110.3, and PM-110.4 are deleted in their
entirety.
      11.   Section PM-111.0, entitled "Means of Appeal", and all its
subsections are deleted in their entirety.
      12.   Section PM-303.4: The text of the entire section is deleted and
replaced with "See Chapter 5 of Title 7 in the Village Code."
      13.   Section PM-303.8: The text of the entire section is deleted and
replaced with "See Section
9-5-8 of the Village Code."
      14.   Section PM-304.15: Delete the provision that reads "During the
period from [date] to [date]" and replace with "Throughout the year".
      15.   Section PM-602.2.1: Insert "during the period from September 1st to
June 1st" for the dates.
      16.   Section PM-602.3: Insert "during the period from September 1st to
June 1st" for the dates.
(Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
CHAPTER 5
PLANTS AND WEEDS
SECTION:
7-5-1: Weeds Declared A Nuisance
7-5-2: Height
7-5-3: Barberry Bushes
7-5-4: Removal; Notice
7-5-5: Abatement
7-5-6: Filing Of Lien For Removal Costs
7-5-7: Growth Of Weeds Prohibited
7-5-1: WEEDS DECLARED A NUISANCE:
Any weeds, including such weeds as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur
or other weeds of a like kind, found growing on any lot or tract of land in the
village or standing uncut or otherwise uncontrolled are hereby declared to be a
nuisance. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-5-2: HEIGHT:
It shall be unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants other than
trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants, to grow to a height
exceeding eight inches (8") anywhere in the village; any such plants or weeds
as exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. The only
exception to this height regulation is a home garden, which need not comply
with this height regulation. (Ord. 2003-06, 6-2-2003)
7-5-3: BARBERRY BUSHES:
It shall be a nuisance and unlawful to plant or permit the growth of a bush or
the species of tall, common or European barberry, further known as the Berberis
vulgaris or its horticultural varieties within the village. (Ord. 75-5, 4-21-
1975)
7-5-4: REMOVAL; NOTICE:
It shall be the duty of the "code official", as designated in section
7-4-13 of this title, to serve or cause to be served a notice upon the owner or
occupant of any premises on which weeds, plants, or grasses are permitted to
grow in violation of the provisions of this chapter and to demand the abatement
of the nuisance within seven (7) days.
Notice shall be served by personal service, by certified or registered mail, or
by posting a sign on the premises of the property in violation. Personal
service may be obtained through delivery of the notice by a village employee,
the "code official", or any person authorized by law to make personal service.
Service by certified or registered mail may be obtained by addressing and
sending the notice to the residence or usual place of business of the owner or
person in control of the property. Service by posting a sign on the premises
with an occupied structure may be obtained by posting a sign in a conspicuous
place near the main entrance of a structure on the property. Service by posting
a sign on the premises with a vacant lot or an unoccupied structure may be
obtained by posting a sign on the property in a conspicuous place near a public
street or roadway adjacent to the property or an entry point onto the property.
The posted sign shall be at least fourteen inches (14") in height and eight
inches (8") in width and at the top thereof in large letters shall state the
words "Notice to Abate". The text of the notice shall contain a reference to
the provision of this code violated and may contain such other information
respecting the nature of the violation as the "code official" deems advisable.
It shall be unlawful for anyone to deface, tamper with, or remove the "Notice
to Abate" sign from the property where it is posted unless authorized by the
"code official". (Ord. 2003-06, 6-2-2003)
7-5-5: ABATEMENT:
If the person so served or provided notice as set forth in section
7-5-4 of this chapter does not abate the nuisance within seven (7) days from
the date of the service or notice, the chairman of the street and alley
committee may proceed to abate such nuisance, keeping an account of the
expenses of the abatement and any related costs and such expenses and related
costs shall be charged to and paid by such property owner or occupant. (Ord.
2003-06, 6-2-2003)
7-5-6: FILING OF LIEN FOR REMOVAL COSTS:
When the village has abated the nuisance as mentioned in the preceding section,
the chairman of the street and alley committee shall cause a notice of such
charges, along with notice of both the applicable statutory authority and this
chapter, to be served on such owner or occupant of the offending premises by
personal service or certified mail after the abatement. Said owner or occupant
shall have ten (10) calendar days within which to pay such charges. Whenever
payment pursuant to such notice has not been paid within ten (10) days or other
time period designated by the village, the incurred expenses shall become a
lien against the property. The village or person performing the service by
authority of the village, in his or its own name, may file a notice of lien in
the office of the recorder of deeds in Woodford County against the property and
the owner for such expenses. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn
statement setting forth the description of the real estate, the amount of the
cost and expense incurred, and the date or dates when such cost and expense
were incurred by the village.
The lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except
taxes, provided that within sixty (60) days after such cost and expense is
incurred, the village shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense
incurred by the village in the office of the recorder of deeds for Woodford
County. Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner or persons interested
in such property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be
released by the village or person in whose name the lien has been filed. The
lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose.
Any action taken by the village pursuant to this section shall not impede or
supersede the village's authority to take any other action permitted under this
code, including the issuance of ordinance violation notices that impose a fine
for the violation. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-5-7: GROWTH OF WEEDS PROHIBITED:
As provided in this section, "growth of weeds" shall mean that such weeds have
exceeded the height limitations set forth in section
7-5-2 of this chapter.
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant, or person in control of
any real property to permit the growth of weeds on such property.
   (B)   It shall also be unlawful for any owner, occupant, or person in
control of any real property to permit the growth of weeds on any right of way
located between the property line of such property and the roadway portion of
an adjoining roadway, highway, or alleyway, inclusive of all parkways,
sidewalks, and waterways found thereon. When a parcel or right of way has,
because of a dangerously steep slope or gradient or for other similar reasons,
weed growth in a natural state and such area has not been previously graded,
improved, or otherwise maintained, this provision shall not apply to that
portion of the right of way with such slope or gradient.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any owner, occupant, or person in control of
any real property to permit the encroachment of vegetation, including all
weeds, flowers, bushes, hedges, trees, or any other plant growth, to encumber
any public place or public way.
   (D)   The village may enforce this section through the procedures and
processes provided in this chapter, along with any other means of enforcement
permitted under this code. (Ord. 2008-06, 10-6-2008)
CHAPTER 6
AIR POLLUTION
SECTION:
7-6-1: Definitions
7-6-2: Emission Of Dense Smoke
7-6-3: Open Burning
7-6-4: Penalty
7-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
Terms used in this chapter have the following meanings:
   AIR POLLUTION: The discharging from stacks, chimneys, exhausts, vents,
ducts, openings, buildings, structures, premises, open fires, portable boilers,
vehicles, processes or any other source of any smoke, soot, fly ash, dust,
cinders, dirt, noxious or obnoxious acids, fumes, oxides, gases, vapors, odors,
toxic or radioactive substances, waste, particulate, solid, liquid or gaseous
matter, or other materials injurious to human, plant or animal life or
property.
   COMBUSTIBLE REFUSE: Any combustible waste material containing carbon in free
or combined state other than liquids or gases.
   DENSE SMOKE: For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke,
the Ringelmann smoke chart is hereby adopted, and shall be used, as a standard
for such grading. Smoke is hereby declared to be "dense" when it is of a degree
of density of number two (2) or greater, of Ringelmann smoke chart for more
than six (6) minutes in an hour, whether such period of time is consecutive or
not.
   OPEN FIRE OR BURNING: Any fire from which the products of combustion are
admitted directly into the open air without passing through a stack or chimney.
   RINGELMANN CHART: The chart used in estimating the light- obscuring capacity
of smoke, published and described in the U.S. Bureau of Mines Information
Circular 6888, on which are illustrated the graduated shades of gray to black.
   SMOKE: Small gas borne particles, consisting, predominantly of carbon and
other combustible material, resulting from incomplete combustion and present in
sufficient quantity to be observable independently of the presence of other
solids.
   STACK OR CHIMNEY: A vertical conduit, duct, vent or flue attached to a
permanent structure. (Ord. 1992-04, 7-6-1992)
7-6-2: EMISSION OF DENSE SMOKE:
It is unlawful for any person to cause or permit the emission of dense smoke or
fumes from any fire, chimney, engine, oil burner or any other agency in the
village which causes annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof.
The owner, proprietor, lessee or occupant of any building, or the person in
charge of the furnace therein, who causes, permits or allows dense smoke or
fumes to issue or be emitted from the smokestack of any stationary furnace, or
the chimney or smokestack of any building in the village contrary to the
provisions of this code, is guilty of creating a nuisance. (Ord. 1992-04, 7-6-
1992)
7-6-3: OPEN BURNING:
The open burning of paper, garbage, refuse, waste or other combustible material
on any property, public or private, from any source whatsoever, within the
village of Roanoke is unlawful and is hereby prohibited, with the exception of
leaf burning and the burning of any other yard waste such as trimmings from
trees or bushes or similar type brush material. It shall also be lawful to make
small fires of wood or charcoal for outdoor cooking purposes. Anyone starting a
fire under this provision must attend that fire at all times. (Ord. 1999-07,
11-1-1999)
7-6-4: PENALTY:
The penalty prescribed for violation of any of the provisions of this chapter
or for any rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, as set forth in
section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ord. 1992-04, 7-6-1992)
CHAPTER 7
DANGEROUS OR UNSAFE BUILDINGS
SECTION:
7-7-1: Statutory Authority
7-7-2: Notice To Demolish Or Repair
7-7-3: Court Action
7-7-4: Other Action
7-7-5: Filing Of Lien For Demolition Or Repair Costs
7-7-1: STATUTORY AUTHORITY:
Pursuant to the power vested in the village by section 11-31-1 of the Illinois
municipal code, the village hereby adopts in whole all provisions of section
11-31-1 as it currently exists and as it may be amended from time to time.
(Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-7-2: NOTICE TO DEMOLISH OR REPAIR:
When village officials determine that a building is dangerous or unsafe,
uncompleted or abandoned, or unfit for human occupancy, village officials shall
provide notice to the owner of the property, and all lien holders of record, to
demolish or repair such building. Notice shall set forth a description of the
real estate and a description of how the building is dangerous or unsafe,
uncompleted or abandoned, or unfit for human occupancy. Notice shall also
provide the property owner at least fifteen (15) days to remedy the problems
with the building by demolishing or repairing such building. The chairperson of
the village's ordinance committee, or other designated village official or law
enforcement officer, shall provide this notice by mail or by both personal
service and mail. If after a diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of
the property owner, which may include the lien holders of record, cannot be
determined, notice mailed to the person in whose name the real estate was last
assessed shall be sufficient notice, even if such notice to the person is
subsequently returned undeliverable. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-7-3: COURT ACTION:
If the property owner fails, neglects, or refuses to comply with the notice to
demolish or repair after a notice period of at least fifteen (15) days, the
village officials may seek court approval authorizing the village to demolish,
repair, enclose, or remove the building under the authority of section 11-31-
1 of the Illinois municipal code. It shall not be a defense to any cause of
action brought by the village under this chapter that the building has been
boarded up or otherwise enclosed. After the village has received court approval
to demolish, repair, enclose, or remove the building, village officials shall
take appropriate action to have the building demolished, repaired, enclosed, or
removed. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-7-4: OTHER ACTION:
Any action taken by the village pursuant to this chapter shall not impede or
supersede the village's authority to take any other action permitted against
the property owner, occupant of the property, or person in control of the
property under this code, including the issuance of ordinance violation notices
that impose a fine for the violation. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)
7-7-5: FILING OF LIEN FOR DEMOLITION OR REPAIR COSTS:
The cost of the demolition, repair, enclosure, or removal incurred by the
village, including court costs, attorney fees, and other costs related to the
enforcement of this chapter, is recoverable from the property owner and shall
become a lien against the property. The lien shall be superior to all prior
existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes, provided that within one hundred
eighty (180) days after the repair, demolition, enclosure, or removal, the
village shall file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by the
village in the office of the recorder of deeds for Woodford County. The notice
of lien shall consist of a sworn statement setting forth the description of the
real estate, the amount of the cost and expense incurred, and the date or dates
when such costs and expense were incurred by the village. Upon payment of the
cost and expense by the property owner or persons interested in such property
after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by the village.
The village may enforce this lien at any time by initiating foreclosure
proceedings pursuant to section 11-31-1 of the Illinois municipal code, and the
costs of the foreclosure proceedings, including court costs, attorney fees, and
other costs related to the enforcement of this section, is also a lien against
the property and recoverable from the property owner. (Ord. 2002-13, 8-19-2002)

CHAPTER 1
SIDEWALKS, STREETS AND WATERCOURSES
SECTION:
8-1-1: Construction Of Sidewalks; Removal
8-1-2: Use Of Paved Streets
8-1-3: Obstructing Streets, Sidewalks, Watercourses
8-1-4: Digging In Streets
8-1-5: Injure Public Ways; Hinder Repairmen
8-1-6: Riding, Driving On Sidewalk
8-1-7: Leaving Animals; Vehicles (Rep. by Ord. 77-2, 5-2-1977)
8-1-8: Erection Of Telegraph, Electric Light Poles
8-1-9: Driveways
8-1-10: Tree Regulations
8-1-11: Drainage Water On Streets And Sidewalks
8-1-12: Mailboxes
8-1-13: Dumping On Streets, Sidewalks, Alleys And Right-Of-Way
8-1-1: CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS; REMOVAL:
Whenever there is to be constructed any new sidewalk in the village upon any of
the streets and alleys therein, where there has not been any sidewalk before,
or where there has been a sidewalk but which needs repair, the village may and
shall pass an ordinance stating that such sidewalk is to be built and the
materials, etc., to be used, and the kind of work that is to be done, and in
what manner. On any such construction of sidewalks or repair of sidewalks
within the village, the village will supply the materials if the owner of the
property supplies the labor. This the village will do only in a residential
area. In a business area, properly zoned as a business area, the village will
provide all of the materials and the labor. (Ord. 88-11, 10-3-1988)
8-1-2: USE OF PAVED STREETS:
The use of all streets in the village which are now or hereafter may be paved
with bituminous material shall be subject to the following regulations:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to drive any automobile, truck or other vehicle
on said streets at a greater speed than twenty five (25) miles per hour; or to
drive over said streets with any vehicle having either steel or rubber tires,
bearing such a load as to cut or force a depression in the surface of the
pavement, or to drive or lead thereon any horse or other animal shod with
calked shoes, or to injure the pavement in any other manner.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to burn weeds or other materials upon the surface
of said streets, or on the parkway between the curb and sidewalks on such
streets. (Ord. 196, 9-7-1943)
8-1-3: OBSTRUCTING STREETS, SIDEWALKS, WATERCOURSES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, throw or leave, or cause
to be placed, thrown or left in any street or alley, or on any sidewalk, any
obstruction or encumbrance not authorized by law or ordinance.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to obstruct any
street crossing.
   (C)   It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct, or cause to be
obstructed, any watercourse, drain, public ditch or sewer at any place that
said obstruction shall hinder or obstruct the free passage of the water in such
watercourse, drain, public ditch or sewer. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 12)
8-1-4: DIGGING IN STREETS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to make any hole, drain or ditch
in any street, alley or other public place without first having obtained
permission from the president of the board of trustees.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person, for any private purpose, to dig,
remove or carry away any earth from any street or alley without permission of
the board of trustees. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 12)
8-1-5: INJURE PUBLIC WAYS; HINDER REPAIRMEN:
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure or destroy any sidewalk,
pavement, crossing, drain or sewer, street, bridge or culvert, or any part
thereof, or to hinder or obstruct any agent or employee of the village in
repairing or making any sidewalk, pavement, crossing, street, sewer, bridge,
culvert or drain or any public improvement or work, ordered to be done by the
village, or to obstruct any of its officers in the discharge of their duties.
(R.O. 1908, Ord. 12)
8-1-6: RIDING, DRIVING ON SIDEWALK:
It shall be unlawful for any person to lead, ride or drive any animal or
vehicle upon or across any sidewalk otherwise than going into or out of
premises occupied or owned by him or his employees. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 12)
8-1-7: LEAVING ANIMALS; VEHICLES:
(Rep. by Ord. 77-2, 5-2-1977)
8-1-8: ERECTION OF TELEGRAPH, ELECTRIC LIGHT POLES:
   (A)   No telegraph, telephone, electric light or other poles or wires shall
be erected or extended in the streets or alleys of the village except under the
directions and supervision of the committee on streets and alleys and the
street commissioner of the village. All poles shall be cedar and of uniform
height, and when new lines are being built, the wires of the new line shall be
at least four feet (4') above the wires of the lines already established at all
places where the wires intersect or cross or run parallel to each other close
enough to be within four feet (4') of each other. Whenever in the judgment of
the president and board of trustees, the removal or change of location of such
poles or wires, or the raising or lowering of the same at any point or along
any street or alley is necessary, then the change shall be made by the owners
or operators of the system to which the poles or wires belong within thirty
(30) days after notice from the officials of the village of such desired
change, and in case of fire when in the judgment of the village officials, any
of such poles and wires may be cut down and removed, and shall be replaced by
the parties to whom they belong under the direction of the said committee on
streets and alleys, and street commissioner, without expense to the village,
and the village shall not be liable for any damage resulting from the cutting
and removing of such poles and wires.
   (B)   No poles or other apparatus shall be erected so as to interfere with
any sewer, gutter, tile drains, water mains or other public or local
improvements and in case of improvements in any way of any street or alley,
upon which poles or other apparatus are located, then the owner of such poles
or other apparatus shall make, at his own expense, all changes necessary to
conform to such improvement.
   (C)   The poles and wires and other apparatus shall be so erected as not to
interfere with any tree or trees in the village or with any tree or trees on
the streets or alleys of the village, and all wires dangerous to persons or
property, shall be properly insulated and well protected so as not to cause any
injury to persons or property.
   (D)   Parties desiring to erect or operate telegraph, telephone or electric
light systems, or to extend the same along the streets and alleys of the
village, shall make application for permit to the president and board of
trustees at some regular or special meeting, and in granting permits, the
president and board of trustees shall reserve unto the village and its
officers, the free use of telegraph and telephone service for fire alarm,
police and other village purposes. (R.O. 1908, Ord. 37)
8-1-9: DRIVEWAYS:
   (A)   Before any new driveway is constructed or an existing driveway is
altered, extended, repaired, or rebuilt in any manner, a permit must be
obtained to construct, alter, extend, repair, or rebuild the driveway from the
zoning officer. The application for the permit shall include the proposed
design or plan for constructing, altering, extending, repairing, or rebuilding
the driveway. The requirement to obtain a permit under this section shall not
apply to routine maintenance and upkeep of a driveway. As used in this code,
the term "driveway" shall mean a private accessway from the public road to any
adjacent lot for vehicular traffic, including any off street vehicle parking
areas that are not within an enclosed structure on lots with single-family or
two-family homes.
   (B)   The zoning officer will review the proposed design or plan for the
construction or modification of the driveway to determine whether the design or
plans for the driveway conform to the requirements set forth in this section.
   (C)   The construction of a new driveway or the modification of an existing
driveway shall meet the following requirements:
      1.   No driveway or property entrance for vehicular traffic shall be
constructed in a manner that allows such traffic to cross over an existing or
planned curb, unless appropriate curb cuts are made in a manner to provide
sufficient access for the driveway or entrance. This provision shall apply to
any off street parking areas adjacent to an existing or planned curb.
      2.   The portion of the driveway that extends from a public street and
crosses the public or street right of way shall be paved in such a manner as to
support vehicular traffic, including a sufficient rock base as necessary. Such
paved area shall be maintained at all times in good and safe structural
condition. Further, if a concrete paved sidewalk is removed or used for this
portion of the driveway, the entire portion of the driveway covered by this
provision shall be concrete.
      3.   The driveway shall not be located within thirty five feet (35') of
any intersection of public streets, as measured from the nearest curb of the
street that intersects the street to which the driveway connects.
      4.   The driveway shall have clearly defined edges or borders or shall be
contained by a weather durable permanent fixture such that the driveway area is
clearly marked or defined as a driveway.
      5.   The driveway shall conform to the overall street design, curb and
gutter design, and sidewalk design existing for the street onto which the
driveway will provide access, including standards for curb cuts, the elevation
or depression of the existing grade, and drainage.
      6.   If a sidewalk is damaged or removed during the construction or
modification of a driveway, then such sidewalk shall be repaired or replaced at
applicant's expense to a better or equivalent condition as the sidewalk was in
prior to when the driveway was constructed or modified.
      7.   Roof or surface drainage water from the property served by a
driveway shall not be permitted to flow over the portion of the driveway that
is on the public or street right of way, and a driveway shall not be used to
direct roof or surface drainage water in a manner that creates a hazardous
condition as defined in section
 8-1-11 of this chapter.
A variance may be requested from the requirements of this section in accordance
with the procedures and time periods provided in section
10-13-6 of this code, except a variance cannot be granted for requirements
(C)1, (C)4, and (C)6 of this section.
   (D)   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, alter, extend,
repair, or rebuild a driveway without first obtaining a permit as required by
this section. If anyone constructs a new driveway or modifies any existing
driveway that does not conform to the requirements set forth in this section,
then the zoning officer and village officials are empowered to take the
necessary action to require that individual to bring the driveway into
compliance with village requirements for design of the driveway, including
street, curb, gutter, and sidewalk requirements.
   (E)   When the zoning officer has approved the applicant's plan to
construct, alter, extend, repair or rebuild a driveway, the zoning officer will
issue a permit to such applicant indicating that the applicant may proceed with
the work as outlined. The fee for such permit is twenty dollars ($20.00), which
must be paid before a permit can be issued under this section. The permit shall
be the same in form and substance as the zoning use permit used under section
10-13-3 of this code, and the procedures and time periods provided in section
10-13-3 of this code shall apply to a permit issued under this section.
   (F)   Once the plan for driveway design has been approved by the zoning
officer, the applicant is then permitted to proceed with constructing the
driveway or modifying the existing driveway. When the driveway is completed,
the applicant shall notify the zoning officer who will then inspect the
driveway to ensure that it conforms with the requirements set forth herein.
   (G)   Any nonconforming driveway in existence on the date of the approval of
ordinance amending this section, or from the effective date of any subsequent
change to this section for the respective subsequent changes, shall remain a
legal nonconforming use subject to the conditions and provisions set forth in
