title 10, chapter 11 of this code. Furthermore, in addition to the conditions
and provisions set forth in section
10-11-3 of this code, any changes or reconfiguration made to a legal
nonconforming use under this section, other than routine maintenance and upkeep
or repairs or replacement consistent with the layout of the driveway prior to
any such work, shall terminate the legal nonconforming use and the requirements
of this section must be met for the changed or reconfigured portion of the
driveway.
   (H)   Any person, or any agent, employee, or contractor of such person, who
shall violate, disobey, omit, neglect, or refuse to comply with, or who shall
resist enforcement of any of the provisions of this section shall be subject to
a fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense or to a penalty as provided
for by section
1-4-13 of this code. Each day a violation is permitted to exist shall
constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
8-1-10: TREE REGULATIONS:
   (A)   No trees of any type, ornamental or otherwise, shall be planted on any
village of Roanoke easement or public right of way.
   (B)   Other than trees, property owners can plant ornamental shrubbery on
easements of the village and public rights of way. However, if the village
needs to use said public right of way or easement for any village use, then
said shrubbery, ornamentation or any form of landscaping that exists on said
public right of way or village easement will be removed in the sole discretion
of the village and the village will have no responsibility or liability for the
replacement of the shrubbery, ornamentation or anything else that has been
placed on said public right of way or village easement.
   (C)   Any violations of this section, after the date of passage, will result
in the village removing said plantings or any other use of that nature and any
other conversion to private use at the expense of the person so causing the
disturbance or unofficial usage and said person shall be charged for the cost.
If the cost is not paid by said person, the village by power of this section
will be empowered to proceed to any legal proceeding necessary to recover said
costs from said person attempting to convert public easements or rights of way
to private use.
   (D)   The village will not be obligated to notify anybody in writing to
remove said plantings or any other converted use of public rights of way or
easements. The village will be empowered to act immediately to keep public
easements and rights of way clear as provided in this section. (Ord. 1992-1, 2-
3-1992)
8-1-11: DRAINAGE WATER ON STREETS AND SIDEWALKS:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or lessee or occupant of any building or
premises to permit water to drain or empty from any such building or premises
owned, occupied, or controlled by such person so as to spread over or across
any street or sidewalk adjoining the premises in such a manner as to create an
icy or slick condition on the street or sidewalk. (Ord. 2002-01, 1-21-2002)
8-1-12: MAILBOXES:
The village shall permit property owners to place and maintain a mailbox for
mail delivery on or over the village's right of way adjacent to any public
street maintained by the village, provided that the property owner does so at
the property owner's risk of any inadvertent damage caused by the village
during the village's maintenance of the public street. Accordingly, the
property owner shall be responsible for any inadvertent damage caused by the
village during the village's maintenance of the public street, and the village
shall not be responsible for such damage. Under this section, the maintenance
of a public street shall include snow removal from the public street. This
section shall apply to all mailboxes currently maintained on or over a village
right of way and any mailboxes erected on or over a village right of way after
the effective date hereof. (Ord. 2004-04, 1-19-2004)
8-1-13: DUMPING ON STREETS, SIDEWALKS, ALLEYS AND RIGHT-OF-WAY:
   (A)   Dumping Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to dump or place any garbage,
refuse, ashes, or any unwanted item or unwanted material on any village street,
sidewalk, alley, or right-of-way at any time unless such person or entity has
express prior consent from the village to dump or place garbage, refuse, ashes,
or any unwanted item or unwanted materials on a village street, sidewalk,
alley, or right-of-way.
   (B)   Signage: The Village may post signage on or near an area on village
street, sidewalk, alley, or right-of-way upon which improper or illegal dumping
has occurred in the past at a location that provides reasonable notice and
warning to violators and potential violators that dumping is prohibited on that
area of the village street, sidewalk, alley, or right-of-way and that a minimum
fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) will be imposed for any violations of
this “no dumping” provision. However, the lack or absence of such signage or
the violator's lack of knowledge or viewing of such signage shall not be a
defense to committing a violation of this Section.
   (C)   Exemptions: This provision shall not apply to residents of property
abutting a Village right-of-way, street, or alley from placing garbage and
refuse for weekly pick-up on the right-of-way, street, or alley immediately
adjacent to property upon which the person resides.
   (D)   Penalty: A person or entity violating this section shall be fined not
less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such offense. A person
violating this section within twelve (12) months of the first violation shall
be fined not less than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such
offense. The chairperson of the village's ordinance committee shall be
permitted to issue administrative citations for violations of this section
under section
1-4-13 of this code. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each date
upon which a violation occurs. In addition to any fine imposed for a violation
of this section of the Village Code, a person convicted of a violation of this
section shall be required to reimburse the Village for the reasonable cost of
removal and disposal of the garbage, refuse, ashes, unwanted item, or unwanted
material dumped or placed on the village street, sidewalk, alley, or right-of-
way in violation of this section. (Ord. 2020-07, 6-1-2020)
CHAPTER 2
STREET NUMBERING
SECTION:
8-2-1: Numbering
8-2-2: Map and Record
8-2-3: Violation
8-2-1: NUMBERING:
All lots, buildings and structures in the Village shall be numbered in
accordance with the following plan:
The base line for streets running north and south shall be Front Street, and
numbers lying north or south thereof shall be designated north or south as the
case may be; the base line for streets running east and west shall be Main
Street, and numbers lying east or west of this line shall be designated east or
west, as the case may be. Numbering shall begin with the base lines with the
number 100, and one unit shall be allowed for each twenty five feet (25') of
frontage. Provided that the numbers at each block shall begin with 100 or a
multiple thereof.
Odd numbers shall be on the north and west sides of the streets.
8-2-2: MAP AND RECORD:
The Clerk shall keep a map of the Village showing the proper street number of
every lot in the Village, which map shall be open to inspection by any
interested person, and shall further keep a record showing the number assigned
to each lot or parcel of land in the Village, which record shall be open to
inspection by any interested person.
8-2-3: VIOLATION:
Any person violating any provision of this Chapter shall be subject to penalty
as provided for by Section
1-4-1 of this Code; provided, that no such person shall be liable for the
penalty provided until after he has received from the Clerk, by mail or
personal service, a notice of the fact that a building owned or occupied by him
does not have the proper number to comply with this Chapter. (Ord. 247; 5-7-51)
CHAPTER 3
RAILROADS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Obstructing Street Crossings
8-3-2: Maintain Public Ways
8-3-3: Speed
8-3-1: OBSTRUCTING STREET CROSSINGS:
No railroad company, conductor or other person managing or controlling any
locomotive or car shall stop or permit to be stopped, or leave the same upon
any railroad track at the crossing of any street or alley intersecting such
railroad so as to obstruct the passageway across the same for any longer time
than five (5) minutes, unless such railroad company shall be necessarily
engaged in making up or switching off its trains; in that case the obstruction
of the passageway across such railroad track shall not continue longer than is
absolutely necessary in the diligent making up or breaking of such trains. Any
such obstructions shall not in any case be continued to exceed twenty (20)
minutes at a time.
8-3-2: MAINTAIN PUBLIC WAYS:
   (A)   It shall be the duty of each and every railroad company operating any
railroad within the Village, and they are hereby required to make and keep open
and to keep in repair ditches, drains, sewers and culverts along and under
their railroad tracks so that pools of water cannot stand on its grounds or
right of way, and so that the natural drainage of adjacent property shall not
be impeded.
   (B)   It shall be the duty of each and every railroad company within the
Village, and they are hereby required, to construct and maintain and keep in
repair all street crossings at the railroad crossings in the Village, and the
approaches to said crossings within their respective rights of way, so that
said crossings shall at all times be convenient and safe to cross. (R.O. 1908,
Ord. 12)
8-3-3: SPEED:
No locomotive, engine, passenger car or other car used upon any railroad shall
be driven, propelled or run upon or along any railroad track within the limits
of the Village at a greater rate of speed than twenty five (25) miles per hour.
(R.O. 1908, Ord. 12 amd. 1974 Code)
CHAPTER 4
PUBLIC BENCHES
SECTION:
8-4-1: Village Responsibility
8-4-2: Placement Requirements
8-4-3: Maintenance
8-4-1: VILLAGE RESPONSIBILITY:
The Village will assume all liability arising out of the use of benches placed
by local businessmen in front of their places of business, regardless of the
ownership of the land upon which the benches are placed. (Ord. 1974-1, 1-7-
1974)
8-4-2: PLACEMENT REQUIREMENTS:
Any benches set out for the use of the general public, in the manner set forth
herein, shall be anchored in place in a manner acceptable to the Village Board,
so as to prevent the movement or shifting of said benches. Approval must be
obtained from said Village Board both as to the placing of the benches for
public use and the method of anchoring said benches. (Ord. 1974-1, 1-7-1974)
8-4-3: MAINTENANCE:
The Village does not accept responsibility for the maintenance and upkeep of
said benches, but rather it remains the responsibility of the individual or
individuals making the benches available for public use. However, in order to
ensure that said benches will never become a detriment to the public welfare,
the Village does reserve the right to specify the materials of which the
aforementioned benches will be constructed, the manner or mode of construction
and to what extent, if any, these benches may be used for advertising purposes.
(Ord. 1974-1, 1-7-1974)
CHAPTER 5
WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM
SECTION:
8-5-1: Superintendent Of Public Works; Duties And Powers
8-5-2: Meters Required
8-5-3: Interfere With Apparatus
8-5-3A: Destruction Of Water Meters
8-5-4: Wasting Water
8-5-5: Water Shutoff; Emergency
8-5-6: Rates, Charges For Combined Waterworks And Sewerage System
8-5-7: Billing Date
8-5-8: Liability For Payment
8-5-9: Late Payments
8-5-10: Delinquencies; Lien On Property
8-5-11: Discontinue Service; Returned Checks; Fee
8-5-12: Village Collector To Render Bills
8-5-13: Funds Kept Separate
8-5-14: Waterworks And Sewerage Revenue Fund
8-5-15: System Of Accounts
8-5-16: Annexed Property, Water And Sewer Lines Required
8-5-17: Sewer Line And Storm Drain Connections; Storm Water Drainage
8-5-18: Water Supply System Protection
8-5-19: Water Well Drilling
8-5-20: Damaging Water Or Sewer Lines; Responsibility For Cost Of Repair
8-5-1: SUPERINTENDENT OF PUBLIC WORKS; DUTIES AND POWERS:
The superintendent of public works is hereby vested with full and complete
power: (Ord. 79, 6-1-1914; amd. Ord. 2009-12, 9-8-2009)
   (A)   To direct in what manner and when attachments may be made to the
street water mains for private purposes.
   (B)   To grant permits for water meters.
   (C)   To have full control of the waterworks system, and make all necessary
rules and regulations concerning the amount of water to be used, the times when
same may be used and to prevent the waste of water.
   (D)   To exercise a supervision over the hydrants and see that they are kept
in proper repair and see that no person except those duly authorized have
access to them. (Ord. 79, 6-1-1914)
8-5-2: METERS REQUIRED:
Water shall be supplied to the inhabitants of the village through meters only,
and said meters shall be properly boxed to protect same from frost and also to
permit their inspection.
All water meters shall be put in under the supervision of the water committee
at the cost and expense of the owner of the premises on which said meter is
installed. The village shall conduct the water to the sidewalk line of the
premises on which said water is desired to be used. All village water used on
said premises shall pass through the said water meter. (Ord. 79, 6-1-1914)
8-5-3: INTERFERE WITH APPARATUS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to in any way interfere with any water
meter, main or hydrant, or to interfere or manipulate or remove any manhole
covers or other appurtenances to the combined waterworks and sewerage system,
without permission from any member of said water board, which board is hereby
vested with full power and complete authority to control the same. (Ord. 79, 6-
1-1914)
8-5-3A: DESTRUCTION OF WATER METERS:
The owner of property located within the village on which a water meter is
located or placed, will be responsible for all damage to said water meter or
meters located on that property. Said owner will also be responsible for all
costs incidental to the repair or replacement of said meter.
The appropriate authorities of the village are hereby empowered to take all
action necessary to see to it that said water meters of the village are
maintained in good repair and to further take all legal action necessary to see
to it that any damaged water meter or meters needing replacement due to damage
are paid for by the property owner on which said meter was placed. (Ord. 86-2,
3-17-1986)
8-5-4: WASTING WATER:
It shall be unlawful for any person to use Village water in any manner so as to
waste the same or to let any hydrant, hose, faucet or other tap run for an
indefinite time or to use the water of the Village in any manner in violation
of the rules which may be established by the Waterworks Board for the use of
Village water. (Ord. 79, 6-1-1914)
8-5-5: WATER SHUTOFF; EMERGENCY:
Whenever it shall be deemed necessary for adequate fire protection by the Water
Committee, this committee may shut off the water to any or all private takers
and no claim shall be allowed against the Village or any of its officers for a
failure on the part of the Village or any of its officers to supply sufficient
water. (Ord. 79, 6-1-1914)
8-5-6: RATES, CHARGES FOR COMBINED WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE SYSTEM:
Effective December 1, 2016, there shall be and there are hereby established
rates and charges for the use of and for the service supplied by the combined
waterworks and sewerage system of the Village as follows:
   (A)   Water Rates:
      1.   Property Within Village Limits: Water being supplied to any property
within the Village limits of Roanoke or annexed to the Village of Roanoke, and
to the three (3) properties located at 1207 West Front Street, 1201 West Front
Street, and 1301 West Front Street, will be billed according to the following
schedule:
 
First 1,000 gallons (minimum charge) $24.15 per thousand
For 1,001 gallons and over           18.58 per thousand
 
      2.   Property Outside Village Limits: Water being supplied to any
property not within the Village limits of Roanoke or not annexed to the Village
of Roanoke will be billed according to the following schedule which is double
the current rate:
 
First 1,000 gallons (minimum charge) $48.30 per thousand
For 1,001 gallons and over           37.16 per thousand
 
      3.   Adjustments: The water billing rates set forth in this subsection
(A) shall be adjusted on an annual basis every May 1st by an increase of 3.00
percent to both the applicable minimum charge for the first one thousand
(1,000) gallons of usage and the applicable rate for usage of one thousand one
(1,001) gallons and over.
   (B)   Bulk Water Sales: The sale of bulk water is made available to
customers with their own container on a drive up basis at the Roanoke Water
Plant. Any amount in twenty five (25) gallon increments may be purchased and
will be paid for at the time of purchase according to the following schedule:
      25 gallons for $1.25 ($0.05 per gallon)
   (C)   Sewer Rates:
      1.   Property Within Village Limits: Sewerage being processed (based on
water usage) for any property within the Village limits of Roanoke or annexed
to the Village, and for the three (3) properties located at 1207 West Front
Street, 1201 West Front Street, and 1301 West Front Street, of Roanoke will be
billed according to the following schedule:
 
First 1,000 gallons (minimum charge) $6.70 per thousand
For 1,001 gallons and over           1.65 per thousand
 
      2.   Property Outside Village Limits: Sewerage being processed (based on
water usage) for any property not within the Village limits of Roanoke or not
annexed to the Village of Roanoke, except for the three (3) properties listed
above, will be billed according to the following schedule which is double the
current rate:
 
First 1,000 gallons (minimum charge) $13.39 per thousand
For 1,001 gallons and over           3.30 per thousand
 
   (D)   Water Tap-In Fees:
      1.   Residential, business, and industrial (commercial) that requires
water services for any property within the Village limits of Roanoke or annexed
to the Village of Roanoke will be billed according to the following schedule:
 
                        Includes 1" meter, check valve, curb stop, tubing (to
1" tap-in fee $1,750.00 property line), fittings, borings (if necessary), labor
                        and equipment
                        Includes 2" meter, backflow preventer valve, curb stop,
2" tap-in fee 3,550.00  tubing (to property line), fittings, borings (if
                        necessary), labor and equipment
 
      2.   Residential, business and industrial (commercial) that requires non-
sewer water services for any property within the Village limits of Roanoke or
annexed to the Village of Roanoke. A separate water meter may be installed by a
licensed plumber on the existing water line to be used for non-sewer water
(i.e., irrigation, preparing batch mixes) at the owner's expense, subject to
the approval of the Village of Roanoke. The owner will be billed according to
the following schedule:
 
1" tap-in fee $1,250.00 Includes 1" meter with check valve
2" tap-in fee 2,100.00  Includes 2" meter with backflow preventer valve
 
   (E)   Sewer Fees: Residential, business, and industrial (commercial) that
requires sewerage services for any property within the Village limits of
Roanoke or annexed to the Village of Roanoke will be billed according to the
following schedule:
 
                                      Property owner pays entire cost of
                                      installation of material, labor and
                                      excavation cost from the property to main
Sewer inspection fee         $ 50.00  trunk sewer line. Before covering the
                                      connections they will be inspected by an
                                      authorized employee of the Village of
                                      Roanoke
Special sewer connection fee 3,000.00  
 
   In addition to the sewer inspection fee, a special sewer connection fee is
imposed for a sewer connection to a sewer line that passes sewerage through the
lift station located on West Davidson Street.
   (F)   Water And Sewer Service To Rental Units: All applicants for service
who occupy rental units shall pay a one hundred dollar ($100.00) security
deposit at the time of making such application. Such deposit shall be refunded
in full at the time service to said applicant is terminated, provided all
charges for services have been paid in full. In the event that said applicant
terminates service and there remains a balance due therefor, the Village shall
have the right to use so much or all of said security deposit as is necessary
to pay any unpaid charges. Service to a rental unit shall be considered
terminated when that rental unit is vacated by the present tenant of record.
(Ord. 2016-13, 11-7-2016; amd. Ord. 2023-09, 10-16-2023)
8-5-7: BILLING DATE:
For the purpose of the operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system
the calendar year shall be divided into twelve (12) monthly periods, said
periods to begin on the first day of each month. The rates or charges for
service above provided for shall be payable monthly on the fifteenth day of the
month immediately following the end of the monthly period for which service has
been supplied. (Ord. 67-5, 6-5-1967)
8-5-8: LIABILITY FOR PAYMENT:
The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of either water or
sewerage services, shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service
on said premises, and the service is furnished to the premises by the Village
only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of
the service, are jointly and severally liable therefor to the Village. Said
water bills will run with the property and remain a liability of the
individuals aforementioned. All bills for services shall be rendered monthly as
of the first day of the month succeeding the monthly period for which service
is billed, and shall be payable not later than the close of business on the
fifteenth day after the bills are rendered. (Ord. 1981-3, 4-6-1981, eff. 5-1-
1981)
8-5-9: LATE PAYMENTS:
If the charges for water and sewerage service, or either of them, are not paid
within fifteen (15) days after the rendition of the bill for such service, then
a penalty of ten percent (10%) of the amount of the bill shall be added
thereto. (Ord. 67-5, 6-5-1967)
8-5-10: DELINQUENCIES; LIEN ON PROPERTY:
In the event said rates or charges for water and sewerage service, or either of
them, are not paid within thirty (30) days after the rendition of the bill for
such service, such charges shall be deemed and are hereby declared to be
delinquent and thereafter such delinquencies shall constitute liens upon the
real estate for which such services are supplied, regardless of the fact that
the owner of the property and the occupant may be separate and distinct
individuals. Further, the Village Collector is hereby authorized and directed
to file sworn statements showing such delinquencies in the Office of the
Recorder of Deeds of Woodford County, Illinois, and the filing of such
statements shall be deemed notice for the payment of such charges for such
services. (Ord. 1996-04, 5-20-1996; amd. Ord. 1998-5, 6-1-1998; Ord. 1998-09,
11-2-1998)
8-5-11: DISCONTINUE SERVICE; RETURNED CHECKS; FEE:
   (A)   If the charges for water, sewerage and garbage service, or either of
them, are not paid within thirty (30) days after the rendition of the bill for
such service, creating the delinquency, water service will be discontinued on
that date. A second notice will be sent and will serve as a notice of
delinquency to the owner of the premises as well as the tenant of the property
seven (7) days prior to the date scheduled for termination of services,
informing them of the delinquent amount. If the matter is not resolved to the
satisfaction of the Village Collector, or the delinquent bill remains unpaid,
then the service to the property will be discontinued on the termination date
stated in the second notice, being seven (7) days from the date of the
delinquency notice. Should the Village Collector be unavailable or unable to
address matters pertaining to a delinquent bill, then the Chairperson of the
Village's Public Works Committee shall have the authority to handle the matter
during the Village Collector's unavailability or absence. When water service is
terminated for non-payment by a current water customer, there will be a fifty
dollar ($50.00) service charge for reinstating such water service, and this
customer shall only be required to fully pay the delinquency in order to have
this customer's water service reinstated. In all other situations, there will
be a fifty dollar ($50.00) service charge for reinstating such water service.
Except as otherwise provided herein, the water service shall not be reinstated
until all past due bills, penalties, and other charges are paid in full.
   (B)   If the charges for water and sewerage, or either of them, are not paid
due to a check returned by the bank for nonpayment for any reason, including,
but not limited to, insufficient funds or a closed account, a notice of the
returned check will be sent informing the account holder of the dishonored
check and a twenty five dollar ($25.00) returned check charge will be added to
the account.
If the matter is not resolved to the satisfaction of the Village Collector, or
the delinquent bill remains unpaid due to the returned check, then the service
to the property will be discontinued on the date stated in the notice. Should
the Village Collector be unavailable or unable to address matters pertaining to
a delinquent bill, then the Chairperson of the Village's Public Works Committee
shall have the authority to handle the matter during the Village Collector's
unavailability or absence. A fifty dollar ($50.00) service charge for
reinstating such water service will be assessed against the account holder. The
water service shall not be reinstated until all past due bills, penalties, and
other charges are paid in full.
If the charges for a delinquent account are not paid due to a check returned by
the bank for nonpayment for any reason, including, but not limited to,
insufficient funds or a closed account, and the notice of delinquent account
has been sent and the date for termination of service has past, water service
will be terminated immediately without a notice sent. A twenty five dollar
($25.00) returned check charge plus a fifty dollar ($50.00) service charge for
reinstating such water service will be added to the account at the time of the
termination of service. The water service shall not be reinstated until all
past due bills, penalties, and other charges are paid in full. (Ord. 2017-01,
2-27-2017)
8-5-12: VILLAGE COLLECTOR TO RENDER BILLS:
It is hereby made the duty of the Village Collector to render bills for water
and sewerage service, or either of them, and for all other charges in
connection therewith, and to collect all monies due thereon. (Ord. 67-5, 6-5-
1967; amd. Ord. 1998-09, 11-2-1998)
8-5-13: FUNDS KEPT SEPARATE:
All revenues and monies derived from the operation of the combined waterworks
and sewerage system shall be held by the Village Clerk separate and apart from
his private funds and separate and apart from all other funds of the Village,
and all of said sums, without any deductions whatsoever, shall be delivered to
the Village Treasurer not more than ten (10) days after the receipt of the
same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed
by the Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 67-5, 6-5-1967)
8-5-14: WATERWORKS AND SEWERAGE REVENUE FUND:
The Village Treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the combined
waterworks and sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the
operation of said system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the
same in a separate fund designated as the "Waterworks and Sewerage Revenue Fund
of the Village of Roanoke", and the Village Treasurer shall administer said
fund in every respect in the manner provided by the Illinois Municipal Code and
all other laws pertinent thereto. (Ord. 67-5, 6-5-1967)
8-5-15: SYSTEM OF ACCOUNTS:
The Village Treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall
keep proper records, books and accounts, in which complete and correct entries
shall be made of all transactions relative to the combined waterworks and
sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals the Village Board of Trustees
shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books
to show the receipts and disbursements of the combined waterworks and sewerage
system. (Ord. 67-5, 6-5-1967)
8-5-16: ANNEXED PROPERTY, WATER AND SEWER LINES REQUIRED:
   (A)   Henceforth, upon due publication and notification to the public, it
will be the complete and total responsibility, including financial
responsibility of anyone annexing to the Village, to run water and sewer lines
from the property being annexed to the village water and sewer lines
appropriately designated by the village engineer. All expenses of hooking up
such water and sewer lines are the complete and total expense of the property
owner. Under no circumstances is the financial obligation of such water and
sewer hookup and line extension the financial obligation of the village.
   (B)   Such annexing property owner, be it a subdivision or unsubdivided
tract of land, may now extend water and sewer lines from his property to
existing village water and sewer lines only upon the approval of the village
engineer, tapping into existing village water and sewer lines only where
designated by the village engineer.
   (C)   This legislation supersedes all legislation of the village reflected
in this code, be it in the subdivision regulations or otherwise. (Ord. 83-1, 1-
17-1983)
8-5-17: SEWER LINE AND STORM DRAIN CONNECTIONS; STORM WATER DRAINAGE:
   (A)   Inspection Of Sanitary Sewer Line: Before any footing tile or sanitary
sewer line connecting to any new housing construction in the village or old
housing construction in the village may be covered by a contractor,
subcontractor or homeowner, said footing tile or sanitary sewer line must be
inspected by the designated inspector of the village board and said designated
inspector must give a written approval that said footing tile or sanitary sewer
line has been inspected. If said inspection is not obtained prior to said
footing tile or sanitary sewer line being covered by dirt by said contractor,
subcontractor or homeowner, then the village board and its designated
inspectors and other agents are hereby authorized and empowered to force said
homeowner, contractor and/or subcontractor to uncover said footing tile and/or
sewer line for proper inspection at the expense of that contractor,
subcontractor or homeowner.
   (B)   Maintenance, Continuation Or Retention Of Broken, Defective Or
Presently Unlawful Building Drains, Building Sewers Or Storm Drain Connections
Or Conditions:
      1.    It is unlawful for any person owning property located within the
village to permit any of the following conditions to be or remain on such
property ninety (90) days after notification by the superintendent of public
works, or actual knowledge, of the existence of such a condition:
         (a)   A storm sewer or storm drain which is so constructed or is in
such a condition as to allow or permit the discharge of stormwater, surface
water or groundwater into a building drain, building sewer or public sanitary
sewer, either directly through a direct connection or indirectly by discharging
or permitting the discharge of such water in or near areas of gravel, crushed
rock or other porous soil or material located near or around openings, holes,
cracks, loose joints or other gaps in a building drain, building sewer or
public sanitary sewer;
         (b)   A private combined sewer;
         (c)   A stormwater, surface water or groundwater collection or
diversion device, including, without limitation, the following: area drains,
yard drains, footing tiles, downspout, leaders, stormwater, surface water or
groundwater sump pumps or other pumping device, which is constructed or in such
a condition so as to discharge or permit or allow the discharge of stormwater,
surface water or groundwater into a building drain, building sewer or public
sanitary sewer either directly through a direct connection or indirectly by
discharging or permitting the discharge of such water in or near areas of
gravel, crushed rock or other porous soil or material located near or around
openings, holes, cracks, loose joints or other gaps in a building drain,
building sewer or public sanitary sewer;
         (d)   A building drain or building sewer with broken, missing or
cracked tiles, loose or separated joints or other holes, cracks, gaps or
spaces;
         (e)   Any other fixture, structure or condition which permits or
allows or is in such a condition to permit or allow stormwater, surface water
or groundwater to enter directly or indirectly a building drain, building sewer
or public sanitary sewer.
      2.   The superintendent of public works may give notification of the
existence of such a condition described in subsection (B)1 of this section
either personally or by certified mail to the owner of record of the property
on which such a condition is located or to the person who last paid local real
estate taxes on such property and upon the giving or mailing of such
notification, the property owner shall be deemed to have received notice of the
existence of such a condition.
      3.   The notification provided in subsection (B)2 of this section shall
be given if one or more of the following occurs:
         (a)   An on-site visual or physical inspection of the property
indicates the existence of a condition described in subsection (B)1 of this
section;
         (b)   A "dye test" indicates that water or dye placed in stormwater,
surface water or groundwater collection or diversion devices or in the ground
near the foundation of a building or structure located on such property enters
the public sanitary sewer;
         (c)   A "smoke test" indicates that smoke placed into the public
sanitary sewer under pressure is escaping through the ground or through
downspouts, leaders, gutters, yard drains, area drains or other stormwater
collection or diversion devices located on the owner's property.
      4.   The superintendent of public works is authorized to develop material
describing the testing procedures set forth in this section and indicating the
manner in which such tests shall be conducted.
      5.   Any person to whom such notification is given may appeal the
determination of the superintendent of public works to the water and sewer
committee of the village by delivering to the village board, within ten (10)
days from the date such notification is given, a "notice of appeal" detailing
the circumstances, grounds or reasons why the property owner believes that the
determination of the superintendent of public works is incorrect or inaccurate.
      6.   The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice,
permanently cease all violations.
   (C)   Storm Drain Discharge Connections and Stormwater Discharge:
      1.   Stormwater, surface water, or groundwater from area drains, footing
tiles, downspouts, leaders, stormwater or groundwater pumps, or other pumping
devices may be directed into a gutter in a village street through an existing
opening in the curb in existence on or before October 1, 2009. Any such
existing use of an existing opening in the curb will be allowed to continue
until such time as a new sidewalk or the replacement curb is installed at which
time no holes or openings will be permitted in either the new sidewalk or the
replacement curb. If such existing opening in the curb allows water to stand in
the immediately adjacent curb and gutter area in a village street for more than
four (4) days after a storm or rainfall, this standing water and use of the
existing opening in the curb will be declared a nuisance, and the use of the
existing opening in the curb must be discontinued by the property owner within
thirty (30) days after receiving written notice from a village official that
the use of the existing opening in the curb is creating a nuisance in this
section. After October 1, 2009, no property owner may direct stormwater,
surface water, or groundwater from area drains, footing tiles, downspouts,
leaders, stormwater or groundwater pumps, or other pumping devices into a
gutter in a village street by creating a hole or opening in the curb or placing
a drainage pipe such that it drains directly into a village street. After
October 1, 2009, property owners shall not be permitted to create any holes or
openings in a curb along a village street for any purpose, except when
authorized by the village for purposes of creating or expanding driveway access
for the property.
      2.   For residential properties, the proper way to discharge stormwater,
surface water, or groundwater would be to use one of the following methods:
         (a)   Into the grass or lawn on the homeowner's property;
         (b)   Direct connection from the homeowner's property to the village
stormwater sewer system;
         (c)   A natural waterway, drainage ditch, or creek adjacent to the
homeowner's property; or
         (d)   A dry well or sump on the homeowner's property.
      3.   It is unlawful for any person owning property located within the
village to permit the discharge of stormwater, surface water, or groundwater
from a downspout, a sump pump or other pumping device, or any other storm water
diversion device, equipment, or fixture onto adjacent property such that the
discharged water is directed at, into, or immediately next to a primary or
accessory building on the neighboring property in a manner that the discharged
water flows into, onto, or immediately next to the building on the neighboring
property or otherwise negatively impacts the building on the neighboring
property. As set forth herein, the term "building" shall be defined as set
forth in the village's zoning regulations as set forth in Title 11 of the
Village Code and shall additionally include any attached improvements to the
building, including, but not limited to, a patio, porch, deck, or carport.
         (a)   The superintendent of public works may give notification of the
existence of such a condition described in subsection (C)3 of this section
either personally or by certified mail to the owner of record of the property
that is discharging stormwater, surface water, or groundwater in a manner that
violates this subsection (C)3 or to the person who last paid local real estate
taxes on such property, and upon the giving or mailing of such notification,
the property owner shall be deemed to have received notice of the existence of
such a condition that violates this subsection (C)3.
         (b)   The notification provided in this subsection shall be given if
an on-site visual or physical inspection of the property indicates the
existence of a condition described in this subsection (C)3.
         (c)   Any person to whom such notification is given may appeal the
determination of the superintendent of public works to the water and sewer
committee of the village by delivering to the village board, within ten (10)
days from the date such notification is given, a "notice of appeal" detailing
the circumstances, grounds, or reasons why the property owner believes that the
determination of the superintendent of public works is incorrect or inaccurate.
         (d)   The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such
notice, permanently cease all violations.
         (e)   This provision shall not apply to stormwater, surface water, or
groundwater that flows from one property onto or into an adjacent property
along a naturally occurring path for such water drainage.
   (D)   Violation; Fine Specified: Any person violating the provisions of this
chapter or permitting such a violation to remain beyond the period of time
provided for voluntary correction or elimination thereof, shall, upon
conviction, be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation. A separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues.
   (E)   Violation; Liability For Loss Or Damage: Any person violating any of
the provisions of this chapter shall become liable to the village for any
expense, loss or damage occasioned the village by reason of such violation.
(Ord. 2009-12, 9-8-2009; amd. Ord. 2-15-2022)
8-5-18: WATER SUPPLY SYSTEM PROTECTION:
   (A)   Backflow Prevention Devices Required: If in accordance with the
Illinois plumbing code or in the judgment of the chairman of the water and
sewer committee, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the
safety of the public water supply system, the chairman of the water and sewer
committee will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved
device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, purchase the
backflow prevention device from the village or acquire a village designated
backflow prevention device. The superintendent of public works shall maintain a
list of approved and acceptable backflow prevention devices by manufacturer
name and model number. In order to comply with this section, the water customer
must install a backflow prevention device set forth on the list maintained by
the village. The water customer will be responsible for any costs associated
with removing and replacing a backflow prevention device not included on the
list of approved and accepted devices maintained by the village. The water
customer shall also, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a
location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code and all
applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such
approved devices as required by the Illinois plumbing code and local
regulations. After such device has been installed, inspected, and approved by
the village, the village shall maintain such device as part of the village's
water supply system.
   (B)   Approval Of Private Water Supply System: No person shall establish or
permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection
whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular
public water supply of the village enters the supply or distribution system of
the municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and
the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
village and the Illinois environmental protection agency.
   (C)   Investigation Of Industrial Properties: It shall be the duty of the
chairman of the water and sewer committee to cause surveys and investigations
to be made of industrial and other properties served by the public water supply
to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may
exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter of public record
and shall be repeated at least every two (2) years unless a licensed plumber
has installed a backflow preventer device on the industrial property, or
annually if an irrigation system has been installed on the property. Records of
such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at
least five (5) years.
   (D)   Right Of Entry For Cross Connection Control Inspection: The approved
cross connection control device inspector shall have the right to enter at any
reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply
or distribution system of the village for the purpose of verifying the presence
or absence of cross connections, and the superintendent of public works or his
authorized agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any
property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution
system of the village for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the
customer regarding the required cross connection control inspection. On demand
the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the
chairman of the water and sewer committee any information which he may request
regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The
refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the
chairman of the water and sewer committee, be deemed evidence of the presence
of improper connections as provided in this chapter.
   (E)   Discontinue Water Service For Violation: The chairman of the water and
sewer committee of the village is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
chapter is known to exist, which includes the installation of a backflow
prevention device that is not included on the village list of approved and
accepted devices, and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem
necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply
distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until
such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the
provisions of this chapter, and until a reconnection fee of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) is paid to the village. Immediate disconnection with verbal
notice can be effected when the chairman of the water and sewer committee is
assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water
supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of
the cause of disconnection.
   (F)   Responsibility For Cost Of Cleanup: The consumer responsible for back
siphoned material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the
potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an
improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been
bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system.
   (G)   Maximum Tap Line: The maximum tap line for a residence into the
village water line is a one inch (1") tap line. No tap line to a residence of
any type, single-family or multiple-family, may exceed one inch (1") unless
specific written permission by variance is given by the board of trustees of
the village. (Ord. 2015-12, 8-3-2015)
8-5-19: WATER WELL DRILLING:
The president and board of trustees of the village hereby adopt the following
as the water well drilling policy of the village:
   (A)   Issuance Of Permits By Water Department: The water department has the
authority to issue water well drilling permits when the conditions for drilling
the well meet all of the standards set forth in the following policy.
   (B)   Permit Required; Fee: The owner of the well shall have obtained a
permit from the water department. The permit fee shall be two hundred dollars
($200.00).
   (C)   Requirements: Before a permit shall be issued, the following
requirements shall be met:
      1.   Use of water obtained from the well:
         (a)   May not be used for potable water use;
         (b)   Will be permitted for the watering of landscape material (trees,
shrubs, flowers or grass);
         (c)   Will be permitted to supplement lakes, ponds and wet detention
basins;
         (d)   Will be permitted to supply cooling systems, the manufacture of
products and the cleaning or washing of vehicles or other equipment.
      2.   Wells may only be located on a tract of land that is at least five
(5) acres in size and is under a single ownership. Each additional well to be
developed shall require an additional twenty five (25) acres of land under one
ownership.
      3.   All wells will be limited in capacity to under fifty (50) gallons
per minute.
      4.   Plans and specifications for all proposed wells must be submitted to
the department clearly indicating precautions that will be taken to prevent the
interconnection of the water taken from the well with the public water system.
   (D)   Water Meter Required: All wells will be required to be metered and the
owner required to pay the appropriate monthly fee to the village if it is
determined by the village that the water from the well is being discharged into
the sanitary sewer system. This subsection is retroactive and will apply to all
existing wells.
   (E)   Existing Wells: All wells currently in operation on the date of the
adoption of these policies will be required to obtain a permit, but they will
be exempted from all requirements except subsection (D) of this section. (Ord.
1990-2, 1-15-1990)
8-5-20: DAMAGING WATER OR SEWER LINES; RESPONSIBILITY FOR COST OF REPAIR:
Any property owner who in any way repairs or does any type of maintenance work,
repair work or any type of work at any time on any water or sewer line on his
property and as a result said work, maintenance, etc., causes any type of
damage or malfunction on water and sewer lines of the village which are not
located on his property, and such damage to the water and sewer lines can be
established by the village engineer of the village, then the cost of repair for
such damage to such water and sewer lines occasioned by the action of the
property owner shall be assessed to the property owner and a bill for such
costs shall be sent to him. If that charge is not paid within sixty (60) days
of the receipt of the bill, then the village will take whatever legal action is
necessary to collect the cost for the repair of said water and sewer system.
(Ord. 1990-8, 12-3-1990)
CHAPTER 6
STREET AND ALLEY PETITION PROCEDURE
SECTION:
8-6-1: Petition To Lay Out, Widen Or Vacate
8-6-2: Description; Owners Named
8-6-3: Copy Posted
8-6-4: Petition Filed With Clerk
8-6-5: Notice Of Meeting
8-6-6: Adjournment
8-6-7: Proceedings To Vacate
8-6-8: Survey And Plat
8-6-9: Ascertain Damages
8-6-10: Agreement
8-6-11: When Damages Not Released
8-6-12: Notify Owners
8-6-13: Venire For Jury
8-6-14: Challenge Of Jury
8-6-15: Unknown Owners
8-6-16: Notice Served
8-6-17: Jury Sworn
8-6-18: Hear Evidence
8-6-19: Damages Assessed
8-6-20: Board Determination
8-6-21: Revoke Proceedings
8-6-22: Order Made
8-6-23: Proceedings, Damages Released
8-6-24: Inducements Offered
8-6-25: Prima Facie Evidence
8-6-26: Road Tax
8-6-27: Streets On Village Line
8-6-28: Vacation, By Ordinance
8-6-29: Streets Laid Out; Fees
8-6-1: PETITION TO LAY OUT, WIDEN OR VACATE:
The board of trustees may lay out, alter, widen or vacate any street, alley or
avenue when petitioned by one or more freeholders of the village, residing in
the vicinity of the street, alley or avenue to be laid out, altered, widened or
vacated. (Ord., 10-15-1900; amd. 1974 Code)
8-6-2: DESCRIPTION; OWNERS NAMED:
Said petition shall set forth in writing a description of the street, alley or
avenue, and what part thereof is to be altered, widened or vacated and, if for
a new street, alley or avenue, the names of the owners of the land, if known,
if not known it shall be so stated, over which the same is to pass; its general
course, and as near as may be, the terminal points.
8-6-3: COPY POSTED:
Whenever any number of freeholders shall determine to petition the Board of
Trustees for the laying out, alteration, widening or vacation of any street,
alley or avenue, the petitioner or petitioners shall cause a copy of the
petition to be posted up in three (3) of the most public places in the Village,
one of which shall be in the immediate vicinity of such street, alley or
avenue, at least ten (10) days before any action shall be had in reference to
said petition. The posting of any notice required by this Chapter may be proved
by the affidavit of the person posting the same, or by other legal evidence.
8-6-4: PETITION FILED WITH CLERK:
Whenever any petition shall have been so posted, it shall be filed in the
office of the Village Clerk, who shall at the next regular meeting lay the
same, with the proof of posting copies thereof, before the Board of Trustees,
and they shall thereupon, at the same or some subsequent regular meeting, fix
upon a time and place when they will meet to examine the same, and to hear all
reasons for or against granting the prayer of said petition.
8-6-5: NOTICE OF MEETING:
It shall be the duty of the Village Clerk to give at least ten (10) day's
notice of the time and place of said meeting by posting notices thereof in
three (3) of the most public places in the Village.
8-6-6: ADJOURNMENT:
The Board of Trustees may, by public announcement, and by the posting of a
notice at the time and place named for said meeting, adjourn the same from time
to time, but not for a time beyond the next regular meeting, when they shall
publicly announce whether they will grant or refuse the prayer of the petition,
and shall endorse upon, or annex to the petition a brief memorandum of such
decision, to be signed by them; such decision shall be subject to revocation in
case the prayer of the petitioners is granted in the manner hereinafter
provided. In case the Board of Trustees refuses to grant the prayer of
petition, the Clerk shall endorse upon the same the fact of said refusal and
preserve the said petition, so endorsed, among the files of his office.
8-6-7: PROCEEDINGS TO VACATE:
If the petition is simply for the vacation of a street, alley or avenue, and
the Board of Trustees, or a majority of them, shall at such meeting decide that
the prayer of the petitioners should be granted, they shall order such street,
alley or avenue to be vacated, a copy of which order, together with the
petition, shall be by them filed with the Clerk, such order to be so filed
within ten (10) days after the date of such decision; and if not so filed, said
order of vacation shall be deemed void and of no effect.
8-6-8: SURVEY AND PLAT:
If such petition is for laying out a new street, alley or avenue, or the
alteration or widening of an existing one, and the Board of Trustees, or a
majority of them, shall be of the opinion that the prayer of the petitioners
should be granted, they shall cause a survey, and plat of such street, alley or
avenue to be made by a competent surveyor, who shall report such survey and
plat to said Board, giving the courses and distances, and specifying the land
over which it is to pass, in which they may make such changes between the
termini of the street, alley or avenue described in the petition, as the
convenience of the public, in their judgment may require.
8-6-9: ASCERTAIN DAMAGES:
They shall also, before they order any street, alley or avenue to be
established, altered, widened or vacated, ascertain as hereinafter provided,
the aggregate amount of damages which the owner or owners of the land over
which it is to pass shall be entitled to by reason of the location, alteration
or vacation of such street, alley or avenue; provided, however, that in case an
appeal is taken from the assessment of damages before the proper Village
officer, the Board in its discretion may make an order laying out, widening or
altering or vacating such street, alley or avenue either before or after such
appeal is determined.
8-6-10: AGREEMENT:
The damages sustained by the owner or owners of the land by reason of the
laying out, widening, alteration or vacation of any street, alley or avenue may
be agreed upon by the owners of such land, if competent to contract, and the
Board of Trustees, or they may be released by such owners, in which case the
agreement or release shall be in writing, and shall be filed and recorded, with
a copy of the order establishing or altering such street, alley or avenue, in
the Village Clerk's office, and shall be a perpetual bar against such owners,
their grantees and assigns, for all further claims for such damages.
8-6-11: WHEN DAMAGES NOT RELEASED:
In case such damages are not released or agreed upon as in the preceding
Section specified, the Board of Trustees shall within twenty (20) days of the
date at which it was decided to grant the prayer of the petition, make a
certificate that they are about to establish, widen, vacate or alter a public
street, alley or avenue, describing such street, alley or avenue, vacation,
widening or alteration, and land over or on which such street, alley or avenue
is to be established, altered, widened or vacated, naming the owners of such
land, if known, and if not known, stating the fact, and asking for a jury to
assess the damages of such owners, and shall present such certificate to some
proper County officer, who shall summon a jury in the manner hereinafter
provided, having the qualification of jurors, to appear before such officer at
a time to be fixed by him, within ten (10) days from the time such certificate
was presented to him, to assess such damages.
8-6-12: NOTIFY OWNERS:
The said Board shall also notify each and every owner of land, if known, and a
resident of the County, whose damages are to be assessed, that they will apply
to a proper officer (giving the time when and place where) to have a jury
impaneled to assess such damages.
8-6-13: VENIRE FOR JURY:
Upon the presentation of such certificate by the said Board, the proper officer
shall forthwith issue a venire directed to any constable of the County, to
summon twelve (12) persons having the qualification of jurors, at least one-
half (1/2) of whom shall be residents of the Village to appear, at such time
and place as may be designated for the trial of said cause, whose competency
shall be determined the same as in other civil causes before the proper
officers.
8-6-14: CHALLENGE OF JURY:
At the trial of the case either party shall have the right of challenge, as in
other cases, and any deficiency in the number of jurors, from whatever cause,
shall be supplied by summoning other persons in the same manner as in civil
cases. Such proper officers shall notify the owners of such land mentioned in
such certificate to appear at the same time before such officer to prove their
damages.
8-6-15: UNKNOWN OWNERS:
In case it shall appear either from the certificate of the said Board, the
affidavit of any person or the return of any officer to whom the writ may be
delivered for service, that there is an unknown owner or owners, who cannot be
found and served within the County, such proper officer shall also cause notice
to be posted in three (3) of the most public places in the Village, in the
vicinity of such proposed street, alley, avenue, or alteration, at least six
(6) days before the time fixed for the appearance of such jury, stating when
such jury is to be impaneled by him, and describing the street, alley or avenue
to be established, altered, widened or vacated as petitioned for, and the land
for which damages are to be assessed.
8-6-16: NOTICE SERVED:
The notice to such owners of land may be served by any constable, or one of the
petitioners, or other person of lawful age, at least five (5) days before the
time of appearance. If any of such owners is an infant, by delivering a copy to
the infant or its guardian, if any; if no guardian, the person with whom he
resides. If any owner is a lunatic or habitual drunkard, having a conservator,
or insane, by delivering a copy to his conservator, if any. If any such owner
is a married woman, by delivering a copy to her.
8-6-17: JURY SWORN:
The jury shall appear and be sworn, or affirmed, by such proper officer,
faithfully and impartially to assess the damages of each of the owners
specified in such certificate, or those of them to be adjusted, according to
law to the best of their judgment and understanding, and all parties in
interest shall be entitled to subpoenas, and other writs and papers, and
changes of venue may be had, and the trial shall be conducted as in other civil
cases.
8-6-18: HEAR EVIDENCE:
The jury shall hear such lawful evidence touching the question of such damages
as may be presented to them, and shall also on request of the said Board; or
owners of land whose damages are to be determined, in a body visit and examine
the proposed location, alteration, widening or vacation of such street, alley
or avenue, and the lands to be taken and affected thereby, and make a written
verdict, specifying the amount of damages, if any, which each such owner shall
recover, and return the same to such proper officer, to be by him entered upon
his docket in the nature of a judgment, to be paid by the said Board, together
with the costs of such suit, in case they shall finally determine to establish,
alter, widen or vacate such street, alley or avenue, and the money therefor
shall be paid by the Village out of the funds in the hands of the Treasurer
raised for road and bridge purposes; provided, that in estimating the damages,
the jury may consider the benefits conferred, or may disregard such benefits;
but no benefits enjoyed in common by the owners of such surrounding property
shall be considered in estimating damages.
8-6-19: DAMAGES ASSESSED:
When there are several such owners, the jury may assess the damages of one or
more, or all of them at the same time, or they may assess such damages at
different times, or there may be different juries and trials at different times
for different owners, if any owner shall demand a separate trial; and such
assessment of damages may be continued from time to time, for good cause, with
like effect as continuances in other cases before proper officers.
8-6-20: BOARD DETERMINATION:
After the total amount of damages shall have been ascertained either by release
or agreement of the parties, or by assessment before a proper officer and a
jury, in the manner hereinbefore provided, the Board shall at its next regular
meeting determine upon the laying out, altering, widening or vacation of such
street, alley or avenue, of which meeting said Board shall give public notice,
by causing not less than three (3) notices thereof to be posted at public
places within the Village, at least five (5) days prior thereto.
8-6-21: REVOKE PROCEEDINGS:
In cases where the damages are not wholly released or agreed upon, and the
Board shall be of the opinion that the damages assessed by the jury are
manifestly too high, and the payment of the same would be an unreasonable
burden upon the Village, the Board may revoke all proceedings had upon the
petition by a written order to that effect, and such revocation shall have the
effect to annul all such proceedings, and the assessments, releases and
agreements, in respect to damages, growing out of the proceedings upon the
petition.
8-6-22: ORDER MADE:
In case the Board shall not revoke such prior proceedings, they shall make an
order, to be signed by them, declaring such street, alley or avenue altered,
widened or laid out, a public street, alley or avenue, which order shall
contain, or have annexed thereto, a definite description of the line of such
street, alley or avenue, together with a plat thereof. The said Board shall,
within ten (10) days, cause the same, together with the report of the surveyor,
the petitions and releases, or agreements in respect to damages, to be
deposited and filed in the office of the Village Clerk, who shall note upon
such order the date of such filing, and record the same.
8-6-23: PROCEEDINGS, DAMAGES RELEASED:
In cases where the damages claimed by the landowners for the right of way is
released, or is agreed upon between the landowners and the said Board, the
Board may at their first meeting, or at an adjourned meeting, examine the route
of the street, alley or avenue, and cause a survey to be made and make out
their order establishing, altering, widening or vacating the same according to
the prayer of the petitioners, and return the same within the time, and in the
manner specified in this Chapter.
8-6-24: INDUCEMENTS OFFERED:
Any person or persons interested in the establishment, alteration, widening or
vacation of any street, alley or avenue in the Village are hereby authorized to
offer inducements to the said Board, for the establishment, alteration,
widening or vacation of any such street, alley or avenue, by entering into
contract with the Board, conditioned upon such establishment, alteration,
widening or vacation, to pay any money or other valuable thing to the Village,
for the benefit of the Village, or to perform any labor, or to construct any
street, alley or avenues, which said persons desire to have established,
widened or altered. And such contract in writing, made with the Village, shall
be deemed good and valid in law, and may be enforced by the Village before any
court having jurisdiction.
8-6-25: PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE:
The record of the Clerk, or a certified copy of such record and papers relating
to the establishment, location, alteration, widening or vacation of any street,
alley or avenue, shall be prima facie evidence in all cases that all the
necessary antecedent provisions had been complied with, and that all the acts
of the Board, or all other persons and officers in regard thereto were regular
in all respects.
8-6-26: ROAD TAX:
The amount of road tax assessed by the Commissioners of Highways of the
Township of Roanoke on the real estate and personal property in the Village
liable to taxation shall, when paid into the Village Treasury, be appropriated
to the improvement of the streets and bridges of the Village, under the
direction of the President and Board of Trustees; provided, that the President
and Board of Trustees may at any time, by a written order, signed by a majority
of the Board, a copy of which shall be spread upon their records, notify the
Collector not to collect the tax so levied within the limits of the Village.
8-6-27: STREETS ON VILLAGE LINE:
Streets and roads may be laid out, altered, widened or vacated on the Village
line in the same manner as other public roads and streets, except that in such
cases, copies of the petition shall be posted up in, and presented to the
Commissioners of Highways of each township interested; whereupon the
Commissioners of Highways of the Township may meet with the Board, and act as
one body, in the same time and in the same manner as in other cases in
considering the petition, viewing the premises, adjusting damages, and making
all orders in reference to proposed road or street alteration, widening or
vacation, and a majority of all such Commissioners, and also a majority of the
Board must concur in all such orders, and a copy of all final orders, plats and
papers shall be filed and recorded in the town clerk's office of the township
interested, and the office of the Village Clerk.
8-6-28: VACATION, BY ORDINANCE:
No street, alley or avenue shall be vacated except by ordinance, and upon a
three-fourths (3/4) majority of all the Trustees authorized by law to be
elected, which vote shall be by yeas and nays, and entered on the record of
said Board.
8-6-29: STREETS LAID OUT; FEES:
Whenever any street, alley or avenue shall be laid out, altered or widened, it
shall be the duty of the Board of Trustees to cause a plat thereof to be made,
showing the width, course and extent thereof, and making such reference to
known and established corners or monuments that the location thereof may be
ascertained, and have the same recorded in the recorder's office of the proper
county; and when any street, alley or avenue is vacated, the ordinance vacating
the same shall be in like manner recorded. The fees for recording shall be paid
by the Village. (10-15-1900; amd. 1974 Code)
CHAPTER 7
RECREATION CENTER
SECTION:
8-7-1: Provision for a Recreation Facility
8-7-1: PROVISION FOR A RECREATION FACILITY:
   (A)   The Village Board authorizes the designation of specific areas as
recreation centers, and
   (B)   The Board may in its discretion provide for the construction of a type
of recreation center, or
   (C)   The Board in its discretion may designate an existing building or
buildings and the surrounding area as recreation centers, and
   (D)   Said recreation center or centers as aforementioned are to be
controlled by the said Village Board of the Village of Roanoke as to the hours
of use by all persons and the Village Board reserves the right to determine
what type of recreational activities will be engaged in upon said premises.
(Ord. 75-9; 6-16-75)
CHAPTER 8
SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES IN PUBLIC RIGHT-OF-WAY
SECTION:
8-8-1: Purpose And Scope
8-8-2:    Definitions
8-8-3: Regulation Of Small Wireless Facilities
8-8-4: Dispute Resolution
8-8-5: Indemnification
8-8-6: Insurance
8-8-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
(A)   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to establish regulations,
standards and procedures for the siting and collocation of small wireless
facilities in the rights-of-way within the village's jurisdiction, or outside
the rights-of-way on property zoned by the village exclusively for commercial
or industrial use, in a manner that is consistent with the Act.
(B)   Conflicts With Other Ordinances: This chapter supersedes all ordinances
or parts of ordinances adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to
the extent of such conflict.
(C)   Conflicts With State And Federal Laws: In the event that applicable
federal or state laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this
chapter, the wireless provider shall comply with the requirements of this
chapter to the maximum extent possible without violating federal or state laws
or regulations. (Ord. 2018-07, 7-16-2018)
8-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
ANTENNA: Communications equipment that transmits or receives electromagnetic
radio frequency signals used in the provision of wireless services.
APPLICABLE CODES: Uniform building, fire, electrical, plumbing, or mechanical
codes adopted by a recognized national code organization or local amendments to
those codes, including the national electric safety code.
APPLICANT: Any person or entity who submits a siting application and the
agents, employees, and contractors of such person or entity.
APPLICATION: A request submitted by an applicant to the village for a permit to
collocate small wireless facilities, and/or a request that includes the
installation of a new utility pole for such collocation at a specific location,
as well as any applicable fee for the review of such application.
COLLOCATE OR COLLOCATION: To install, mount, maintain, modify, operate, or
replace wireless facilities on or adjacent to a pre- existing structure or
utility pole, and/or modification of a structure for the purpose of mounting or
installing a wireless facility on that structure or utility pole.
COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE: Cable service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 522(6), as
amended; information service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 153(24), as amended;
telecommunications service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 153(53), as amended;
mobile service, as defined in 47 U.S.C. § 153(53), as amended; or wireless
service other than mobile service.
COMMUNICATIONS SERVICE PROVIDER: A cable operator, as defined in 47 U.S.C. §
522(5), as amended; a provider of information service, as defined in 47 U.S.C.
§ 153(24), as amended; a telecommunications carrier, as defined in 47 U.S.C. §
153(51), as amended; or a wireless provider.
FCC: The Federal Communications Commission of the United States.
FEE: A one-time charge.
HISTORIC DISTRICT or HISTORIC LANDMARK: A building, property, or site, or group
of buildings, properties, or sites that are either (i) listed in the national
register of historic places or formally determined eligible for listing by the
keeper of the national register, the individual who has been delegated the
authority by the federal agency to list properties and determine their
eligibility for the national register, in accordance with section VI.D.1.a.i
through section VI.D.1.a.v of the nationwide programmatic agreement codified at
47 CFR Part 1, Appendix C; or (ii) designated as a locally landmarked building,
property, site, or historic district by an ordinance adopted by the Village
pursuant to a preservation program that meets the requirements of the certified
local government program of the Illinois state historic preservation office or
where such certification of the preservation program by the Illinois state
historic preservation office is pending.
LAW: A federal or state statute, common law, code, rule, regulation, order, or
local ordinance or resolution.
MICRO WIRELESS FACILITY: A small wireless facility that is not larger in
dimension than twenty four inches (24") in length, fifteen inches (15") in
width, and twelve inches (12") in height and that has an exterior antenna, if
any, no longer than eleven inches (11").
MUNICIPAL UTILITY POLE: A utility pole owned or operated by the village in
public rights-of-way.
PERMIT: A written authorization required by the village to perform an action or
initiate, continue, or complete a project.
PERSON: An individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership,
association, trust, or other entity or organization.
PUBLIC SAFETY AGENCY: The functional division of the federal government, the
state, a unit of local government, or a special purpose district located in
whole or in part within this state, that provides or has authority to provide
firefighting, police, ambulance, medical, or other emergency services to
respond to and manage emergency incidents.
RATE: A recurring charge.
RIGHT-OF-WAY: The area on, below, or above a public roadway, highway, street,
public sidewalk, alley, or utility easement dedicated for compatible use.
Right-of-way does not include village-owned aerial lines.
SMALL WIRELESS FACILITY: A wireless facility that meets both of the following
qualifications: (i) each antenna is located inside an enclosure of no more than
six (6) cubic feet in volume or, in the case of an antenna that has exposed
elements, the antenna and all of its exposed elements could fit within an
imaginary enclosure of no more than six (6) cubic feet; and (ii) all other
wireless equipment attached directly to a utility pole associated with the
facility and any pre-existing associated equipment of the structure is
cumulatively no more than twenty eight (28) cubic feet in volume. The following
types of associated ancillary equipment are not included in the calculation of
equipment volume: electric meter, concealment elements, telecommunications
demarcation box, ground-based enclosures, grounding equipment, power transfer
switch, cut-off switch, and vertical cable runs for the connection of power and
other services.
UTILITY POLE: A pole or similar structure that is used in whole or in part by a
communications service provider or for electric distribution, lighting, traffic
control, or a similar function.
WIRELESS FACILITY: Equipment at a fixed location that enables wireless
communications between user equipment and a communications network, including:
(i) equipment associated with wireless communications; and (ii) radio
transceivers, antennas, coaxial or fiber-optic cable, regular and backup power
supplies, and comparable equipment, regardless of technological configuration.
Wireless facility includes small wireless facilities. Wireless facility does
not include: (i) the structure or improvements on, under, or within which the
equipment is collocated; or (ii) wireline backhaul facilities, coaxial or fiber
optic cable that is between wireless support structures or utility poles or
coaxial, or fiber optic cable that is otherwise not immediately adjacent to or
directly associated with an antenna.
WIRELESS INFRASTRUCTURE PROVIDER: Any person authorized to provide
telecommunications service in the state that builds or installs wireless
communication transmission equipment, wireless facilities, wireless support
structures, or utility poles and that is not a wireless services provider but
is acting as an agent or a contractor for a wireless services provider for the
application submitted to the village.
WIRELESS PROVIDER: A wireless infrastructure provider or a wireless services
provider.
WIRELESS SERVICES: Any services provided to the general public, including a
particular class of customers, and made available on a non-discriminatory basis
using licensed or unlicensed spectrum, whether at a fixed location or mobile,
provided using wireless facilities.
WIRELESS SERVICES PROVIDER: A person who provides wireless services.
WIRELESS SUPPORT STRUCTURE: A freestanding structure, such as a monopole;
tower, either guyed or self-supporting; billboard; or other existing or
proposed structure designed to support or capable of supporting wireless
facilities. Wireless support structure does not include a utility pole. (Ord.
2018-07, 7-16-2018; amd. Ord. 2019-03, 5-6-2019)
8-8-3: REGULATION OF SMALL WIRELESS FACILITIES:
(A)   Permitted Use: Small wireless facilities shall be classified as permitted
uses and subject to administrative review, except as provided in division (C)9
herein regarding height exceptions or variances, but not subject to zoning
review or approval if they are collocated (i) in rights-of-way in any zoning
district, or (ii) outside rights-of-way in property zoned exclusively for
commercial or industrial use.
(B)   Permit Required: An applicant shall obtain one or more permits from the
village to collocate a small wireless facility. An application shall be
received and processed, and permits issued shall be subject to the following
conditions and requirements:
   1.   Application Requirements: A wireless provider shall provide the
following information to the village, together with the village's small cell
wireless facilities permit application, as a condition of any permit
application to collocate small wireless facilities on a utility pole or
wireless support structure:
      (a)   Site specific structural integrity and, for a municipal utility
pole, make-ready analysis prepared by a structural engineer, as that term is
defined in section 4 of the structural engineering practice act of 1989;
      (b)   The location where each proposed small wireless facility or utility
pole would be installed and photographs of the location and its immediate
surroundings depicting the utility poles or structures on which each proposed
small wireless facility would be mounted or location where utility poles or
structures would be installed. This should include a depiction of the completed
facility;
      (c)   Specifications and drawings prepared by a structural engineer, as
that term is defined in section 4 of the structural engineering practice act of
1989, for each proposed small wireless facility covered by the application as
it is proposed to be installed;
      (d)   The equipment type and model numbers for the antennas and all other
wireless equipment associated with the small wireless facility;
      (e)   A proposed schedule for the installation and completion of each
small wireless facility covered by the application, if approved;
      (f)   Certification that the collocation complies with the collocation
requirements and conditions contained herein, to the best of the applicant's
knowledge; and
      (g)   In the event that the proposed small wireless facility is to be
