   CONSTRUCTION: The excavation of earth to provide for a basement or cellar;
and/or the addition to or removal from a lot or tract of land of earth or water
so as to prepare said lot or tract of land for the construction of a structure;
and/or the placing of construction materials in a permanent position and
fastened in a permanent manner; and/or the demolition, elimination or removal
of an existing structure in connection with such construction.
   CUL-DE-SAC: A residential street with only one outlet and entrance with an
appropriate terminal for safe and convenient reversal of traffic movement.
   DEDICATE; DEDICATED: To transfer the ownership of a right of way, street,
parcel of land, or improvement to the village or other unit of local government
without compensation.
   DRAINAGEWAY: A watercourse, gully, dry stream, creek bed, or ditch that
carries storm water runoff or which is fed by street or building gutters or by
storm water sewers, or that serves the purpose of draining water from the lands
adjacent to such watercourse, gully, dry stream, creek bed, or ditch.
   DWELLING: A building designed for residential living purposes and containing
one or more dwelling units and/or lodging units.
   DWELLING, DUPLEX: A dwelling containing two (2) dwelling units.
   DWELLING, MULTI-FAMILY: A dwelling containing three (3) or more dwelling
units.
   DWELLING, SINGLE-FAMILY: A dwelling containing one dwelling unit.
   DWELLING UNIT: One or more rooms constituting all or part of a dwelling
which are used exclusively as living quarters for one family and not more than
two (2) roomers or boarders, and which contain a stove, sink and other kitchen
facilities.
   EASEMENT: A grant by the property owner of the use of land by the public, a
corporation or persons for specified purposes.
   FAMILY: (A) An individual; or
   (B)   Two (2) or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption,
including foster children; or
   (C)   Not more than three (3) persons not so related.
   GRADE: The ascending or descending inclination with the horizontal of a site
or street, measured along the centerline of the street or right of way for a
street or right of way, expressed by stating the vertical rise or fall as a
percentage of the horizontal distance.
   LOT: The tract of land within a subdivision marked by the subdivider on the
plat as a numbered, lettered or other identified tract of land to be offered
for sale, dedication or development.
   LOT, CORNER: A lot located:
   (A)   At the junction of and abutting two (2) or more intersecting streets;
or
   (B)   At the junction of and abutting a street and the nearest shoreline or
high water line of a storm or floodwater runoff channel or basin; or
   (C)   At the junction of and abutting two (2) or more storm or floodwater
runoff channels or basins; or
   (D)   At the abutting point of abrupt change of a single street where the
interior angle is less than one hundred thirty five degrees (135°), and the
radius of the street centerline is less than one hundred feet (100').
   LOT, INTERIOR: A lot other than a corner lot.
   LOT LINES: The lines bounding a lot.
   MAJOR THOROUGHFARE PLAN: A part of the comprehensive plan which sets forth
the general location, alignment and dimensions and the identification and
classification of existing and proposed streets.
   OWNER, OWNERSHIP: An individual, firm, association, syndicate, partnership,
corporation, company, organization, trust or other legal entity having a
proprietary interest in a use, structure, lot or tract of land.
   PLANNED DEVELOPMENT: A tract of land which is developed as a unit under a
single ownership or control which includes two (2) or more main or principal
structures.
   PLAT: A map, plan or layout showing the subdivision of land into lots.
   PLAT, FINAL: The final engineering and architectural maps, drawings, and
supporting material indicating a subdivider's plan of a subdivision that, if
approved, may be filed and recorded with the Woodford County recorder's office.
   PLAT OFFICER: The person appointed by the village president with the consent
of the village board as the administrative assistant to the plan commission and
assigned to administering and enforcing the regulations and standards of this
title.
   PLAT, PRELIMINARY: The preliminary engineering and architectural maps,
drawings, and supporting material indicating the proposed layout of a
subdivision, but which cannot be recorded.
   PROPERTY: The general term denoting either singularly or in combination, an
area, lot or otherwise designated portion of land.
   PUBLIC WATER SYSTEM: A constructed system for the acquisition, purification
and transmission of potable water to individual users and which is approved by
the Illinois department of public health.
   RESIDENTIAL COUNTRY ESTATES SUBDIVISION: A subdivision consisting of a
minimum of ten (10) residential lots with no lot being less than one acre in
area and no lot having a frontage less than one hundred feet (100') unless such
lot is on a cul-de-sac, which must have a minimum frontage of fifty feet (50'),
and the streets are constructed as rural profile streets in accordance with
standard road and bridge specifications.
   RESUBDIVISION: Any change in an approved or recorded subdivision plat.
   RIGHT OF WAY: The entire dedicated tract or strip of land that is to be used
by the public for circulation or service.
   ROANOKE SUBDIVISION STANDARDS: The standard detailed drawings of types of
streets, curbs, and sewer appurtenances, etc., which are to be used in
subdivision construction and which are on file in the office of the
superintendent of public works or zoning officer.
   SANITARY SEWER: A constructed conduit for the collection and carrying of
liquid and solid sewage wastes other than stormwaters, to a sewage treatment
plant, and which is approved by the Illinois department of public health.
   SCHOOL: A building or group of buildings and all associated structures,
facilities and grounds in or on which instruction in subjects that are
fundamental and essential in general education, and are under the supervision
of the state of Illinois superintendent of schools.
   SIDEWALK: That paved portion of the right of way designed and intended for
the movement and use of pedestrian traffic.
   SLOPE: See definition of Grade.
   STORM SEWER: A constructed conduit for the collection and carrying of
surface waters to a drainage course.
   STREET: A road or way within a public or private right of way that affords
the principal means of access for vehicular traffic to abutting property.
Streets shall be provided in accordance with the appropriate street sections
contained in the "Roanoke Subdivision Standards". A street may be designated as
an avenue, a boulevard, drive, highway, expressway, lane, parkway, place, road,
thoroughfare or by other appropriate names. Streets are identified according to
type of use as follows:
   (A)   Thoroughfare Or Expressway: A street designed as a partially access
controlled roadway for carrying traffic up to maximum allowable speeds for the
primary purpose of moving high volumes of traffic through the village rather
than within it.
   (B)   Collector: A street generally designed to serve as a secondary traffic
generator for collecting and distributing traffic between thoroughfares or
expressways and minor streets, including principal entrance streets into a
residential development or streets for circulation within a residential
development.
   (C)   Minor: A street primarily designed to provide access to abutting
property; and to gather individual trips for delivery to a collector street.
   STRUCTURE: Anything constructed or erected with a fixed location on the
surface of the ground or underground, or affixed to something having a fixed
location on the surface of the ground whether temporary, semipermanent, or
permanent. Among other things, structures include buildings, walls, fences,
billboards, and signs.
   SUBDIVIDER: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, estate,
or other group or combination acting as a unit, dividing or proposing to divide
land in a manner that constitutes a "subdivision" as defined in this title.
Includes any agent of the subdivider who acts on behalf of or for the
subdivider in selling, leasing, or developing any interest, lot, parcel, unit,
site, or plat in the subdivision.
   SUBDIVISION; SUBDIVIDE: Any division or development of any part, lot, area
or tract of land by the subdivider into lots two (2) or more in number for the
purpose, whether immediate or future, of conveyance, transfer, improvement or
sale, with the appurtenant streets, alleys and easements, dedicated or intended
to be dedicated to public use or for the use of the purchasers or owners within
the part, lot, area or tract divided. The division of land into lots two (2) or
more in number, each lot with area greater than five (5) acres, and not
involving any new street, alley, easement or other means of access, shall not
be deemed a subdivision for the purpose of this title.
   ZONING CODE: The village zoning code as set forth in title 10 of this code.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005; amd. Ord. 2013-01, 1-21-2013)
11-1-5: INCORPORATION OF OTHER TITLES:
In addition to the provisions of this title, every subdivision made pursuant to
this title shall comply with all other provisions of this code, including the
zoning code and title 8 of this code. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
CHAPTER 2
PROCEDURE
SECTION:
11-2-1: Preliminary Considerations
11-2-2: Preapplication Procedure
11-2-3: Conditional Approval Of Preliminary Plat
11-2-4: Approval Of Final Plat
11-2-5: Small Subdivisions
11-2-6: Completion Of Public Improvements
11-2-7: Acceptance Of Public Improvements
11-2-8: Resubdivisions
11-2-9: Vacation Of Plats
11-2-1: PRELIMINARY CONSIDERATIONS:
   (A)   Regulatory:
      1.   No land which is located within the village or which is located
entirely or in part within the one and one-half (11/2) miles of the nearest
limits of the village shall, after the effective date of this title, be
subdivided and filed for record, nor any street laid out, nor any improvements
made to the land until the plat or plats of the subdivision shall have been
certified to and approved by action as specified herein.
      2.   The layout of the proposed subdivision shall be in conformity with
the comprehensive plan and the official map.
      3.   No land shall be subdivided for any use unless streets exist or will
be provided by the subdivider to provide access to all the subdivided parcels
of land.
   (B)   Advisory: The owner or subdivider may consult with the plat officer or
the plan commission prior to the preparation of the tentative plan of the
subdivision as set forth in section
11-2-2 of this chapter. Requirements for streets, school and recreational
sites; shopping centers; community facilities; sanitation, water supply and
drainage; and relationship to other developments, existing and proposed, in the
vicinity, will be analyzed in advance of the preparation of the preliminary
plat as part of the preapplication process.
   (C)   Application For Approval: A subdivider desiring approval of a plat of
any land lying within the jurisdiction of this title shall submit a written
application therefor to the plan commission. Such application shall be
submitted in compliance with the provisions of this title. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-
19-2005)
11-2-2: PREAPPLICATION PROCEDURE:
   (A)   Previous to the filing of an application for conditional approval of
the preliminary plat, the subdivider may submit to the plat officer
preapplication plans and data as specified in section
11-5-1 of this title. This step is not mandatory and shall not require a formal
application, or any fee or the filing of a plat with the plan commission.
   (B)   Upon receipt of the plans and data as described in subsection (A) of
this section, the plat officer shall review the plans and data and then shall
inform the subdivider whether the plans and data, as submitted or as modified,
meet the requirements of this title. When the plans and data do not meet such
objectives, the plat officer shall state the reasons in writing and deliver a
copy to the subdivider. The plat officer shall provide this response within
fifteen (15) working days after receipt of the preapplication plans and data.
   (C)   Upon the request of the subdivider, the plat officer shall also submit
the plans and data to the plan commission for review at its next regularly
scheduled meeting. The plat officer shall inform the subdivider of the time and
place of this meeting, and the subdivider shall be encouraged to attend that
meeting. Within thirty (30) days after the plan commission's meeting, the plan
commission shall inform the subdivider whether the plans and data, as submitted
or as modified, meet the requirements of this title. When the plan commission
finds that the plans and data do not meet such objectives, the plat officer, on
behalf of the plan commission, shall state the reasons in writing and deliver a
copy to the subdivider. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-2-3: CONDITIONAL APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT:
   (A)   Preliminary Plat: The subdivider shall prepare a preliminary plat
together with improvement plans and other supplementary material as specified
in section
11-5-2 of this title.
   (B)   Application For Submission: The subdivider shall complete a written
subdivision application for submission to the plan commission with the
preliminary plat. The subdivision application form shall be available at the
village hall during regular business hours or from the plat officer. The
subdivision application shall be in a form as established by the plan
commission.
   (C)   Submission Of Application: The subdivider shall submit three (3) full
size copies of the preliminary plat and supplementary material specified herein
and ten (10) reduced sized copies of the main preliminary plat, along with a
written subdivision application, to the plat officer for transmittal to the
plan commission at least ten (10) working days prior to the plan commission
meeting at which the preliminary plat and subdivision application are to be
considered by the plan commission. The subdivider shall also submit payment of
any fees or costs with the preliminary plat and application.
   (D)   Public Hearing: The plan commission shall hold a public hearing on the
preliminary plat and subdivision application.
   (E)   Review Of Preliminary Plat: The plat officer shall inform the
subdivider of the time and place of the hearing when the plan commission shall
review the preliminary plat and subdivision application. If the subdivider or
other interested party requests a special meeting of the plan commission to
review a subdivision application, then the cost of said special meeting shall
be paid by such requesting person. This cost shall include the salary or
stipend of each plan commission member and the plat officer for attending the
special meeting.
   (F)   Plan Commission Meeting; Copies Needed: The plat officer shall provide
a copy of the application and the preliminary plat and supporting materials to
each plan commission member at least seven (7) days prior to the plan
commission meeting when the preliminary plat and subdivision application will
be considered.
   (G)   Hearing Procedures:
      1.   The chairman (or acting chairman) of the plan commission shall
announce the public hearing on the proposed subdivision.
      2.   A summary of the proposed subdivision shall be provided to the plan
commission and the public by the chairman of the plan commission or his
designee, which shall include a brief description of the location of the
property and the proposed subdivision.
      3.   The subdivider shall then be permitted to describe the proposed
subdivision and any supporting information or documents, including the
preliminary plat and subdivision application, and to provide any evidence or
testimony supporting the proposed subdivision request.
      4.   During the subdivider's presentation in support of the proposed
subdivision, the chairman may allow plan commission members to also ask
questions or make comment as the chairman determines to be appropriate.
      5.   At the conclusion of the presentation of the proposed subdivision by
the subdivider, the chairman shall allow public comment, including evidence and
testimony from any opposition to the proposed subdivision. The chairman may
limit opposing parties to one or more representatives during the hearing when
appropriate for the proper and efficient conduct of the meeting.
      6.   At the conclusion of the presentation of evidence and comment in
support of or against the proposed subdivision, the chairman shall allow the
plan commission to further discuss and deliberate on the decision to recommend
approval or disapproval of the preliminary plat and subdivision application.
      7.   The plan commission may only recommend approval or disapproval of
the preliminary plat and subdivision application upon the concurring vote of a
majority of the plan commission members present provided a quorum exists to
conduct the hearing.
   (H)   Recommendation: After the public hearing, the plan commission shall
make a recommendation to approve or disapprove the preliminary plat and
subdivision application, provided that such recommendation shall be made within
ninety (90) days from the date of application or the filing of the last item of
required supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time period is
extended by mutual consent. Such recommendation shall be provided to the
village board within seven (7) days in writing, which shall include any
findings or conditions of such recommendation, if any.
   (I)   Disapproval Of Preliminary Plat: If the plan commission recommends
disapproval of the preliminary plat and subdivision application, the plan
commission shall provide the subdivider with a statement in writing setting
forth the reasons for its recommendation, specifying in detail how the proposed
subdivision does not meet the requirements of this title or fails to comply
with the official map. This written statement shall be provided to the
subdivider within the same ninety (90) day period. At the subdivider's request,
the subdivider may revise the preliminary plat and subdivision application and
resubmit these documents to the plan commission for approval without paying an
additional filing fee. Upon the subdivider's request to resubmit the
preliminary plat and subdivision application, this action shall constitute a
mutual agreement to extend the time periods for reviewing the preliminary plat
and subdivision application. The subdivider shall resubmit the revised
preliminary plat and subdivision application, including any necessary
supporting documents, at least seven (7) days prior to the next scheduled plan
commission meeting in order for the plan commission to review the revised
preliminary plat and subdivision application. During the resubmission process,
negotiations between the subdivider and the plan commission or the plat officer
may occur as to the type and extent of revisions to be made by the subdivider.
   (J)   Village Board Action: The village board shall have thirty (30) days
after its next regularly scheduled meeting following the plan commission's
recommendation to review the plan commission's recommendation and decide
whether to approve or disapprove the preliminary plat and subdivision
application. The village board may adopt the recommendation of the plan
commission upon a concurring vote of a majority of all village board members.
The village board can only take action that is adverse to the plan commission
by a vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all board members. If the preliminary plat and
subdivision application are approved by the village board, the subdivider may
proceed with preparing the final plat. If the preliminary plat and subdivision
application are disapproved, the subdivider may make revisions in the
preliminary plat or subdivision application and resubmit the revised
preliminary plat and subdivision application for approval. The revised
preliminary plat and subdivision application must first be resubmitted for
review by the plan commission in accordance with the procedures set forth
herein for the plan commission's recommendation before further review by the
village board. However, the plan commission shall have the discretion to
determine whether a new public hearing is necessary on the revised preliminary
plat and subdivision application prior to the plan commission's review of the
revised preliminary plat and subdivision application depending on the scope and
scale of revisions being made.
   (K)   Approval; Copies Needed: Upon the village board's approval of the
preliminary plat, two (2) copies of the original preliminary plat shall be
endorsed by the village president, with one copy being provided to the
subdivider and one copy being provided to the village clerk. The village
board's conditional approval of the preliminary plat does not qualify it for
recording, but shall be construed as an expression of approval of the general
layout submitted as a guide to the preparation of the final plat and an
assurance to the subdivider that the final plat will be approved if it conforms
to the terms of the conditionally approved preliminary plat.
   (L)   Fee: The subdivision application shall be accompanied by cash, a
check, or money order, in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). Such payment
shall be made payable to the village and provided to the plat officer, who
shall promptly provide the payment to village collector for deposit into the
general corporate fund of the village. A revised preliminary plat and
subdivision application shall not require the payment of an additional fee.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-2-4: APPROVAL OF FINAL PLAT:
   (A)   Within one year after conditional approval of the preliminary plat,
the subdivider shall submit the final plat and other supplementary material in
compliance with section
11-5-3 of this title, along with the appropriate fee, to the plat officer. If
the application for approval of the final plat is not submitted within this one
year period, it shall become null and void unless an extension of time is
applied for by the subdivider and granted by the village board.
   (B)   The subdivider shall complete a written application for approval of
the final plat for submission to the plan commission with the final plat. The
application form shall be available at the village hall during regular business
hours or from the plat officer. The application shall be in a form as
established by the plan commission.
   (C)   The subdivider shall submit four (4) full size copies of the final
plat and supplementary material specified herein and ten (10) reduced sized
copies of the main final plat, along with a written application, to the plat
officer for transmittal to the plan commission at least ten (10) working days
prior to the plan commission meeting at which the final plat and application
are to be considered by the plan commission. The final plat shall conform to
the preliminary plat as approved and it may constitute only that portion of the
approved preliminary plat which the subdivider proposes to record and develop
at the time; provided, however, that such portion conforms to all requirements
of this title. The subdivider may delay applying for approval of other parts of
the proposed subdivision beyond the initial one year period with approval from
the village board. If only a partial application is submitted, only the
portions receiving final approval shall be recorded.
   (D)   The plan commission shall hold a public hearing on the final plat and
application. The plat officer shall inform the subdivider of the time and place
of the hearing when the plan commission shall review the final plat. If the
subdivider or other interested party requests a special meeting of the plan
commission to review the final plat and application, then the cost of said
special meeting shall be paid by such requesting person. This cost shall
include the salary or stipend of each plan commission member and the plat
officer for attending the special meeting.
   (E)   The plat officer shall provide a copy of the application and the
preliminary plat and supporting materials to each plan commission member at
least seven (7) days prior to the plan commission meeting when the preliminary
plat and subdivision application will be considered.
   (F)   The public hearing procedures shall follow an abbreviated process
similar to the procedures set forth above for the preliminary plat and
subdivision application with same voting requirements. After the public
hearing, the plan commission shall make a recommendation to approve or
disapprove the final plat and application. The plan commission's review shall
focus on whether the final plat conforms with the preliminary plat and
subdivision application, with the technical requirements in chapters 4 and 5 of
this title, including the seal of a registered Illinois land surveyor or
engineer, and with the comprehensive plan and the official map in existence at
the time when the preliminary plat was approved. Such recommendation from the
plan commission shall be provided to the village board within seven (7) days in
writing, which shall include any findings or conditions of such recommendation,
if any.
   (G)   The village board shall review the plan commission's recommendation at
its next regularly scheduled meeting following receipt of the plan commission's
recommendation and shall decide whether to approve or disapprove the final plat
and application. The village board's review shall be confined to the same
considerations reviewed by the plan commission in accordance with the
provisions set forth in subsection (F) of this section. The review process of
the final plat and application shall not exceed sixty (60) days after
submission of the completed final plat and application unless a longer period
is mutually agreed upon by the subdivider and the village board.
   (H)   Upon the village board's approval of the final plat, four (4) copies
of the final plat shall be endorsed by the village president, with two (2)
copies being provided to the subdivider, one copy being provided to the village
clerk, and one copy being provided to the plat officer. Within ninety (90) days
after the approval of the final plat by the village board, the subdivider shall
file one copy of the final plat with the county recorder of Woodford County,
and if not so filed, it shall have no validity and shall not be recorded
without recertification by the village board. Upon demonstration of unique
circumstances or hardship, the village board may extend this ninety (90) day
period.
   (I)   The application for approval of the final plat shall be accompanied by
cash, a check, or money order, in the amount of fifty dollars ($50.00). Such
payment shall be made payable to the village and provided to the plat officer,
who shall promptly provide the payment to the village collector for deposit
into the general corporate fund of the village. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-2-5: SMALL SUBDIVISIONS:
A subdivider of any proposed subdivision having fewer than five (5) lots
fronting on an existing street that complies with the standards of this title
may, at the discretion of the plat officer, submit a subdivision application
and final plat for approval under the process set forth in section
11-2-4 of this chapter, along with any supplementary material and the
appropriate fee, without going through the steps required for the preliminary
plat set forth in section
11-2-3 of this chapter. However, the review by the plan commission and the
village board may include all aspects of the proposed subdivision (similar to
the review of a preliminary plat) rather than just the technical issues
described in the review process set forth in section
11-2-4 of this chapter. Furthermore, the village board may determine, in its
complete discretion, that the full review process as set forth in sections 11-
2-3 and 11-2-4 of this chapter must be followed. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-2-6: COMPLETION OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
The subdivider shall substantially complete construction of all public
improvements set forth in the final plat no later than two (2) years after the
village board's approval of the final plat. Upon a showing of undue hardship by
the subdivider or circumstances beyond the control of the subdivider, the
subdivider may request that the village board grant an extension of the
completion period for up to an additional one year period. Provided no danger
to the health, safety, or general welfare would be created by this extension,
the extension may be granted at the complete discretion of the village board
and upon any conditions set forth by the village board. If at the expiration of
the two (2) year completion period, or any approved extension thereof, the
public improvements have not been completed or properly installed, the village
may proceed to properly complete the public improvements utilizing the surety
bond or other financial security provided by the subdivider. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-
19-2005)
11-2-7: ACCEPTANCE OF PUBLIC IMPROVEMENTS:
The approval of the final plat by the plan commission or the village board
shall not constitute acceptance by the village of any public improvements set
forth in a final plat, irrespective of any act by any officer, agent,
representative, or employee of the village with regard to the public
improvements. Upon completion of the public improvements, the subdivider shall
submit to the village a signed certification of compliance from a properly
licensed engineer that all public improvements set forth on the final plat have
been properly installed in accordance with the requirements of this title.
Provided the village board concludes that the certification of compliance is
accurate, which shall include review of the public improvements by the village
engineer, the village board shall take formal action to accept the public
improvements. If, upon the completion of the one year guarantee period set
forth in subsection
11-5-3(D) of this title, the public improvements are free of defects, the
village board shall take action to release the bond or other financial security
provided by the subdivider under subsection
11-5-3(D) of this title. The village engineer shall confirm whether the public
improvements are free of defects upon the completion of the one year guarantee
period before the village board takes any action to release the subdivider's
bond or other financial security provided under subsection
11-5-3(D) of this title. If, upon the completion of the one year guarantee
period set forth in subsection
11-5-3(D) of this title, the public improvements are not free of defects as
determined by the village engineer, the village board shall take action to
remedy such defects utilizing the surety bond or other financial security
provided by the subdivider. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-2-8: RESUBDIVISIONS:
If changes are made in any approved or recorded subdivision plat to: a) any
street layout, b) any area reserved therein for public use, or c) any lot line,
or if the changes being made to any approved or recorded subdivision plat
affect another legally recorded plat, then such changes shall be approved by
the plan commission and the village board by the same procedures, rules, and
regulations provided in this title for approval of subdivisions. (Ord. 2005-09,
12-19-2005)
11-2-9: VACATION OF PLATS:
A subdivider of any proposed subdivision may seek to vacate a plat or a portion
of a plat at any time before the sale of any lot therein by a written
instrument declaring the subdivision plat to be vacated, with a copy of the
subdivision plat attached thereto. Such vacation instrument must then be
approved by the plan commission and the village board by the same procedures,
rules, and regulations provided in this title for approval of subdivisions. The
village board may reject any vacation request if approving the vacation would
abridge or destroy any public rights in any public uses, improvements, streets,
or alleys provided in the subdivision plat. If the vacation request is properly
approved by the village board, the vacation instrument shall then be recorded
and shall thereby divest the public of any rights in any public uses,
improvements, streets, or alleys provided in or dedicated by the subdivision
plat. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
CHAPTER 3
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
11-3-1: Streets
11-3-2: Easements
11-3-3: Blocks
11-3-4: Lots
11-3-5: Street Names
11-3-1: STREETS:
The course, width, grade, and location of all streets shall conform to the
comprehensive plan and the official map and shall be considered in their
relation to existing and planned streets, to topographic conditions, to public
convenience and safety, and in their appropriate relation to the proposed uses
of the land to be served by such streets and shall conform to the following
design standards:
   (A)   Where not shown on the comprehensive plan, the arrangement of streets
in a subdivision shall be revised by the plan commission and shall either:
      1.   Provide for the continuation or projection of existing principal
streets in surrounding areas; or
      2.   Conform to the major thoroughfare plan where applicable; or
      3.   Conform to topographic or other conditions where continuance or
projection of existing streets is impractical.
   (B)   Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic
will be discouraged.
   (C)   Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed
expressway or a railroad right of way or rail crossings, access thereto shall
be limited to a minimum number of intersections and such access intersections
with expressways and/or rail crossings shall be determined with due regard for
sight distance, distance between intersections, approach grades and
requirements for future grade separations. No street grade shall be less than
one- half of one percent (0.5%) or more than ten percent (10%).
   (D)   Street intersections with centerline offsets of less than one hundred
feet (100') shall be prohibited.
   (E)   A tangent at least one hundred feet (100') long shall be introduced
between curves on arterial and collector streets where the curve radius is less
than five hundred feet (500').
   (F)   Where connecting street lines deflect from each other more than ten
degrees (10°), they shall be connected with a curve with a radius adequate to
assure sight distance.
   (G)   Streets shall be laid out to intersect as nearly as possible at right
angles and no street shall intersect any other street at less than seventy
degrees (70°).
   (H)   Alleys shall not be permitted on property intended or zoned for
residential districts. Alleys may be provided on property intended or zoned for
commercial or industrial use subject to the following provisions:
      1.   The alley is set at the rear of the subject lot or tract and shall
be paved.
      2.   The minimum right of way shall be twenty feet (20').
      3.   Where the alley intersects with another street or alley, corners
shall be constructed in a manner to permit safe vehicular movement.
      4.   No construction of any type shall be permitted on the right of way.
      5.   Dead end alleys shall be avoided where possible, but if unavoidable,
shall be provided with adequate turnaround facilities as determined by the
village engineer. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
   (I)   The minimum street right of way widths and pavement widths shall be as
follows:
 Right Of Way Width (Feet) Pavement Width (Feet)
                                Right Of Way Width (Feet) Pavement Width (Feet)
Alleys                          20                        16
Minor street                    60                        30
Minor commercial/industrial     60                        30
street
Collector street                60                        30
Commercial/industrial collector 60                        32
street
Thoroughfare                    80                        44
Residential country estates     60                        60
street
 
Any modification to these provisions governing street widths as approved under
chapter 7 of this title shall conform to the standards for urban roads as
specified in the Illinois department of transportation "Manual Of Street And
Highway Improvement Standards". (Ord. 2013-01, 1-21-2013)
   (J)   Dead end streets, designed to be so permanently, shall not be longer
than six hundred feet (600') and shall be provided with a turnaround having an
outside surface diameter of at least ninety feet (90') and a right of way line
diameter of at least one hundred feet (100').
   (K)   Private streets and reserve strips shall not be permitted in platting
subdivisions except as set forth in this section. Every subdivision shall be
served from a publicly dedicated street. Reserve strips controlling access to
streets, shall be placed under the control of the village or township and be
under such conditions as approved by the governing body. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-
2005)
11-3-2: EASEMENTS:
Easements across lots, centered on rear or side lot lines, or where necessary
for utilities, watercourse, drainageway channel or stream shall not be less
than ten feet (10') wide, and shall be shown on the plat. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-
2005)
11-3-3: BLOCKS:
   (A)   The length, width and shape of blocks shall be determined with due
regard to:
      1.   Provision of adequate building sites for the special type of use
contemplated.
      2.   Requirements as to lot size and dimensions.
      3.   Needs for convenient access, circulation, control and safety of
street traffic.
      4.   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
   (B)   Block lengths shall not exceed one thousand three hundred twenty feet
(1,320') nor be less than five hundred feet (500').
   (C)   In cases where the block length exceeds six hundred feet (600') and
where deemed essential by the plan commission to provide pedestrian circulation
to schools, playgrounds, shopping centers and other community facilities, an
easement dedicated to the village or township for a crosswalk shall be provided
of not less than ten feet (10') wide.
   (D)   Block width shall be wide enough to allow two (2) tiers of lots of a
minimum depth of one hundred feet (100'). (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-3-4: LOTS:
   (A)   All provisions of the zoning code concerning lots shall apply
including lot area, width and depth. The standards of the specific zoning
district of the area at the time of submission of the final plat shall be
followed in determining minimum lot requirements.
   (B)   The lot shape and orientation shall be appropriate for the location of
the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated.
   (C)   Double frontage, and reverse frontage lots, shall be avoided except
where essential to provide separation of residential development from major
streets or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation.
   (D)   Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to
street lines. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-3-5: STREET NAMES:
A proposed street which is in alignment with or joins an existing and named
street shall bear the name of the existing street. In no case shall the
proposed name of the street duplicate the name of an existing street within the
village or the area covered by the comprehensive plan and the official map. The
village clerk shall maintain a list of all street names for the village and the
area covered by the comprehensive plan and the official map, which shall be
available for public inspection.
The use of the suffix "street", "avenue", "boulevard", "driveway", "place" or
"court" or similar description shall not be a distinction sufficient to
constitute compliance with this section. House numbers shall be assigned in
accordance with the provisions of the village or Woodford County, depending
upon the location of the subdivision. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
CHAPTER 4
REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
11-4-1: Monuments
11-4-2: Streets And Utilities
11-4-3: Sanitary Sewers
11-4-4: Water
11-4-5: Storm Drainage
11-4-6: Sump Pump Drainage
11-4-7: Completion Of Required Improvements
11-4-1: MONUMENTS:
Metal markers or monuments shall be placed by an Illinois registered land
surveyor at all lot corners, block corners, angle points, points of tangency or
curves in streets, and at such intermediate points as shall be required by the
plat officer. Metal markers, which may be metal pipes or rods, shall be a
minimum of one-half inch (1/2") in diameter and eighteen inches (18") in
length.
At least two (2) permanent reference monuments shall be placed at locations
within each subdivision. The monuments shall be made of stone or reinforced
concrete, being at a minimum three feet (3') in length and six inches (6")
thick with a suitable centerpoint, except as otherwise may be approved by the
plat officer. Such monuments, as near as possible, shall be placed so as to be
flush with the established finished grade in a manner that they cannot be moved
by frost.
All markers and monuments shall be set in the ground before streets and alleys
are accepted by the village. The placement of all markers and monuments shall
be the responsibility of the subdivider. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-4-2: STREETS AND UTILITIES:
   (A)   Streets (and alleys where provided) shall be completed to grades shown
on plats, profiles and cross sections as needed and approved by the plan
commission.
   (B)   Streets and alleys shall be graded, surfaced, and improved to the
dimensions and standards herein.
   (C)   Prior to placing the street surface, adequate subsurface drainage for
the streets and all utilities under the streets shall be provided or installed
by the subdivider. Upon the completion of the street and alley improvements,
plats and profiles as built shall be filed with the plan commission.
   (D)   Streets shall have such right of way and pavement widths as specified
in chapter 3 of this title. When existing streets are located within the
subdivision or adjacent to the subdivision, the subdivider shall provide for
additional right of way width to equal the minimum required by subsection
11-3-1(I) of this title; provided, however, that when such existing streets
abut the subdivision on one side only, only one-half (1/2) of the difference
between the existing right of way width and the width as specified in chapter 3
of this title shall be provided by the subdivider. The plan commission shall
make such requirements as to type of pavement and as to the type of
construction for curbs, gutters and sidewalks as it deems to be necessary for
such street; provided, such requirements are consistent with this title and the
Illinois department of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And
Bridge Construction".
   (E)   The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with street signs, the
type, height, and design as approved by the plan commission, at the
intersections of all streets. The plan commission may have the village install
the street signs with the subdivider being required to pay the cost of all
materials.
   (F)   Utility and street improvements shall be provided for each new
subdivision in accordance with standards and requirements described in the
following provisions:
      1.   Unless the subdivision is unable to connect to village water and
sewer systems as determined by village officials, water supply and sanitary
sewer disposal shall be provided as follows:
 
Dwelling Type Sanitary Sewage Disposal Water Supply
All dwellings village sewer system     village water supply
 
      2.   Street cross sections shall comply with the specifications and
standards provided herein and the Illinois department of transportation
"Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", unless otherwise
determined by the plan commission, the township road commission or the county
superintendent of highways. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
      3.   Grading and improving of streets, except streets in a residential
country estate subdivision and thoroughfares, shall be as per approved plans
and profiles, equal to the minimum widths required by subsection
11-3-1(I) of this title, and constructed in accordance with the "Roanoke
Subdivision Standards". Streets in a residential country estate subdivision and
thoroughfares shall otherwise comply with the specifications and standards
provided herein and the Illinois department of transportation "Standard
Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction". (Ord. 2013-01, 1-21-2013)
      4.   Pavement base, subbase, and surface of streets shall meet the
minimum standards and specifications as set forth in the Illinois department of
transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction",
including any supplements or revisions thereto. Streets constructed outside the
corporate limits of the village but within the jurisdiction of this title shall
also conform to any standards or regulations applicable to the township or
county as applicable.
      5.   Storm sewer system and other drainage improvements shall be provided
as per approved plans and profiles.
      6.   Curbs shall be provided for all streets along the outside pavement
line, except as noted below for an approved residential country estate
subdivision, and shall be constructed as follows: Portland cement concrete curb
integral with gutter. A residential country estate subdivision shall be
required to provide curbs and gutters as set forth under this provision if such
subdivision is created through the extension of an existing street with curbs
and gutters or if, as determined by the plan commission or village board,
drainage or other characteristics of the property create an unreasonably
dangerous impact on persons or vehicles using the streets or on adjoining
properties; otherwise, the residential country estate subdivision will not be
required to provide curbs and gutters provided that ample drainage is provided
along the streets that are constructed in accordance with the standards for
rural profile streets as set forth in accordance with the Illinois department
of transportation "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction".
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
      7.   Sidewalks shall be provided on two (2) sides of all streets, except
sidewalks shall not be required in an approved residential country estate
subdivision. Sidewalks shall be at least five feet (5') in width, of portland
cement concrete four inches (4") thick, placed on suitably compacted base,
located within the dedicated right of way. Sidewalks in a commercial or
industrial area where the buildings are built immediately adjacent to the front
or street property line shall be at least ten feet (10') in width outward from
the curb line. Sidewalk alignment on lots abutting other subdivisions or lots
having existing sidewalks shall be so constructed to provide continuous and
contiguous pavement. The construction of sidewalks in a subdivision approved
under this title shall be done by the subdivider and section
 8-1-1 of this code shall not apply to the construction or maintenance of
sidewalks required under this title until two (2) years after the sidewalk has
been constructed in accordance with this provision of this title and the
sidewalk has been accepted by the plat officer. (Ord. 2013-01, 1-21-2013)
      8.   All utility lines, including electrical and gas lines,
telecommunication lines, and cable television lines, shall be installed
underground and along either the front or rear lot lines. All main lines shall
be installed in a utility easement. All transfer boxes and junctions shall be
located on a rear lot utility easement whenever possible so as not to be
unsightly and hazardous to the public.
      9.   Street lighting shall be provided for each residential subdivision
with either streetlights or yard lights. If streetlights are installed, they
shall be installed at every intersection and along straightaways at a minimum
spacing of one every five hundred feet (500'). Alternatively, the subdivider
can impose a restrictive covenant requiring a yard light be placed in every
lot, which shall operate automatically from sunset to sunrise. Such restrictive
covenant shall require all yard lights to be located in the yard ten feet (10')
from the front lot line and within three feet (3') of the driveway. All wiring
for street or yard lights shall be buried underground.
   (G)   When all of the streets and other facilities required above are
completed within the platted area in accordance with the above provisions and
approved by the authorities having jurisdiction, they shall be submitted for
acceptance for maintenance by either the village or the township highway
commissioner; this acceptance to be evidenced by a stipulation and
certification of completion of work executed by the village or the township
highway commissioner, which shall be recorded in the office of the recorder of
deeds of Woodford County. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-4-3: SANITARY SEWERS:
   (A)   A public sanitary sewage collection and treatment system shall be
provided as follows:
      1.   Where the subdivision is reasonably accessible to the village
sanitary sewer system and is so located that it can be annexed to the village,
the subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete sanitary sewage
collection system connected to such existing public sanitary sewer system.
      2.   Where no such connection to the village system can be made, the
subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete sanitary sewage
collection system and treatment plant, approved by the Illinois environmental
protection agency, with adequate provision for the maintenance of such plant.
   (B)   The sanitary sewer system shall be installed in accordance with the
plans and specifications that have been submitted by the subdivider and
approved by the duly appointed village engineer, which shall comply with the
most recent edition of the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois".
   (C)   Upon completion of the sanitary sewer system installation, a
registered professional engineer shall certify that the sanitary sewer system
complies with all the standards required by the village and the Illinois
environmental protection agency. One certified copy of the plans for such
sanitary sewer system as built shall be filed with the village. The subdivider
shall obtain any required permits from any other agency having jurisdiction,
including the Illinois environmental protection agency.
   (D)   Storm sewers and sump pump drainage lines shall not be connected to
sanitary sewers. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-4-4: WATER:
   (A)   The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete water
main supply system consisting of mains at least six inches (6") in diameter,
which shall be connected to the village water system. The water supply system
shall also include appropriate fittings, valves, and fire hydrants.
   (B)   The plans for the installation of a water main supply system shall be
prepared by the subdivider with the cooperation of the village water department
and the village engineer. Upon completion of the water supply installation, one
copy of the plans for such system as built shall be filed with the village. The
subdivider shall obtain any required permits from any other agency having
jurisdiction, including the Illinois environmental protection agency.
   (C)   The water supply system shall be installed in accordance with the
plans and specifications that have been submitted by the subdivider and
approved by the duly appointed village engineer, which shall comply with the
most recent edition of the "Standard Specifications For Water And Sewer Main
Construction In Illinois".
   (D)   Fire hydrants shall be provided at no more than six hundred foot
(600') intervals.
   (E)   The maximum line tap for a residence into the village waterline is a
one inch (1") tap line. No tap line to a residence of any type, single-family
or multiple-family, may exceed one inch (1") unless specific permission is
granted by the modification process as set forth in chapter 7 of this title.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-4-5: STORM DRAINAGE:
The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with an adequate storm water
drainage system to properly drain the subdivision and all areas upstream that
are tributary to the subdivision in accordance with the following
specifications:
   (A)   The storm water runoff rate from the subdivision shall not exceed the
storm water runoff rate from the area in its natural undeveloped state.
   (B)   The storm water runoff rate shall not exceed the available capacity of
the downstream drainage system. Existing natural waterways in a subdivision
shall be preserved or improved as part of the storm water drainage system.
   (C)   Easements necessary for the storm water drainage system shall be
provided by the subdivider for portions of the storm water drainage system not
included within a street right of way.
   (D)   If any existing natural waterways, swales, creeks, or storm sewer
systems will become overburdened with storm water because of any proposed new
subdivision or development, then the subdivider will be required to construct
"on site" improvements consisting of the following:
      1.   A "storm water detention area" shall be constructed on property of
the subdivision or development that will ensure that peak storm water runoff
flow rates after development are not in excess of those that prevailed prior to
said subdivision or development.
      2.   The "storm water detention area" shall be self-draining so that no
water pools remain after the draining process and shall drain in such a manner
as to minimize the impact of the storm water on the downstream property.
   (E)   No structures shall be constructed within the storm water discharge
channels or a detention area.
   (F)   The drainage line shall be installed in accordance with the plans and
specifications that have been submitted by the subdivider and approved by the
duly appointed village engineer.
   (G)   The subdivider shall obtain any required permits from any other agency
having jurisdiction, including the Illinois environmental protection agency.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-4-6: SUMP PUMP DRAINAGE:
The subdivider shall provide a sump pump drainage line that serves each lot in
the subdivision, and each lot shall be provided with a connection to the sump
pump drainage line. The sump pump drainage line shall be designed to receive
effluent from sump pumps and shall meet the following specifications:
   (A)   The drainage line shall be constructed of PVC pipe having a minimum
diameter of six inches (6"), unless the anticipated effluent shall require a
larger diameter, and shall be installed below the frost line.
   (B)   The drainage line shall be designed to discharge into either a storm
sewer or a drainage ditch.
   (C)   Manholes or clean out shall be provided on the drainage line at a
maximum spacing of five hundred feet (500') and shall be located in the street
right of way or an easement accessible for maintenance. For subdivisions
outside the village limits, the maintenance of the drainage line shall be the
responsibility of the property owner.
   (D)   The drainage line shall be installed in accordance with the plans and
specifications that have been submitted by the subdivider and approved by the
duly appointed village engineer.
   (E)   The subdivider shall obtain any required permits from any other agency
having jurisdiction, including the Illinois environmental protection agency.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-4-7: COMPLETION OF REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS:
No building of any type may be begun and no zoning use permit issued under the
zoning code until all sewer, water, and drainage systems of said subdivision
are completed, inspected, and approved by the duly appointed village engineer.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
CHAPTER 5
PLATS AND DATA
SECTION:
11-5-1: Preapplication Plans And Data
11-5-2: Preliminary Plat
11-5-3: Final Plat
11-5-4: Subdivider Accompanied By Engineer
11-5-1: PREAPPLICATION PLANS AND DATA:
If the subdivider submits preapplication information for a proposed subdivision
previous to the filing of an application for approval of the preliminary plat,
the subdivider shall submit to the plat officer and the plan commission the
following plans and data as part of the preapplication information:
   (A)   General information data and location map, which shall include the
general topography of the site and shall describe or outline existing
covenants, zoning, land characteristics, community facilities and utilities,
streets, schools, parks, playgrounds, and commercial and industrial
developments.
   (B)   Sketch plan showing in simple sketch form the proposed layout of
streets, lots, utilities, and other features and improvements in relation to
existing conditions. This information shall also include any proposed
protective covenants, capital improvements, and public sites in addition to the
streets and other public service facilities. This sketch may be freehand on a
print of a topographic map. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-5-2: PRELIMINARY PLAT:
A preliminary plat of the subdivision shall be accurately drawn to a scale of
one hundred feet to one inch (100' = 1"). The preliminary plat shall be
eighteen inches by twenty four inches (18" x 24") in size or in six inch (6")
multiples thereof.
   (A)   The following data shall be included on the preliminary plat:
      1.   Public Land Survey: The preliminary plat shall be tied to at least
one point of the public land survey system.
      2.   Existing Boundary Lines, Monuments, And Lot Lines: By bearings and
distances, shown in number of feet to the nearest hundredth expressed in
decimals (not fractions).
      3.   Existing Easements: Location, width, and purpose.
      4.   Existing Streets: On and adjacent to the tract by name, right of way
width, location, type, street width, and elevation of surfacing; plus bridges,
curbs, gutters, culverts, and sidewalks.
      5.   Existing Utilities: On and adjacent to the tract; location, size and
invert elevation of sanitary sewers, storm sewers, and water mains; location of
gas lines; fire hydrants, electric and telephone lines and poles, television
cable and telecommunication lines, and streetlights; if any of the above are
not available at site indicate direction and distance to the nearest ones and
furnish statements of availability.
      6.   Other Existing Conditions: Watercourses, bodies of water, marshes,
rock outcrop, wooded areas, parks, dwellings, buildings, facilities, public and
quasi-public uses, and other significant features.
      7.   Proposed Public Improvements: Streets or other major improvements
planned by public authorities for future construction on or near the tract.
      8.   Adjacent Property: Names of adjacent subdivisions and tract names
with name of record owner(s), conditions of the adjacent land with approximate
gradient and direction of elevations and slope.
      9.   Ground Elevations: On mean sea level datum plane show contours at
vertical intervals as follows:
         Slope of three percent (3%) or less: one foot (1') interval contour
map.
         Slope over three percent (3%) but less than six percent (6%): two foot
(2') interval contour map.
         Slope over six percent (6%): five foot (5') interval contour map.
      10.   Title And Certificates: Present tract designation; present zoning
classification; official designation under which subdivision is to be recorded;
names and addresses of owners of subdivision tract(s); acreage, scale, north
point, datum, bench marks, and certification of registered professional
engineer or registered professional surveyor and date of survey.
   (B)   The preliminary plat shall show all existing conditions required above
in topographic data and show all proposals, including, but not necessarily
limited to, the following:
      1.   Streets: Names, right of way and street widths, approximate grades
and gradients.
      2.   Easements: Location, width, and purpose.
      3.   Utilities: Location, type and approximate size; this information may
be shown on a separate exhibit.
      4.   Lots: Lot lines, area in acreage, numbers, and block numbers.
      5.   Sites (Nonpublic): If any, for shopping centers, churches, industry,
multi-family dwellings, or any other nonpublic use exclusive of single-family
dwellings.
      6.   Sites (Public): If any, to be dedicated or reserved for parks,
playgrounds, schools, or other public uses.
      7.   Setback Lines: Give dimensions of minimum setback lines.
      8.   Side Data: Including number of residential lots, typical lot size,
and acres in other public and nonpublic land uses.
      9.   Indicators: Title, scale, north arrow and plat date. (Ord. 2005-09,
12-19-2005)
      10.   Other Preliminary Plans: The preliminary plat shall be accompanied
by preliminary construction plans showing existing ground surface and proposed
street grades; typical cross sections of the streets and sidewalks; a
preliminary plan of proposed sanitary sewers, storm and surface water drainage
systems and sewers, and water mains with grades and size indicated and
construction details.
The village engineer shall review the construction plans. The subdivider shall
reimburse the village for the cost of the engineering fees for reviewing the
construction plans, prior to preliminary plan approval. (Ord. 2013-01, 1-21-
2013)
      11.   Draft Of Protective Covenants: Whereby the subdivider proposes to
regulate land use in the subdivision and otherwise protect the proposed
development.
      12.   Zoning: Show proposed new zoning classification of the subdivision
and adjacent area. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-5-3: FINAL PLAT:
The final plat shall meet the following specifications:
   (A)   Proposed Preliminary Plat: The final plat may include all or only a
part of the area of the preliminary plat as proposed in the application.
   (B)   Drawing: The original drawing of the final plat of the subdivision
shall be eighteen inches by twenty four inches (18" x 24"), or in six inch (6")
multiples thereof. It shall be drawn at a scale of one hundred feet (100') to
the inch. Four (4) black or blue line prints and one reproducible print shall
be submitted with the original final plat.
   (C)   Required Data: The following information shall be shown on the final
plat:
      1.   Primary control points or descriptions and "ties" to such control
points to the public land survey system, to which all dimensions, angles,
bearings and similar data on the final plat shall be referred.
      2.   Tract boundary lines, right of way lines of streets, easements and
other rights of way, and property lines of residential lots and other sites;
with accurate dimensions, bearings or deflection angles, and radii, arcs and
central angle of all curves.
      3.   Name and right of way width of each street or other rights of way.
      4.   Location and right of way widths of existing and/or platted streets
adjacent to the tract.
      5.   Location, dimensions and purpose of all easements.
      6.   Consecutive numbers for each lot or site within all subdivisions
having the same name.
      7.   Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated
or reserved.
      8.   Minimum setback line on all lots and other sites.
      9.   Location and description of monuments.
      10.   Names of record owners of adjoining unplatted land.
      11.   Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land
by book and page.
      12.   Certification by Illinois registered land surveyor as to accuracy
of survey and plat.
      13.   Statement of owner certifying that he has title to land being
subdivided.
      14.   Statement by owner dedicating streets, rights of way, easements and
any sites for public uses.
      15.   Title, scale, north arrow and date.
      16.   Such other certificates, affidavits, endorsements or dedications as
may be required by applicable codes, ordinances and/or statutes pertaining to
zoning, dedicated streets and drainage facilities.
   (D)   Performance Bonding: At the time when an application for final plat
approval is submitted under the provisions of this title, the subdivider shall
also submit proof that a good and sufficient surety bond has been filed with
the village clerk in a penal sum sufficient to cover the estimate by a
qualified engineer of the probable expenditures, with such estimate approved by
the village engineer, necessary to enable the subdivider to construct all
public improvements in a manner that shall conform with the standards of
construction established pursuant to the provisions of this title and
guaranteeing the public improvements against faulty materials and workmanship
for a one year period following written acceptance of the public improvements
by the village board. The bond shall be conditioned upon faithful adherence to
the rules and regulations contained in this title. In lieu of a surety bond,
upon approval by the village board (which shall be completely within the
discretion of the village board), the subdivider may provide a cash bond or
other financial security or surety payable to the village in an equivalent
amount to the amount required for the surety bond, which will be held by the
village until the successful completion of the one year guarantee period.
   (E)   Protective Covenants: Whenever the subdivider imposes any protective
covenants on subsequent owners of any portion of the area covered by the final
plat, a copy of the protective covenants in recordable form shall be submitted
with the final plat. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-5-4: SUBDIVIDER ACCOMPANIED BY ENGINEER:
Whenever a subdivider is to appear before the plan commission or the village
board on a matter related to subdivision request or application, including any
public hearings or review of preliminary or final plats, the subdivider should
be accompanied by an engineer in order that said engineer can answer any
questions posed by the plan commission or the village board. If said subdivider
is not accompanied by an engineer, then the plan commission or the village
board shall, at their discretion, postpone any matters concerning the
subdivider's subdivision, until the subdivider's engineer is available for such
meeting. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
CHAPTER 6
OFFICIAL MAP
SECTION:
11-6-1: Purpose
11-6-2: Designation Of Public Sites, Open Spaces
11-6-3: Amendments Of Official Map
11-6-1: PURPOSE:
The official map is hereby made a part of this title by reference and is
intended to designate public sites and streets that may be required by the plan
commission or the village board in any proposed subdivision plats. The
designation of such public sites on final subdivision plats may be required
prior to approval provided that such public site is indicated on the official
map for fifteen (15) days prior to the date of application for final approval
of the subdivision plat. Limits to which such areas designated for public use
on the official map may be restricted from development are as specified herein.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-6-2: DESIGNATION OF PUBLIC SITES, OPEN SPACES:
Whenever the requirements provided by this title, including the official map,
shall indicate the necessity for providing a school site, park site, roadway,
or street or other public lands within any proposed subdivision for which
approval has been requested, and no such provision has been made therefor, the
plan commission or the village board may require that lands be designated for
such public purpose before approving such plat. Factors that may be reviewed by
the plan commission or the village board in determining the need for such
public sites in a proposed subdivision shall include the size, scope,
population density, or other characteristics of the proposed subdivision.
Whenever a final plat of subdivision, or part thereof, has been approved by the
village board as complying with the official map and a public site is
designated therein, the subdivider shall dedicate the subdivider's
proportionate share of the land comprising the public site to the appropriate
governmental body. The village board shall determine the subdivider's
proportionate share of land to be dedicated under this provision based upon the
size and population density of the proposed subdivision. Thereafter, the
corporate authorities of the governmental body having jurisdiction over the
particular public site shall purchase the remainder of such land comprising the
designated public site, at fair market value, within one year from date of
approval of such plat, and if it does not do so within such period of one year,
the land so designated may then be used by the owners thereof in any other
manner consistent with this title, including the official map and the zoning
code. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-6-3: AMENDMENTS OF OFFICIAL MAP:
Amendments to the official map shall be made in the manner prescribed by law,
which shall include a public hearing on the proposed amendment before either
the plan commission or the village board. Any public or semipublic agency may
request the establishment of a future public site or easement on the official
map. When such proposed site is not included in the comprehensive plan, the
requesting agency shall indicate to the plan commission the need for the site
in the particular location specified. The plan commission shall study the
request and shall report to the village board as to the consistency of the
proposed site with the comprehensive plan. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
CHAPTER 7
ADMINISTRATION; ENFORCEMENT
SECTION:
11-7-1: Responsibility For Administration
11-7-2: Plat Officer
11-7-3: Interpretation
11-7-4: Conflict
11-7-5: Validity; Severability
11-7-6: Saving Provision
11-7-7: Amendment
11-7-8: Modification
11-7-9: Violations; Penalties
11-7-1: RESPONSIBILITY FOR ADMINISTRATION:
The authority for administration of this title is hereby vested in the: a) plat
officer and b) joint zoning and planning board. The joint zoning and planning
board may also be designated as the "plan commission" in this title. The plat
officer shall have the authority and responsibility as set forth in this title,
subject to the authority of the plan commission and the limitations set forth
in this title. Also, the duly appointed village engineer shall provide
assistance as indicated in the respective provisions of this title. (Ord. 2005-
09, 12-19-2005)
11-7-2: PLAT OFFICER:
   (A)   The plat officer shall be the village's zoning officer as properly
appointed by the village president in accordance with the zoning code. The plat
officer may be provided with assistance by other persons as the village board
may direct.
   (B)   The plat officer shall administer and enforce this title and shall
carry out and perform duties as follows:
      1.   Receive and file for public record all applications and pertinent
data for preliminary and final plats, including the preliminary and final
plats, and providing such information and documentation to the plan commission;
      2.   Schedule any public hearings for the plan commission for
consideration of applications or petitions for amendments or modifications to
this title;
      3.   Conduct inspections to determine compliance with this title;
      4.   Investigate alleged violations of this title;
      5.   Inform subdividers and other persons or entities in violation of
this title of the provisions and requirements of this title with which they are
in noncompliance and the available remedies;
      6.   Notify the chairperson of the village's ordinance committee
regarding subdividers and other persons or entities in violation of this title
regarding the initiation of proceedings against such subdividers and other
persons or entities as permitted under this title and the Illinois municipal
code; and
      7.   Maintain permanent and current records of this title, including
preliminary and final plats, maintaining all such records as public records in
cooperation with the village clerk. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-7-3: INTERPRETATION:
The interpretation and application of the regulations and standards of this
title, the provisions of these regulations and standards shall be held to be
the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety, and
general welfare. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-7-4: CONFLICT:
   (A)   Public Provisions: The regulations and standards of this title are not
intended to interfere with, abrogate, or annul any other rule, regulation,
statute, or any other provision of law. Where any provision of these
regulations and standards imposes restrictions different from those imposed by
any other provision of these regulations or any other ordinance, rule,
regulation, statute, or any other provision of law, whichever provisions are
more restrictive or impose higher standards shall control.
   (B)   Private Provisions: The regulations and standards of this title are
not intended to abrogate any easement, covenant, or any other private agreement
or restriction, provided that where the provisions of these regulations and
standards are more restrictive or impose higher regulations or standards than
such easement, covenant, or any other private agreement or restriction, the
requirements of these regulations and standards shall govern. (Ord. 2005-09,
12-19-2005)
11-7-5: VALIDITY; SEVERABILITY:
   (A)   If any court of competent jurisdiction shall declare invalid the
application of any provision of this title to a particular property, structure,
or land, such ruling shall not affect the application of said provision to any
other property, structure, or land not specifically included in said ruling.
   (B)   Should any section, clause, or provision of this title be declared
invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, the same shall not affect the
validity of this title as a whole or any part thereof, other than the part so
declared to be invalid. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-7-6: SAVING PROVISION:
The regulations and standards of this title shall not be construed as abating
any action now pending under, or by virtue of, prior existing subdivision
regulations and standards, or as discontinuing, abating, modifying or altering
any penalty accruing or about to accrue, or as affecting the liability of any
person, firm, corporation, or other legal entity, or as waiving any right of
the village under any section or provision existing at the time of the adoption
of these regulations and standards, or as vacating or annulling any rights
obtained by any person, firm, corporation, or other legal entity, by lawful
action of the village, except as shall be expressly provided for in these
regulations and standards. (Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-7-7: AMENDMENT:
For the purpose of protecting the public health, safety, and welfare, the
regulations, standards, and restrictions set forth in this title may from time
to time be amended, supplemented, changed, or repealed by ordinance, as
provided by law. No such action may be taken unless and until a request is made
to the plan commission for a change by any person, by the plan commission, or
by the village board, and public hearing is held thereon in the same fashion as
is provided in title 10, chapter 13 of this code for amendments to the zoning
code, except that the provisions in title 10, chapter 13 of this code regarding
notice to property owners located within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the
subject property and regarding a written protest or petition against any
proposed amendments or changes shall not apply to amendments to this title.
(Ord. 2005-09, 12-19-2005)
11-7-8: MODIFICATION:
Where the plan commission finds that extraordinary hardships, other than purely
financial or practical difficulties, may result from strict compliance with
this title, it may recommend to the village board a modification of the
regulations so that substantial justice may be done and the public interest
secured; provided, that such modification will not have the effect of
nullifying the purpose of the comprehensive plan or this title.
   (A)   Approval Of Modification: Neither the plan commission nor the village
board shall approve a modification to this title unless it finds in each
specific case, based upon the evidence presented by the petitioner, that all of
the following criteria have been met:
      1.   The granting of the modification will not be detrimental to the
public safety, health, or welfare, or injurious to other property;
      2.   The conditions upon which the modification request is based are
unique to the property for which the modification is sought and are not
applicable generally to other property;
      3.   Because of the particular physical surroundings, shape, or
topographical conditions of the specific property involved, a particular
hardship to the owner would result, as distinguished from a mere inconvenience,
if the strict letter of these regulations are carried out; and
      4.   The modification will not in any manner vary the provisions of the
zoning code.
   (B)   Large Scale Development: The standards and requirements of this title
may be modified by the village board upon the recommendation of the plan
commission in case of a plan or a program for a planned development for a
community, or a neighborhood unit, which in the judgment of the plan commission
shall exceed the minimum requirements for adequate public space and
improvements for circulation, recreation, light, air and service needs of the
tract when fully developed and populated and which also provides such covenants
or other legal provisions as will assure conformity to the purposes of the
comprehensive plan.
   (C)   Procedure For Seeking Modifications: Applications for any such
modification, except those initiated by the plan commission, shall be submitted
in writing by the subdivider with the subdivision application at the time when
the preliminary plat is filed for the consideration of the plan commission. The
petitions shall state fully the grounds for the modification request and all
the facts relied upon by the petitioner to make the modification request.
   (D)   Review By The Plan Commission And Village Board: In recommending a
modification as provided in this section, the plan commission or village board
may prescribe such conditions, as will, in their judgment, secure substantially
the objectives of the standards or requirements of these regulations and this
title in general. The recommendation of a modification by the plan commission
shall be conditional and subject to the final approval of the village board. In
reviewing a request for modification, the review and approval process shall be
the same as that provided in section
11-2-3 of this title at the same time the preliminary plat is reviewed by the
plan commission and the village board. However, the village board can take
action adverse to the plan commission by a majority vote rather than the two-
thirds (2/3) vote as set forth in subsection
11-2-3(J) of this title when the plan commission has voted to recommend
approval of a modification. If the plan commission votes to not recommend
approval of a modification, then the village board can only take adverse action
